Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of the City of Falls Church, Virginia," and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Falls Church City Code." 
(Code 1973, § 1-1; Code 1982, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Provisions requiring codification of ordinances, § 4.13. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to codify and recodify its ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the interpretation and construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the city as enacted by the General Assembly and printed in part I of this volume as it now exists and as it may be amended by the General Assembly in the future. 
    City. The term "city" or "the city" or "this city" means the City of Falls Church, in the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
    Code. The term "Code" means the Code of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Code of Virginia. The term "Code of Virginia" means the Code of Virginia of 1950, as amended from time to time. 
State Law reference- Official citation of the Code of Virginia, Code of Virginia, § 1-1. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, Code of Virginia, § 1-210. 
    Council, city council. The term "council" or "city council" means the city council of the City of Falls Church, Virginia. 
    County. The term "county" or "the county" means the County of Arlington in the State of Virginia. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision or section appears requiring the city manager, the head of a department of the city or any city officer to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize such person to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act, unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. The city manager or any specific officer or department head of the city grants such authority by the power vested in him in this Code, and such references also refer to the designee of the city manager, officer or department head. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-21. 
    Establishment. The term "establishment" means a place of business or operation of any kind, and shall include any person who is an owner, or the agent of such owner. 
    Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 1-216. 
    Health officer. The term "health officer" means the health officer of the Fairfax County State Health District or the authorized agent or representative of the health officer. 
    In the city. The term "in the city" means any territory, jurisdiction of which, for the exercise of its regulatory power, has been conferred on the city by public or private law. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 1-223. 
    Number. A word importing the singular only shall extend and be applied to several persons and things, and a word importing the plural only may apply to one person or thing. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 1-227. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
State Law reference- Oath, Code of Virginia, § 1-228. 
    Occupant. The term "occupant," when applied to a building or land, means any person who holds a written or oral lease of or actually occupies the whole or part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Officer, department, employee, board, committee, commission. Whenever reference is made to an officer, department, employee, board, committee, commission, etc., it shall be deemed to refer to an officer, department, employee, board, committee, commission, etc., of the City of Falls Church, Virginia. 
    Official time standard. Whenever particular hours are specified in this Code relating to the time within which any act shall be performed by any person, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
    Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" includes an individual, a firm, partnership, association of persons, corporation, organization, cooperative, limited liability company, trust, joint venture, government, political subdivision, or any other legal or commercial entity and any successor, representative, agent, agency, or instrumentality thereof or any other group acting as a unit. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 1-230. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" means real, personal or mixed property. 
    Public grounds. The term "public grounds" means the parks and all public lands owned or leased by the city, and those parts of public places which do not form traveled parts of streets as defined in this section. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write, the name of such person being written near it and being witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
    State, commonwealth. The term "commonwealth," "state" or "the state" means the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
    Street. The term "street" includes avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city, and means the entire width thereof between abutting property lines; it shall be construed to include a sidewalk or footpath, unless the contrary is expressed or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense may include the future, as well as the past and present. 
    Written and in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" include typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year, unless a fiscal year is indicated. 
(Code 1973, § 1-2; Code 1982, § 1-2; Ord. No. 1315, 6-11-1990) 
State Law reference- Statutes, definitions and rules of construction, Code of Virginia, § 1-200 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the 1982 Code and ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1973, § 1-3; Code 1982, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    If any part, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is for any reason declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 1-4; Code 1982, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Severability, Code of Virginia, § 1-243. 
Sec. 1-5. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1973, § 1-5; Code 1982, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Headlines of sections of statutes, Code of Virginia, § 1-217. 
Sec. 1-6. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the adoption of this Code, nor shall it affect any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered prior to the adoption of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(3)  Any ordinance granting any franchise or right; 
(4)  Any ordinance appropriating funds or relating to an annual budget and annual tax levy; 
(5)  Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement or any special assessment; 
(6)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
(7)  Any ordinance relating to the salaries of city officers or employees; 
(8)  Any ordinance annexing or excluding territory of the city; 
(9)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city; 
(10)  Any ordinance relating to the zoning district map; 
(11)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(12)  Any ordinance pertaining to fees, rates, charges and deposits; 
(13)  Any ordinance rezoning property or amending the zoning map; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 998, § 3, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 1-7. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-8. - References to chapters or sections. 
    All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-9. - References and editor's notes. 
    The references and editor's notes appearing throughout the Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to assist the user of the Code. 
Sec. 1-10. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code shall be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. For repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from affected reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provision by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section (number of section) of the Code of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, is hereby amended to read as follows: . . . ." 
(c)  If a new section not existing in this Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered (state new section number), which said section reads as follows: . . . ." The new section shall then be set out in full as adopted. 
(d)  All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
Charter reference- Ordinances, §§ 4.08-4.11. 
Sec. 1-11. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code may be prepared and printed when needed and when funds therefor are available. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed or replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate headlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such headlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______ to _______" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; 
but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
State Law reference- Authority to supplement Code, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433. 
Sec. 1-12. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the city, it is provided that a violation of any provision thereof shall constitute a class 1, 2, 3 or 4 misdemeanor, such violation shall be punishable as provided in Code of Virginia, § 18.2-11. 
(b)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city, or rule or regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor and no specific penalty is provided for the violation thereof, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $2,500.00 or by imprisonment in jail for a period of not exceeding 12 months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section or any other section of this Code, no penalty shall be imposed for a violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city which is greater than the penalty prescribed by the general law of the commonwealth for a like offense. 
(d)  Each day any violation of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute, except where otherwise provided, a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 1-7; Code 1982, § 1-7; Ord. No. 1349, 4-9-1991) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to impose penalties for violation of ordinances, § 2.06. 
Cross reference- Authorized punishments for conviction of misdemeanors, § 28-1. 
State Law reference- General powers of council to provide penalties for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1401; enforcement of ordinances and regulations, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1429; authority of court trying case, upon conviction, to require bond conditioned that the person convicted will not violate the ordinance for the breach of which he was convicted for a period of not more than one year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1430; injunctive relief for continuing violations of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1432; classification of criminal offenses and punishment therefor, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-8 et seq. 
Sec. 1-13. - Incorporation of state code provisions by reference. 
    Any and all provisions in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city that incorporate by reference or rely upon the Code of Virginia shall be deemed to include all subsequent amendments to the Code of Virginia, provided that such intent is specifically stated. 
(Code 1982, § 1-16; Ord. No. 1452, 9-13-1993) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-220.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal. 
(a)  The official seal of the city shall consist of a circle two inches in diameter with a rim enclosing a 11/4-inch circle of beads, and in the space between the rim and the beaded circle there shall be engraved the words, "City of Falls Church" separated by a star at either end of such words, and the word, "Virginia." In the inner circle there shall be the imprint of Falls Church with trees and tombstones. Above the imprint of the church there shall be the word, "Incorporated," with numerals "1948." 
(b)  The seal shall be the official and corporate seal for the city. It shall be affixed to all appropriate documents and shall be reposed in the custody of the city clerk for such official uses. 
(Code 1973, § 1-8; Code 1982, § 1-8) 
Charter reference- Provisions as to authority of city to have corporate seal, § 1.01. 
Secs. 2-2-2-20. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - PLANNING DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 38; zoning, ch. 48. 

Sec. 2-90. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a department of planning, which shall be headed by a director of planning. Such department shall consist of other officers and employees as may be duly provided. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(a)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-91. - Annual budget. 
    The annual budget for the planning department shall be prepared pursuant to the Charter, § 6.03 and adopted by council as provided in Charter, § 6.10. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(b)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-92. - Appointment of director. 
    The director of planning shall be appointed by the city manager, upon the advice of the planning commission and the city council. The director shall report to the city manager, who shall be in turn responsible for the performance of the director and the department, in support of the planning commission, the city council, other boards and commissions and other city departments, as well as in support of the city manager's full range of responsibilities. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(c)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-93. - Responsibilities. 
    The planning department is responsible for: 
(1)  Supporting the planning commission through the coordination and administration of site plan and subdivision review, formulation or evaluation of master plan and zoning text and map revisions, and the conduct of such other activities as may be related to such support, including the official custody of commission records. 
(2)  Supporting the city council or any city board or commission on any matter, as referred to the department by the council through the city manager. 
(3)  Supporting the city manager and other city departments on matters of planning and forecasting as these may relate to any function of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(d)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-94. - Exercise of responsibilities. 
    In the exercise of its responsibilities, the planning department shall coordinate its work, conclusions and recommendations with all other affected city officials. In carrying out its responsibilities relative to master plan, zoning and capital improvement programming matters, including the review of related legislation, the department shall: 
(1)  Determine and describe the extent to which each proposal appears to be consistent with existing development regulations and planning practices, referring questions of law to the city attorney. 
(2)  Comment, professionally, on the merits and make recommendations based on identified and relevant facts, clearly distinguishing facts from judgment. 
(3)  Determine whether a proposal is in a form consistent with existing development regulations or if it could be recast in a more effective manner for achieving what is stated. If it is not in a consistent form or if it could be recast in a more effective manner, an alternative shall be either requested from the sponsor by the department or the department may prepare its own for consideration as an alternative or an amendment to the basic proposal. Each of the functions above shall be so carried out that the product of each is clearly distinguishable from the products of the exercise of the other responsibilities. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(e)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq. 
Sec. 2-95. - Requests for information. 
    In the exercise of its responsibilities, the department may request such information and advice from other departments and officials as may be necessary to the discharge of its responsibilities. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1982, § 2-2(f)) 
Charter reference- Planning, zoning and subdivision control, § 17.01 et seq.

ARTICLE IV. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority regarding creation, etc., of boards, committees, commissions, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1107. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-119. - General requirements for citizen bodies appointed by city council. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the council for any given body: 
(1)  Annual business meeting. Every citizen body shall hold an annual business meeting for the purpose of electing officers, adopting rules of procedure and adopting a basic schedule of regular meetings for the coming year. Such business meeting shall be held within two months following the annual appointment of new fullterm members or the anniversary of their appointment. 
(2)  Rules of procedure. Every citizen body shall adopt and conduct its activities pursuant to rules of procedure consistent with the requirements of the Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3700 et seq., the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, the city Charter, this section and the Charter of the body. Such rules and any subsequent changes shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and available for reference by all who wish to see them. 
(3)  Minimum procedural requirements. The following minimum procedural requirements shall be included in the rules of procedure adopted under subsection (2) of this section: 
a.  An oath of office is required of all new appointees. 
b.  Officers of citizen bodies shall be elected annually within two months following: 
1.  The annual appointment of new fullterm members; or 
2.  The anniversary of their appointment. 
c.  The basic schedule of regular meetings for the ensuing year shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
d.  A quorum for the taking of actions shall consist of at least a simple majority. Meetings may be conducted for the purpose of exchange of information without a quorum. 
e.  The terms and conditions under which the public may speak and be heard at meetings of any citizen body may be set forth in the rules of procedure for the body. 
f.  Summary minutes shall be kept of all meetings. Draft minutes shall be filed with the city clerk promptly and the city clerk will circulate them to city councilmembers. An annual report highlighting the previous year's activity shall be presented to the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting according to the following schedule: reports should be presented during the month previous to the month in which terms for that particular board/commission expire (e.g., reports are presented in February for boards/commissions with terms expiring at the end of March). This also applies to appointees to regional boards and commissions. The nomination schedule listing the months when terms expire is printed in the boards', commissions' and committees' brochure. 
Subsections (3)c. and e. of this section do not apply to the city employee review board, the retirement board, the private school and day care facility board, the other post employment benefits finance board and the building board of appeals. 
(4)  Newly created citizen bodies. Every new citizen body established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall hold an organizational meeting within 30 days of the appointment of its membership. Such meetings shall be convened by a temporary chair appointed from among the members by the mayor. A permanent chair and vice-chair shall be elected by the members from among themselves at the organizational meeting. 
(Code 1982, § 2-1; Ord. No. 732; Ord. No. 1493, 10-11-1994) 
Secs. 2-120-2-136. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ARCHITECTURAL ADVISORY BOARD[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; condominiums, § 6-48 et seq.; housing, ch. 22; zoning, ch. 48. 

Sec. 2-137. - Purpose of division. 
    The purpose of this division is to: 
(1)  Conserve property values and to obtain a beneficial relationship between taxable values of real property and the cost of municipal services; 
(2)  Promote the general welfare by encouraging such design of buildings and other structures as will avoid both excessive uniformity and inappropriate dissimilarity; 
(3)  Encourage the most appropriate use of land with equal respect to sound economics and reasonable harmony with such existing buildings as are generally recognized to be in good taste or to have a lasting historical value. 
(Code 1973, § 2-7; Code 1982, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-138. - Established; composition; appointment; terms of office of members; chair; consultants. 
(a)  There is hereby established an architectural advisory board consisting of five persons who shall be residents of the city. All members shall be appointed for staggered terms of three years. The city council shall designate the first chair of the board, and thereafter the board shall annually elect its chair and such other officers as it may deem necessary. 
(b)  The city council may appoint not more than two nonresidents as nonvoting consultants to the board if the purposes of this division would be better accomplished by appointment of such consultants who would be appointed for one-year terms. 
(c)  The board shall also and in addition consist of an alternate member, who shall be a resident of the city, and who shall exercise full voting rights in the absence of a regular member. The term of office shall be for three years. 
(Code 1973, § 2-8; Code 1982, § 2-4; Ord. No. 867; Ord. No. 1026, 9-27-1982) 
Sec. 2-139. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The architectural advisory board's powers are advisory, and its findings and recommendations shall not have the force and effect of enforceable regulations. The board's powers are applicable to all zoning districts under the zoning regulations except R-1A and R-1B. 
(b)  The board shall review the architectural features of buildings and structures, and alterations thereto, including sites and all auxiliary features such as signs and lights proposed in the designated zones. The board shall consider the general design, arrangement, texture, materials and color and the appropriateness of these matters in relationship to other structures and area characteristics. 
(Code 1973, § 2-9; Code 1982, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-140. - Procedures. 
(a)  Findings and recommendations on matters of architectural design. 
(1)  Upon receipt of an application for a building permit or site plan approval or upon prior request from the owner or builder, the building inspector shall collaborate with the zoning administrator to give notice to the chair of the architectural advisory board of a proposed new structure or alteration to exterior of an existing structure, stating the location and type of work contemplated. Immediately upon receipt of design drawings from the builder, a copy of each pertinent part shall be transmitted to the chair of the board, together with descriptive data on material, texture, color and any other item related to appearance and design. The board shall review the data submitted and tender its written findings and recommendations to the zoning administrator, who shall make such findings and recommendations available to the applicant. 
(2)  The board shall reduce to writing its findings and recommendations, and, if the proposed structure is disapproved, the findings shall state that: 
a.  The objectionable features are of such nature as to be expected to provoke beyond reasonable doubt one or more departures from the purposes set forth in this article; and 
b.  The findings are not based on personal preference as to taste or architectural style. 
(3)  The zoning administrator in all cases shall confer with the chair of the board and at their mutual discretion shall arrange a conference between the zoning administrator, the builder or such builder's advisors and the board, to seek a consensus on any matter affecting design and architectural compatibility in the designated zone. 
(4)  If the board has not transmitted its recommendations to the zoning administrator within 15 days of receipt of the design drawings, the board shall be deemed to have waived its function. 
(b)  Findings and recommendations on matters of signs. 
(1)  When the proposed structure consists only of one or more signs, the board shall be provided with a copy of the application for a sign permit and any supporting material, shall initiate its review on the basis of the information contained therein and shall make findings and recommendations in the manner specified in subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  The board shall have discretion whether to make separate findings and recommendations relating to proposed signs which are included in plans or designs submitted for review under subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 2-10; Code 1982, § 2-6) 
Secs. 2-141-2-163. - Reserved.
