DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, ch. 16. 

Sec. 2-185. - Appointment. 
    The head of the department of finance shall be known as the director of finance, who shall be, or be appointed by, the city manager. In making such appointment, the city manager shall give consideration to the applicant's qualifications in municipal finance and financial control. 
Sec. 2-186. - Powers and duties. 
    The director of finance shall have general management and control of the functions of the department. He shall appoint and remove, subject to the provisions of chapter 9 of the city Charter, all officers and employees of the department, excepting constitutional officers, and shall have power to make rules and regulations consistent with this Charter and the ordinances of the city for the conduct of its business. He shall have charge, subject to the direction and control of the city manager, of the administration of the financial affairs of the city, except those of the school board, unless specified in this chapter, and to that end shall have authority and be required to: 
(1)  Compile the departmental estimates and other data necessary or useful to the city manager in the preparation of the current expense and capital budgets. 
(2)  Supervise and control all encumbrances, expenditures and disbursement to insure that budget appropriations are not exceeded. 
(3)  Maintain a general accounting system for the city government and each of its departments, boards, commissions, offices and agencies, in conformity with the best recognized practices in governmental accounting; and encumber each item of appropriation with the amount of each purchase order, payroll or contract which he has approved, including each advance authorization as provided in subsection (6) of this section. 
(4)  Prescribe the form of receipts, vouchers, bills or claims to be used, and of accounts to be kept by all departments, boards, commissions, offices and agencies of the city, provided that in so doing he shall consult with any officer appointed by the council for the purpose. 
(5)  Require daily, or at such other intervals as he may deem expedient, a report of receipt from each of such departments, boards, commissions, offices and agencies, and prescribe the times at and the manner in which moneys received by them shall be paid to the office of the director of finance or deposited in a city bank account under the control of the city treasurer. 
(6)  Examine all contracts, purchase orders and other documents, except bonds and notes authorized as provided in chapter 7 of the city Charter, which create financial obligations against the city and approve the same only upon ascertaining that money has been appropriated therefor and that an unexpended and unencumbered balance is available in such appropriation to meet the same, provided that the director of finance may give advance authorization for the expenditure from any appropriation for the purchase of supplies, materials or equipment of such sum, within such appropriation, as he may deem necessary during a period of not to exceed 12 months for the purchase of items not to exceed in cost $100.00 for any one item, and immediately encumber such appropriation with the amount of such advance authorization, and thereafter, within the period specified, purchase orders for such items, to an aggregate not exceeding such authorization, shall be valid without the prior approval of the director of finance endorsed thereon, but each such purchase order shall be charged against such authorization and no such purchase order, which, together with all such purchase orders previously charged within the period specified, shall exceed the amount of such authorization, shall be valid. 
(7)  Audit before payment, for legality and correctness, all accounts, claims and demands against the city, and no money shall be drawn from any bank account of the city or school board except by warrant or check, signed by the director of finance, based upon a voucher duly approved by him as above provided. 
(8)  Submit to the city manager for presentation to the council not later than the tenth day of the first month of each quarter, a statement concerning the financial transactions of the city and each utility respectively, prepared in accordance with accepted principles of municipal accounting and budgetary procedure, and showing: 
a.  The amount of each appropriation with transfers to and from the same; and 
b.  The revenue estimated to be received from each source, and actual receipts from each source for the preceding months, the total receipts from each source for the fiscal year to the end of the preceding month, and the balance remaining to be collected. 
(9)  Furnish to the head of each department, court, board, commission, office and agency of the city a copy of that portion of the statement relating to such department, court, board, commission, office and agency of the city. 
(10)  Prepare and submit to the city manager at the end of each fiscal year, for the preceding year, a complete financial statement and report of the financial transactions of the city. 
(11)  Protect the interests of the city by withholding the payment of any claim or demand by any person, firm or corporation against the city until any indebtedness or other liability due from such person shall first have been settled and adjusted. 
Secs. 2-187-2-209. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC PROPERTY AND FACILITIES 

Sec. 2-210. - Naming of public property or facility. 
(a)  Criteria for naming city facilities. City facilities, including buildings and parks, ("facilities") shall generally be named according to the geographical, historical, or ecological relationships in which the site is located. Exceptions may be made in the following circumstances: 
(1)  To commemorate an individual's service: Facilities may be named after an individual who has made significant contributions to the City of Falls Church through participation in community, state, or national service. 
(2)  To help identify the facilities purpose/usage: A name may be assigned to a city facility if it helps to describe and identify the usage or purpose of the facility. 
(b)  Renaming city facilities. Renaming a city facility can occur if: 
(1)  The criteria of subsection (a) are met; 
(2)  A valid justification for renaming the facility is provided; 
(3)  Changing the name will not cause undue confusion within the community; and 
(4)  An appropriate level of community support exists. 
(c)  Process for naming city facilities. 
(1)  The naming of any city-owned building, park, or other city-owned facility shall be by resolution of the city council. 
(2)  Individuals and/or organizations may make recommendations to the city council regarding the naming or renaming of facilities, parks, public open space areas and other related components of facilities. 
(3)  Prior to adopting a resolution naming a city-owned facility, the city council shall hold a public hearing, and shall seek a recommendation from the following: The planning commission; the historical commission; the recreation and parks advisory board; and any other boards and/or commissions or community organization that the city council deems appropriate. 
(d)  The naming of school facilities shall be by action of the city school board, and is not subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 2-7; Ord. No. 1305, 5-14-1990; Ord. No. 1855, 3-14-2011) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate animals and fowl, § 2.04. 
Cross reference- Noise, § 14-49 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Comprehensive animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.2.6500 et seq.; authority of city to adopt ordinances paralleling animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6543. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Cruelty; trapping and poisoning prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall override, overdrive, overload, torture, ill-treat, abandon, willfully inflict inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly or unnecessarily beat, maim, mutilate or kill any animal, whether belonging to such person or another, or deprive any animal of necessary sustenance, food or drink, shelter or emergency veterinary treatment or sores any equine for any purpose or administer drugs or medications to alter or mask such soring for the purpose of sale, show, or exhibition of any kind, unless such administration of drugs or medications is within the context of a veterinary client-patient relationship and solely for therapeutic purposes; or, being the owner of such animal, permit such acts to be done by another; willfully set foot on, instigate, engage in or in any way further any act of cruelty to any animal; or carry or cause to be carried in or upon any vehicle or vessel or otherwise any animal in a cruel, brutal or inhumane manner, so as to produce torture or unnecessary suffering or cause any of the above things or, being the owner of such animal, permit such acts to be done by another. Such person shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the dehorning of cattle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to set or bait any trap or other contrivance for the catching of game or tame animals, or to knowingly permit any such trap to be set or baited on such person's premises or property, or to set out any poisoned bait with the intent of poisoning any game or tame animal except by the consent of the city animal control officer or state game warden. 
(Code 1973, § 4-1; Code 1982, § 4-1; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
State Law reference- Specific authority to adopt (a) of above section, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6543; general authority of city to prevent cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6569; cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6570. 
Sec. 4-2. - Limitations on companion animals and pets allowed per dwelling unit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep more than three dogs over four months of age or four cats over four months of age or a total of seven companion animals per dwelling unit in the city. 
(b)  Companion animals for which the animal control officer, prior to January 1, 2005, has issued a permit shall be exempt from the limitation of the number of companion animal pets stated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Any person, on February 1, 1998, being the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, who is lawfully keeping more than the number of dogs and cats permitted by this section shall be entitled to continue to keep all such dogs and cats, so long as they are duly licensed and inoculated in accordance with this chapter. However, it shall be unlawful for any such person to replace such dog or cat unless the total number dogs and cats kept by the person does not exceed the number of dogs and cats permitted by subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  This limitation shall not apply to any person authorized to operate a kennel, being any establishment in which five or more canines, felines, or hybrids of either are kept for the purpose of breeding, hunting, training, renting, buying, boarding, selling or showing. 
(Code 1982, § 4-1.1; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
Sec. 4-3. - Keeping of wild or exotic animals. 
(a)  Prohibition; exception. No person shall keep or permit to be kept on the premises of such person any live wild or exotic animal. This section shall not be construed to apply to zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, circuses or veterinary clinics which are properly licensed by the federal government or Commonwealth of Virginia. In no case, however, shall such wild or exotic animals be exhibited or displayed in such a manner that persons other than the handler of such animal can pet, fondle or otherwise come in direct physical contact with such animals. 
(b)  Applicability. The term "wild or exotic animals" means any animal except: 
(1)  Dogs, cats, hamsters, gerbils, guinea pigs, ferrets, and birds which are normally purchased through a pet store; 
(2)  Gold fish and aquarium fish; 
(3)  Nonpoisonous snakes, less than eight feet in length; and 
(4)  Domestic rabbits, mice and rats which have been bred in captivity and which never have known the wild. 
(Code 1982, § 4-1.2; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998) 
Sec. 4-4. - At large animals or fowl. 
(a)  No person shall fasten, turn at large or permit to graze or roam about on any street within the city any animal except as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  No person residing within the city shall permit fowl of any kind, being on such person's property or being under such person's charge, to run at large upon any street or other public place or to trespass upon the land or property of another against such person's will or consent. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2; Code 1982, § 4-2; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit the running at large of animals, § 2.04. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate running at large and keeping of animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6543. 
Sec. 4-5. - Impounding of animals running at large; disposal. 
    Any animal found running at large in violation of section 4-4 shall be taken into custody by the animal control officer or other proper official and held until the owner shall have paid the penalty and costs imposed upon such owner, together with the cost of maintaining such animal while in the pound. Any animal held five days or longer under this provision shall be disposed of in the same manner as is provided in section 4-77. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3; Code 1982, § 4-3; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
State Law reference- Seizure and impoundment of animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6546. 
Sec. 4-6. - Permitting animals to trespass. 
    The owner of any animal, after being requested by the owner or tenant of any premises not to permit the animal to trespass upon such premises, shall not allow any such animal to go upon such premises. In addition, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to capture and confine any unrestricted animal found off the property of its owner or of undetermined ownership when such animal is causing a public nuisance or a threat to public safety or health, excluding dogs which are prohibited by section 4-73 from running unrestricted at all times. Any impoundment shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 4-7. 
(Code 1973, § 4-4; Code 1982, § 4-4; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Sec. 4-7. - Burial or cremation of dead animals and fowl. 
    The owner of any animal or fowl which has died, when said owner knows of such death, shall forthwith have its body cremated, buried or otherwise disposed of in a manner acceptable to the city animal control officer. Should the owner of any dead animal or dead fowl fail to comply with the provisions of this section within 48 hours following receipt of the written notice to such owner by the city animal control officer, said city animal control officer shall be authorized to cause any such dead animal or fowl to be cremated, buried or disposed of at the expense of said owner. 
(Code 1973, § 4-5; Code 1982, § 4-5; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
State Law reference- Disposal of dead companion animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6554. 
Secs. 4-8-4-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6500 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-37. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Confined to their premises means dogs shall be kept on the owner's premises, unless in the custody of a responsible person or, in the case of hunting, when dogs are under the control of a responsible person. 
    Dangerous dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has bitten, attacked, or inflicted injury on a person or companion animal that is a dog or cat, or killed a companion animal that is a dog or cat. However, when a dog attacks or bites a companion animal that is a dog or cat, the attacking or biting dog shall not be deemed dangerous if: 
(1)  No serious physical injury, as determined by a licensed veterinarian, has occurred to the dog or cat as a result of the attack or bite; 
(2)  Both animals are owned by the same person; 
(3)  Such attack occurs on the property of the attacking or biting dog's owner or custodian; or 
(4)  For other good cause as determined by the court. 
No dog shall be found to be a dangerous dog as a result of biting, attacking, or inflicting injury on a dog or cat while engaged with an owner or custodian as part of lawful hunting or participating in an organized, lawful dog handling event. 
    Hearing dog means a dog trained to alert its owner by touch to sounds of danger and sounds to which the owner should respond. 
    Owner means any person having a right of property in a dog, and any person who keeps or harbors a dog, or has it in the care of such person, or who acts as its custodian and any person who permits a dog to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person. 
    Service dog means a dog trained to accompany its owner for the purpose of carrying items, retrieving objects, pulling a wheelchair or other such activities of service or support. 
    Vicious dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has: 
(1)  Killed a person; 
(2)  Inflicted serious injury to person, including multiple bites, serious disfigurement, serious impairment of health, or serious impairment of a bodily function; or 
(3)  Continued to exhibit the behavior that resulted in a previous finding by a court or an animal control officer as authorized pursuant to section 4-101, that it is dangerous, provided that its owner has been given notice of that finding. 
(Code 1973, § 4-10; Code 1982, § 4-10; Ord. No. 1100, 2-25-1985; Ord. No. 1308, 5-14-1990; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definition of dangerous and vicious dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540. 
Sec. 4-38. - Animal control officer-Office created; salary. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to employ or appoint an animal control officer of the city at a salary to be fixed by the council. 
(Code 1973, § 4-11; Code 1982, § 4-11; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Animal control officer, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6557. 
Sec. 4-39. - Same-Duties. 
    The duties of the animal control officer shall be as follows: 
(1)  Enforcement of the provisions of this article governing the running at large of dogs. 
(2)  Enforcement of the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city and the laws of the state governing the licensing of dogs by the owners. 
(3)  Investigation of dog damage claims and the rendering of a report to the council. 
(4)  Patrolling the city as directed by the city manager. 
(5)  Collection and disposal of dead dogs. 
(Code 1973, § 4-12; Code 1982, § 4-12; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-40. - Dog control required. 
(a)  Responsibility of owner; waiver. All dogs shall be kept secured by a leash or lead, and under the immediate control of the owner or other responsible person, or shall be kept within the real property limits that are subject to the control of the dog's owner or the person having responsibility of the dog. A written waiver of this requirement for a specific time and place may be obtained from the animal control officer for such activities as off-lead training, obedience matches and trials, exhibitions, when the dog has a skin condition which would be exacerbated by the wearing of a collar, and other activities compatible with animal control. 
(b)  Exercising dogs; exception. Nothing in this section or in any other section shall be deemed to make unlawful the exercising of dogs not secured by a leash or lead in such areas of the city specifically designated by the city council with appropriate signs for such exercising. This section shall not apply to dogs used by government law enforcement agencies. 
(c)  Violation and penalty. Upon conviction of a violation of this section, owners or the responsible person, as the case may be, shall be subject to a fine of up to $100.00, plus the cost of impoundment. The chief judge of the General District Court shall have the authority to fix a prepayable fine, which shall be in addition to the impoundment cost. 
(Code 1973, § 4-15; Code 1982, § 4-15; Ord. No. 1090, 11-26-1984; Ord. No. 1100, 2-25-1985; Ord. No. 1308, 5-14-1990; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit dogs running at large, § 2.04. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit dogs from running at large, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6538. 
Sec. 4-41. - Failure to remove excrement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, keeper or walker of a dog to fail to immediately remove the dog's excrement from any property other than the dog owner's property. Any violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00. 
(Code 1973, § 4-15; Code 1982, § 4-15; Ord. No. 1090, 11-26-1984; Ord. No. 1100, 2-25-1985; Ord. No. 1308, 5-14-1990; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit dogs running at large, § 2.04. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit dogs from running at large, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6538. 
Secs. 4-42-4-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Provision authorizing issuance of licenses, § 2.07. 
Cross reference- Business, professional, occupational licenses, § 40-456 et seq. 
State Law reference- Licensing of dogs, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.2-6524-3.2-6531. 

Sec. 4-56. - Required; tax on dogs and kennels. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own a dog four months old or older in the city unless such dog is licensed, as required by provisions of this Code. Any dog not wearing a collar bearing a current license tag shall prima facie be deemed to be an unlicensed dog and, in any proceeding under this Code, the burden of proof of the fact that the dog has been licensed shall be on the owner of the dog. No license tag shall be issued for any dog unless there is presented to the treasurer, at the time of application for such license, the certificate of rabies vaccination required by section 4-125. 
(b)  License tax; fees. 
(1)  There is hereby provided and levied an animal license tax upon dogs within the city, four months old or older, consisting of the following fees: 
a.  Fertile males and females, a $10.00 fee; and 
b.  Infertile males and females, a $5.00 fee. Any person who applies for a license tag for a neutered or infertile dog shall present at the time of application a certification from a licensed veterinarian attesting the neutering or infertility of the dog. If such certification is not so presented, the dog shall be taxed the fee levied on fertile dogs. 
(2)  No license tax shall be levied on any dog: 
a.  That is trained and serves as a guide dog for a blind person; 
b.  That is trained and serves as a hearing dog for a deaf or hearing impaired person; or 
c.  That is trained and serves as a service dog for a mobility-impaired person. 
(3)  The fee for a kennel of 20 dogs shall not exceed $25.00 annually; and the fee for a kennel of 50 dogs shall not exceed $35.00 annually. 
(c)  On January 1 and not later than January 31 in the year in which the dog's rabies tag expires, the owner of any dog four months old or older shall pay a license tax as prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  If a dog shall become four months of age or come into the possession of any person between January 2 and November 2 of any year, the license tax for the current calendar year shall be paid forthwith by the owner. 
(e)  If a dog shall become four months of age or come into the possession of any person between October 31 and December 31 of any year, the license tax for the succeeding calendar year shall be paid forthwith by the owner and such license shall protect such dog from the date of purchase. 
(f)  If a dog license tag shall become lost, destroyed or stolen, the owner or custodian shall at once apply to the treasurer, or the treasurer's agent who issued the license, for a duplicate license tag. Upon affidavit of the owner or custodian before the treasurer or the treasurer's agent that the original license tag has been lost, destroyed or stolen, the treasurer shall issue a duplicate license tag which the owner or custodian shall immediately affix to the collar of the dog. 
(Code 1973, § 4-13; Code 1982, § 4-13; Ord. No. 770; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998) 
Sec. 4-57. - Failure to obtain license. 
    Every dog for which a license has not been obtained within 30 days after such license is required by law may be taken up wherever and whenever found within the city and kept, unless redeemed by owner, for a period of five days and disposed of as provided in section 4-77. 
(Code 1973, § 4-14; Code 1982, § 4-14; Ord. No. 905) 
Secs. 4-58-4-72. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 4-73. - Conditions for seizure. 
    Any dog not under control or confined to its owner's premises as required by section 4-40, or not subject to the exceptions of section 4-40, shall be seized and impounded as directed by the police chief or the designated agent for the chief of police. The owner would be required to pay the cost of impoundment. 
(Code 1973, § 4-16; Code 1982, § 4-16; Ord. No. 1100, 2-25-1985; Ord. No. 1308, 5-14-1990) 
State Law reference- Confinement and disposition of animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6546; impoundment of stray animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6569. 
Sec. 4-74. - Redemption; fee. 
    An animal confined pursuant to this division shall be kept for a period of not less than five days, such period to commence on the day immediately following the day the animal is initially confined in the facility, unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner. Any dog so seized and impounded may be redeemed by the owner at any time, within five days after its impoundment, upon payment of a fee to be determined by the city manager for board of such dog. Such fees shall be payable, as the city treasurer shall direct, as compensation for the cost of seizing and keeping such dog. 
(Code 1973, § 4-17; Code 1982, § 4-17) 
State Law reference- Confinement and notice to owner, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6546 B. 
Sec. 4-75. - Pound procedures. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal shall not include agricultural animals. 
    Rightful owner means a person with a right of property in the animal. 
(b)  The operator or custodian of the pound shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain whether the animal has a collar, tag, license, tattoo, or other form of identification. If such identification is found on the animal, the animal shall be held for an additional five days, unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner. If the rightful owner of the animal can be readily identified, the operator or custodian of the pound shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner of the animal's confinement within the next 48 hours following its confinement. 
(c)  If any animal confined pursuant to this section is claimed by its rightful owner, such owner may be charged with the actual expenses incurred in keeping the animal impounded. 
(d)  If an animal confined pursuant to this section has not been claimed upon expiration of the appropriate holding period as provided by this article, it shall be deemed abandoned and become the property of the pound. Such animal may be humanely destroyed or disposed of by the methods set forth as follows in subsection (d)(1) through (5) of this section; however the pound shall release more than two animals or a family of animals during any 30-day period to any one person under subsection (d)(2), (3), or (4) of this section: 
(1)  Release to any humane society, animal shelter, or other releasing agency within the Commonwealth, provided that each humane society, animal shelter, or other releasing agency obtains a signed statement from each of its directors, operators, staff, or animal caregivers specifying that each individual has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment and updates such statements as changes occur; 
(2)  Adoption by a resident of the county or city who will pay the required license fee, if any, on such animal, provided that such resident has read and signed a statement specifying that the resident has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment; 
(3)  Adoption by a resident of an adjacent political subdivision of the Commonwealth, provided that such resident has read and signed a statement specifying that the resident has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment; 
(4)  Adoption by any other person, provided that such person has read and signed a statement specifying that the person has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment, and provided that no animal may be adopted by any person who is not a resident of the county or city for which the pound is operated, or of an adjacent political subdivision, unless the animal is first sterilized, and the pound may require that the sterilization be done at the expense of the person adopting the animal; or 
(5)  Release, for the purposes of adoption or euthanasia only, to an animal shelter, or any other releasing agency located in and lawfully operating under the laws of another state, provided that such animal shelter or other releasing agency: 
a.  Maintains records that would comply with Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6557; 
b.  Requires that adopted dogs and cats be sterilized; 
c.  Obtains a signed statement from each of its directors, operators, staff, and animal caregivers specifying that each individual has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment, and updates such statement as changes occur; and 
d.  Has provided to the pound, animal shelter, or other releasing agency within the Commonwealth a statement signed by an authorized representative specifying the entity's compliance with subsections (a) through (c) of this section, and the provisions of adequate care and performance of humane euthanasia, as necessary in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
For purposes of recordkeeping, release of an animal by a pound to a pound, animal shelter or other releasing agency shall be considered a transfer and not an adoption. If the animal is not first sterilized, the responsibility for sterilizing the animal transfers to the receiving entity. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the immediate euthanasia of a critically injured, critically ill, or unweaned animal for humane purposes. Any animal euthanized pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be euthanized by one of the methods prescribed or approved by the state veterinarian. 
(f)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the immediate euthanasia or disposal, by the methods listed in subsection (d)(1) through (5) of this section, of an animal that has been released to a pound, animal shelter, other releasing agency, or animal control officer by the animal's rightful owner after the rightful owner has read and signed a statement: 
(1)  Surrendering all property rights in such animal; 
(2)  Stating that no other person has a right of property in the animal; and 
(3)  Acknowledging that the animal may be immediately euthanized or disposed of in accordance with subsection (d)(1) through (5) of this section. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit any feral dog or feral cat not bearing a collar, tag, tattoo, or other form of identification which, based on the written statement of a disinterested person, exhibits behavior that poses a risk of physical injury to any person confining the animal, from being euthanized after being kept for a period of not less than three days, at least one of which shall be a full business day, such period to commence on the day the animal is initially confined in the facility, unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner. The statement of the disinterested person shall be kept with the animal as required by Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6557. For purposes of this subsection, a disinterested person shall not include a person releasing or reporting the animal. 
(h)  No pound shall place a companion animal in a foster home with a foster care provider unless the foster care provider has read and signed a statement specifying that he has never been convicted of animal cruelty, neglect, or abandonment, and each pound shall update such statement as changes occur. The pound shall maintain the original statement and any updates to such statement in accordance with this division and for at least so long as the pound has an affiliation with the foster care provider. 
(i)  A pound that places a companion animal in a foster home with a foster care provider shall ensure that the foster care provider complies with Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6503. 
(j)  If a pound finds a direct and immediate threat to a companion animal placed with a foster care provider, it shall report its findings to the animal control agency in the locality where the foster care provider is located. 
(k)  The pound must be operated in accordance with regulations issued by the state board of agriculture and consumer services. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6546. 
Sec. 4-76. - Suspicion of rabies. 
    No dog shall be released if rabid or suspected of being rabid, but such dog shall be destroyed or held for further examination, at the discretion of a licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1973, § 4-18; Code 1982, § 4-18) 
State Law reference- Rabid animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6522. 
Sec. 4-77. - Disposition of unredeemed dogs. 
(a)  Any dogs which are not redeemed within five days from the date of their seizure shall be humanely destroyed or disposed of by sale or gift to a federal agency, state-supported institution, agency of the commonwealth, agency of another state or a licensed federal dealer, or by delivery to any local humane society or shelter. 
(b)  Any animal destroyed pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be euthanized by one of the methods prescribed or approved by the state veterinarian. Any money derived from the sale of such dogs shall be deposited as directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 4-19; Code 1982, § 4-19; Ord. No. 905) 
State Law reference- Disposition of animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6546. 
Secs. 4-78-4-92. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS DOGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Dangerous or vicious dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540. 

Sec. 4-93. - Determination procedure. 
    Any animal control officer who has reason to believe that a canine or canine crossbreed within the city is a dangerous or vicious dog shall apply to a magistrate for the issuance of a summons requiring the owner or custodian, if known, to appear before a general district court at a specified time. The summons shall advise the owner or custodian of the nature of the proceeding and the matters at issue. The animal control officer shall confine the animal until such time as evidence shall be heard and a verdict rendered. If the animal control officer determines that the owner or custodian can confine the animal in a manner that protects the public safety, such officer may permit the owner or custodian to confine the animal until such time as evidence shall be heard and a verdict rendered. If the animal control officer or police officer orders such confinement, the animal may not be removed from the owner's or custodian's immediate property and must be secured on a leash no longer than six feet when not confined indoors or locked within an adequate structure. Failure to comply with such an order shall be a violation of this section. The court, through its contempt powers, may compel the owner, custodian or harborer of the animal to produce the animal. If, after hearing the evidence, the court finds the animal is a dangerous dog, the court shall order the animal's owner or custodian to comply with the provisions of section 4-95. If, after hearing the evidence, the court finds that the animal is a vicious dog, the court shall order the animal euthanized by the animal control officer in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6562. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(a); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Sec. 4-94. - Breed determination prohibited; exempted acts; exceptions. 
(a)  No canine or canine crossbreed shall be found to be a dangerous or vicious dog solely because it is a particular breed, nor is the ownership of a particular breed of canine or canine crossbreed prohibited. 
(b)  No animal shall be found to be a dangerous or vicious dog if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who was: 
(1)  Committing, at the time, a crime upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; 
(2)  Committing, at the time, a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; or 
(3)  Provoking, tormenting, or physically abusing the animal, or can be shown to have repeatedly provoked, tormented, abused, or assaulted the animal at other times. 
(c)  No police dog which was engaged in the performance of its duties at the time of the acts complained of shall be found to be a dangerous or vicious dog. 
(d)  No animal which, at the time of the acts complained of, was responding to pain or injury, or was protecting itself, its kennel, its offspring, a person or its owner's or custodian's property shall be found to be a dangerous or vicious dog. If the owner of an animal found to be a dangerous dog is a minor, the custodial parent or legal guardian shall be responsible for complying with all requirements of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982(b), § 4-20; Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Sec. 4-95. - Registration certificate. 
    The owner or custodian of an animal found by a court to be a dangerous dog shall, within ten days of such finding, obtain a dangerous dog registration certificate from the animal control officer for a fee of $50.00, in addition to other fees that may be authorized by law. The animal control officer shall also provide the owner or custodian with a uniformly designed tag which identifies the animal as a dangerous dog. The owner or custodian shall affix the tag to the animal's collar and ensure that the animal wears the collar and tag at all times. All certificates obtained pursuant to this section shall be renewed annually for the same fee and in the same manner as the initial certificate was obtained. If the owner or custodian fails to obtain such a certificate within the time allotted, the animal control officer shall have the power to seize the animal and euthanize the animal in accordance with state law. The animal control officer shall provide a copy of the dangerous dog registration certificate and verification of compliance to the state veterinarian. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(c); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Sec. 4-96. - Requirements for certificates or renewals. 
(a)  All dangerous dog certificates or renewals required to be obtained under this section shall only be issued to persons 18 years of age or older who present satisfactory evidence that: 
(1)  The animal has a current rabies vaccination; 
(2)  The animal has been neutered or spayed; 
(3)  The animal: 
a.  Is and will be confined in a proper enclosure designed to prevent its escape; 
b.  Is and will be confined inside the owner's or custodian's residence, or is and will be muzzled and confined in the owner's or custodian's fenced-in yard with adequate shelter until the proper enclosure is constructed; 
(4)  The residence of the owner or custodian is and will continue to be posted with clearly visible signs warning both minors and adults of the presence of a dangerous dog on the property; and 
(5)  The animal has been permanently identified by means of a tattoo on the inside thigh or by electronic implant. 
(b)  All certificates or renewals required to be obtained under this section shall only be issued to persons who present satisfactory evidence that the owner has liability insurance coverage, to the value of at least $100,000.00 that covers animal bites. The owner may obtain and maintain a bond in surety, in lieu of liability insurance, to the value of at least $100,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(d); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Sec. 4-97. - Confinement. 
    While on the property of its owner or custodian, an animal found to be a dangerous dog shall be confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked structure of sufficient height and design, with adequate shelter, to prevent its escape or to prevent direct contact with or entry to minors, adults, or other animals. The structure shall be designed to provide the animals with shelter from the elements of nature. When off its owner's property, an animal found to be dangerous shall be kept on a leash and muzzled in such a manner as not to cause injury to the animal or interfere with the animal's vision or respiration, but as to prevent it from biting a person or another animal. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(e); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Sec. 4-98. - Unemancipated minors as owners or custodians. 
    If the owner or custodian of a dangerous dog is an unemancipated minor, the custodian parent or legal guardian shall be responsible for complying with all requirements of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(f); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
Sec. 4-99. - Notification requirements. 
(a)  The owner of any dog found to be dangerous shall register the animal with the Commonwealth of Virginia Dangerous Dog Registry, as established under Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542, within 45 days of such a finding by a court of competent jurisdiction. The owner shall also cause the local animal control officer to be promptly notified of: 
(1)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of all owners; 
(2)  All of the means necessary to locate the owner and the dog at any time; 
(3)  Any complaints or incidences of attack by the dog upon any person or cat or dog; 
(4)  Any claims made or lawsuits brought as a result of any attack; 
(5)  Tattoo or chip identification information or both; 
(6)  Proof of insurance or surety bond; and 
(7)  The death of the dog. 
(b)  After an animal has been found by a court to be a dangerous dog, the animal's owner or custodian, upon learning of same, immediately shall notify the animal control officer if the animal: 
(1)  Is loose or unconfined; 
(2)  Bites or attacks either a person or another animal; or 
(3)  Is sold, given away, or dies. 
(c)  Any owner of a dangerous dog who relocates to a new address shall, within ten days of relocating, provide written notice to the appropriate local animal control authority for the old address from which the animal has moved and the new address to which the animal has been moved. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(g), (h); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
Sec. 4-100. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any owner or custodian of a canine or canine crossbreed or other animal is guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor if the canine or canine crossbreed previously declared a dangerous dog pursuant to this section, when such declaration arose out of a separate and distinct incident, attacks and injures or kills a cat or dog that is a companion animal belonging to another person. 
(b)  Any owner or custodian of a canine or canine crossbreed or other animal is guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor if the canine or canine crossbreed previously declared a dangerous dog pursuant to this section, when such declaration arose out of a separate and distinct incident, bites a human being or attacks a human being causing bodily injury. 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to any animal that, at the time of the acts complained of, was responding to pain or injury, or was protecting itself, its kennel, its offspring, a person, or its owner's or custodian's property, or when the animal is a police dog that is engaged in the performance of its duties at the time of the attack. 
(d)  The owner or custodian of any animal which has been found by a court to be a dangerous dog who fails to comply with the requirements of this division shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(i); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
Sec. 4-101. - Appeal of determination. 
    The animal control officer may determine, after investigation, whether a dog is a dangerous dog. If the animal control officer determines that a dog is a dangerous dog, the animal control officer may order the animal's owner to comply with the provisions of this division. If the animal's owner disagrees with the animal control officer's determination, the owner may appeal the determination to the general district court for a trial on the merits. 
(Code 1973, § 4-20; Code 1982, § 4-20(j); Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 1595, 1-12-1998; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 1768, 9-27-2004) 
State Law reference- Control of dangerous or vicious dogs, penalties, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6440; dangerous dog registry, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6542. 
Secs. 4-102-4-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RABIES CONTROL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Rabies vaccination, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6521 A; rabies control, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.2-6521 B-3.2-6526 B. 

Sec. 4-125. - Vaccination required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, hold or harbor any dog over the age of four months, within the city, unless the dog has been vaccinated with a modified live virus (Flury strain) rabies vaccine, approved by the state department of health, within a period of 36 months or inoculated within a period of 12 months with a killed rabies vaccine approved by the state department of health. 
(Code 1973, § 4-21; Code 1982, § 4-21; Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Rabies vaccination required, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.2-6521 A, 3.2-6521 B, 3.2-6526 B. 
Sec. 4-126. - Dogs brought into city. 
    Any person transporting a dog into the city from some other jurisdiction or political entity shall be required to comply with section 4-125 within 30 days of the time of such transporting. 
(Code 1973, § 4-22; Code 1982, § 4-22) 
Sec. 4-127. - Collar tag and certificate of inoculation. 
    At the time of vaccination, a suitable, distinctive and legible collar tag and a certificate of inoculation stating the type of vaccine used shall be obtained by the dog owner or person having custody and care of the dog. The collar tag shall be affixed to the dog's collar and shall be worn at all times when the dog is not on the property of the owner or is not in the immediate control of a responsible person. 
(Code 1973, § 4-23; Code 1982, § 4-23) 
Sec. 4-128. - Impoundment of unvaccinated dogs. 
    Any dog found in the city which is not identified as having been vaccinated in the manner set forth in the provisions of this division shall be impounded by such officials of the city as may be designated for such duty by the city manager and such dog shall be held for a period of five days. Upon presentation of proof of ownership, vaccination of the dog, payment of the cost of impounding the dog as set forth in section 4-74; and upon payment of any fine assessed under the provisions of this Code, the dog shall be released to the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 4-24; Code 1982, § 4-24) 
Sec. 4-129. - Prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    No dog license shall be issued to any applicant unless there is presented to the official issuing licenses a certificate of rabies vaccination properly executed and signed by a licensed veterinarian certifying that the dog has been vaccinated in accordance with the provisions set forth in section 4-125. The certificate shall show the time of inoculation, rabies collar tag number, a brief description of the dog, sex and breed, and the name of the owner of such dog. 
(Code 1973, § 4-25; Code 1982, § 4-25; Ord. No. 905) 
State Law reference- Rabies certificate required, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6529. 
Sec. 4-130. - Rabies epizootic. 
    When, in the judgment of the health officer of the city, an emergency shall exist within the city, or immediately adjacent areas, due to widespread rabies epizootic, the health officer shall declare a quarantine in the city. Upon such declaration, each owner or custodian of a dog shall restrict the dog to the premises of the owner or custodian or the immediate custody of a responsible person for the duration of such emergency. The health officer shall cause to be publicized such declaration by all media available, and shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 4-26; Code 1982, § 4-26) 
State Law reference- Declaration of rabies emergency, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6525. 
Sec. 4-131. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this division shall be enforced by the police officers of the city, the state game warden, the animal control officer and the city health officer. 
(Code 1973, § 4-27; Code 1982, § 4-27; Ord. No. 905; Ord. No. 1660, 11-8-1999) 
Secs. 4-132-4-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CATS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Rabies vaccination, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6521 A; rabies control, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.2-6521 B-3.2-6526 B. 

Sec. 4-161. - Vaccination required. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a cat to keep, harbor or having in such owner's or custodian's custody or control a cat four months old or older for longer than 14 days, unless such cat has been vaccinated with a rabies vaccine approved by the state department of health and the vaccination is not beyond the expiration date for such vaccination. After the initial vaccination, each cat shall be periodically vaccinated so as to ensure the cat has, at all times, an effective vaccination approved by the state department of health. 
(Code 1982, § 4-36; Ord. No. 1034, 1-10-1983; Ord. No. 1279, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 4-162. - Certificate of vaccination. 
    Rabies inoculation receipts, issued by a veterinarian at the time of vaccination, shall be carefully preserved by the owner or custodian of a cat and exhibited promptly upon request for inspection by any animal control officer or other law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1982, § 4-37; Ord. No. 1034, 1-10-1983) 
Sec. 4-163. - Violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be guilty, upon conviction, of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 4-38; Ord. No. 1034, 1-10-1983)

Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; architectural advisory board, § 2-137 et seq.; condominiums, § 6-48 et seq.; pools, § 8-474 et seq.; noise, § 14-49 et seq.; outdoor lighting, § 14-127 et seq.; fire prevention, ch. 18; housing, ch. 22; solid waste, ch. 34; erosion and sediment control, ch. 35; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; subdivisions, ch. 38; public utilities, ch. 42; water conservation, § 42-65 et seq.; cross connection and backflow prevention control in waterworks, § 42-150 et seq.; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq.; zoning ch. 48.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - BUILDING STANDARDS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-19. - Building official appointed. 
    The city manager shall appoint a building official for the purpose of enforcing the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1982, § 6-1.1; Ord. No. 1164, 11-10-1986) 
State Law reference- Uniform statewide building code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. 
Sec. 6-20. - Building board of appeals. 
    The building official shall appoint a building code board of appeals following the regulations as set forth in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1982, § 6-1.11; Ord. No. 1164, 11-10-1986; Ord. No. 1176, 3-9-1987) 
Sec. 6-21. - Building permit fees. 
    No permit, as required by the building code, shall be issued until the fee, as prescribed by resolution and adopted by city council, has been paid. 
(Code 1973, § 6-6; Code 1982, § 6-3) 
Sec. 6-22. - State maintenance code enforcement. 
    The city manager or his designated assistant shall appoint a property maintenance code official for the purpose of enforcing the state maintenance code. Enforcement of the code shall be on a complaint-only basis. 
Sec. 6-23. - Enforcement, applicability and fines. 
    In addition to the authority granted by Part III of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, the building official, assisted by offices designated by the city manager, is hereby authorized to take corrective actions and issue a warning notice or a notice of violation for any violation of this chapter pursuant to the procedures in this section. 
(1)  Applicability. With respect to a property or use within the city, no owner or agent of the owner, person, tenant or corporation shall violate any provision of this chapter. 
(2)  Penalties. Violations not resulting in injury to persons and not corrected by the compliance date specified on a warning notice shall incur the civil penalties of $100.00 for a first offense, and $150.00 for a second and subsequent offense. The period set for compliance shall not be less than ten calendar days. Violations arising from the same operative set of facts shall not be charged more frequently than once in any ten-day period. 
(3)  Admission of responsibility, request for hearing, failure to respond. At any time before the expiration of the date set for compliance on a notice of violation, the person, persons, firm or corporation receiving a civil violation under this section shall either admit responsibility by paying the civil penalty indicated on the notice of violation at the city treasurer's office, or shall request a hearing by appearing at the clerk of the court's office. Failure to respond by the compliance date may result in additional fines and penalties as provided for by this section and in the same manner as provided by law for civil infractions. 
(4)  Violations for which a summons is issued. A summons may be issued by an authorized official in lieu of a civil violation notice for violations that have gone uncorrected after proper notice to correct has been given. Such summons shall be set for hearing according to the procedures of the district court. 
(5)  Unsafe structures and or violations resulting in injuries to persons. Unsafe structures and structures unfit for human occupancy as defined by the Virginia Maintenance Code, section 105, and violations resulting in injury to persons shall be deemed a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to section 1-12 of the City Code. 
(6)  Collection of fines. If a person charged with a civil infraction violation under this section fails to respond as provided for in subsection 6-23(3), the city treasurer's office shall collect the fines and penalties, if any, pursuant to the procedures of that office. 
(7)  Request for hearing. Cases for which a hearing has been requested under subsection 6-23(3) shall be heard in the general district court of the City of Falls Church in the same manner and with the same right of appeal as provided for by law. In any hearing for a violation of this section, it shall be the burden of the City of Falls Church to show the liability of the violator by a preponderance of the evidence. An admission of liability or finding of liability shall not be a criminal conviction for any purpose. If the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the judge or magistrate shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation in order to comply with the Code. In addition, each day the violation continues after conviction or the court-ordered abatement period has expired shall constitute a separate offense. Except as otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, the court shall order the abatement of the violation within not less than ten calendar days, or more than six months of the date of conviction. 
(8)  City of Falls Church Uniform Schedule of Civil Penalties for the Virginia Maintenance Code. The following sections of the Virginia Maintenance Code are adopted by reference and subject to the fines provided for in subsection 6-23(2): 
Violations of General Requirements VMC Chapter 3 Violations of Light Ventilation and Occupancy Limitations VMC Chapter 4 Violations of Plumbing Facilities and Fixture Requirements VMC Chapter 5 Violations of Mechanical and Electrical Requirements VMC Chapter 6 Violations of Fire Safety Requirements VMC Chapter 7  
(Ord. No. 1872, 3-12-2012) 
Secs. 6-24-6-47. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONDOMINIUMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Architectural advisory board, § 2-137 et seq.; swimming pool design and construction, § 8-474 et seq.; outdoor lighting, § 14-127 et seq.; fire prevention, ch. 18; housing, ch. 22; solid waste, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; subdivisions, ch. 38; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Condominium act, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.39 et seq.; limitations on ordinances regarding condominiums, Code of Virginia, §§ 55-79.43, 55-79.94(e)-(g). 

Sec. 6-48. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this division to regulate the conversion to condominiums and construction of new condominiums to the maximum extent permitted by state law. Should the meaning and application of any provision in this division be unclear, it shall be construed in a manner consistent with this purpose. Should any amendments to state law be made which affect the authority of the city, the city's authority shall be the maximum permitted by those amendments. 
(Code 1982, § 8-1; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
Sec. 6-49. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, words and terms shall have the same meaning given to them in the Virginia Condominium Act, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.39 et seq., as amended (the Act). 
(Code 1982, § 8-2; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-50. - Site plan requirements. 
    A site plan shall be required for newly constructed condominiums and for the conversion to condominiums of residential or commercial structures, as provided in chapter 48, article V, division 7, pertaining to site plans. In any case where the conversion does not conform to the zoning and land use regulations of the city, a variance shall be required. A request for a variance shall be granted if the applicant can demonstrate to the reasonable satisfaction of the board of zoning appeals that the nonconformities are not likely to be adversely affected by the proposed conversion. No action on such request shall be unreasonably delayed. As in the case with other variances, variances shall be reviewed by the planning commission for the purpose of advice to the board of zoning appeals. At the time of the review by the planning commission of the site plan, the developer shall be provided with a copy of this division by the department of housing and human services. 
(Code 1982, § 8-3; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
Sec. 6-51. - Application for registration; local requirements. 
    The declarant of a condominium is required to file with the city all information which is required by the state real estate board pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 55-79.89. Such information shall be filed in the department of housing and human services simultaneously with the filing of the application of registration with the state real estate board, and shall be made available for inspection by the public. In the case of conversion condominiums, the director of housing and human services shall cause a notice of the receipt of such information pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 55-79.89, to be prominently posted in the conversion condominium. 
(Code 1982, § 8-4; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
State Law reference- Application for registration, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.89; authority to require filing with the city, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.94 E. 
Sec. 6-52. - Elderly and disabled tenants. 
(a)  The developer of a condominium project which is being converted from multifamily rental use shall offer to those elderly or disabled tenants occupying apartments or units as their residence, at the time of issuance of the general notice required by Code of Virginia, § 55-79.94 B, leases or extension of leases on apartments or units they then occupy, or on other apartments or units of at least equal size and overall quality; provided, however, that no such lease or extension shall be valid unless all of the terms and conditions thereof are agreed upon by the lessor and the lessee; provided, further, that the rent for such apartment or unit shall not be in excess of reasonable rent for comparable apartments or units in the same market area as such conversion condominium. Such lease shall include or incorporate by reference the bylaws and/or rules and regulations, if any, of the association. No such developer shall be required to offer such leases or extensions on more than 20 percent of the apartments or units in such conversion condominium, nor shall any such lease or extension be required to be extended for more than three years from the date of the general notice referred to in this section. 
(b)  The requirements set forth in this section shall not apply in the case of any apartments or units which will, in the course of the conversion, be substantially altered in the physical layout, restricted exclusively to nonresidential use, or be converted in such a manner as to require relocation of the tenant in premises outside of the project being converted. 
(Code 1982, § 8-5; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.94 F. 
Sec. 6-53. - Relocation. 
    The developer of a condominium project which is being converted from multifamily rental use shall reimburse any tenant displaced by the conversion for amounts actually expended to relocate as a result of such dislocation; provided, however, that such reimbursement shall not be required to exceed the amount which the tenant would have been entitled to receive under Code of Virginia, §§ 25.1-407 and 25.1-415 if the real estate comprising the condominium had been condemned by the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1982, § 8-6; Ord. No. 1093, 1-14-1985) 
State Law reference- Authority for certain cities to adopt this requirement, Code of Virginia, § 55-79.94 G. 
Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8-1-8-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MASSAGE THERAPY ESTABLISHMENTS AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 20; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Massage therapy, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-3000; municipal license authority, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-20. - Declaration of findings and policy. 
    It is hereby declared that the city has found it necessary and proper to exercise its regulatory authority under the police power for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of its citizens by providing for the permitting and regulation of massage therapists and massage establishments. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-2; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief means the City of Falls Church chief of police, or the chief's designee. 
    Client means any person receiving a massage from a massage therapist who has been compensated for administering the massage. 
    Disqualifying offenses means offenses which disqualify an applicant from obtaining a permit pursuant to this article or, if the offender already holds a permit, which mandate revocation of the permit. Disqualifying offenses are: 
(1)  Convictions, pleas of nolo contendere or a forfeiture on a charge of violating any provision of the Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-346, 18.2-347 through 18.2-349, 18.2-355 through 18.2-358, 18.2-361, 18.2-368, 18.2-370, 18.2-370.1, 18.2-371, 18.2-386.1 or 18.2-387, which laws relate to sexual offenses, or any provision of an ordinance of the city or a law or ordinance of another jurisdiction which prohibits the same conduct, within the past ten years. 
(2)  Convictions, pleas of nolo contendere or a forfeiture on a charge of violating any provision of this article, or on a charge of violating a similar law in any other jurisdiction, within the past five years. 
(3)  Making a false statement on a permit application. 
    Erogenous areas means the genitals and the nipples and areolae. 
    Massage means the treatment, for compensation, of soft tissues for therapeutic purposes by the application of massage and bodywork techniques based on the manipulation or application of pressure to the muscular structure or soft tissues of the human body, unless the massage is excluded from regulation by section 8-22. 
    Massage establishment means any fixed place of business where a massage is administered to a client, unless the place is excluded from regulation by section 8-22. 
    Massage therapist means any individual certified as a massage therapist by the Board of Nursing of the commonwealth. 
    Out-call massage means any massage administered for compensation at a location other than at a massage establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-3; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-22. - Exclusions. 
    The provisions of this article do not apply to the following massages, and such massages are expressly excluded from the requirements of this article: 
(1)  A massage administered only to the scalp, face, neck, shoulders, arms, hands, and/or the feet. 
(2)  A massage of the upper body while the client is fully clothed and seated in a chair. 
(3)  A massage administered in a hospital or medical clinic, or in the office of a physician, chiropractor, osteopath or physical therapist licensed by the commonwealth. 
(4)  A massage administered in a nursing home, convalescent care facility, assisted-living facility, progressive care facility or life care facility. 
(5)  A massage administered by a physician, chiropractor, osteopath, physical therapist or nurse, licensed by the commonwealth, in any location. 
(6)  A massage administered at an organized public event, such as a health fair or sporting event, which is open for participation or viewing by the general public. 
(7)  A massage administered at a school which offers a massage therapy program that has received programmatic approval from the state board of education, office of proprietary schools, or that has been certified or approved by the state board of education, office of proprietary schools or the state council of higher education; provided, however, that this exclusion applies only if the individual administering the massage is a student enrolled at the school and receives no compensation for doing so. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-4; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Secs. 8-23-8-47. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 8-48. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-25; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-49. - Right of entry to enforce provisions. 
    The chief, the director of health, the zoning administrator and the building official, or their duly authorized agents, are hereby authorized to enter, examine and survey, during business hours, any premises in the city for which a massage establishment permit has been issued, pursuant to this article, for the purpose of inspection and to enforce the provisions of this article. The director of health will make best efforts to inspect each massage establishment at least one time per year to determine whether it is being operated in compliance with this article. This section shall not restrict or limit the right of entry vested in any law enforcement agency. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-26; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-50. - Revocation or suspension of permits. 
(a)  Grounds for revocation. Grounds for revocation of any permit granted under this article exist if the permittee, operator or manager has committed any disqualifying offense or repeatedly has had a permit issued under this article suspended. If the permittee is a: 
(1)  Privately held corporation. Privately held corporation or company, grounds for revocation exist in the event of such conduct by the corporation or company or by any officer or director. 
(2)  Publicly held corporation. Publicly held corporation, grounds for revocation exist in the event of such conduct by the corporation or by any officer or agent who has responsibility for the daily operations of the establishment. 
(3)  Partnership. Partnership, grounds for revocation exist in the event of such conduct by the partnership or any partner. 
If the chief believes that grounds for revocation of a permit exist, the chief shall give the permittee written notice enumerating the grounds and declaring the chief's intent to hold a hearing at a specified date and time to determine whether revocation is warranted. The notice shall be mailed, by certified mail, to the permittee's last known address, at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing. At the hearing, the permittee may be represented by counsel, may cross examine witnesses and may present evidence in the permittee's favor. If the chief finds that any ground for revocation in fact exists, the chief shall revoke the permit. The chief shall issue a written notice of the chief's findings and decision within ten workdays of the hearing. Any appeal shall be filed by the permittee with the city police department within 30 days after a permittee receives the notice and shall specify the grounds for appeal. The chief's action remains in effect during the pendency of the appeal. The city manager shall hold an appeal hearing as promptly as practicable and in no event more than 60 days after the appeal is filed. 
(b)  Grounds for suspension. Grounds for suspension of any permit granted under this article exist if the permittee has failed to comply with any provisions of this article, other than those which mandate revocation. If the permittee is a: 
(1)  Privately held corporation. Privately held corporation or company, grounds for suspension exist in the event of such failure to comply by the corporation or company or by any officer or director. 
(2)  Publicly held corporation. Publicly held corporation, grounds for suspension exist in the event of such failure to comply by the corporation or by any officer or agent who has responsibility for the daily operations of the establishment. 
(3)  Partnership. Partnership, grounds for suspension exist in the event of such failure to comply by the partnership or any partner. 
The chief or any person with a right of entry under section 8-49 may order the suspension of the permit with or without notice. The order shall set forth the reasons for the suspension. A copy of the suspension order shall be hand delivered or mailed, by certified mail, to the permittee's last known address. The chief may end a suspension at any time if the reason for the suspension is corrected. Any appeal shall be filed by the permittee with the city police department within 30 days after a permittee receives the suspension order and shall specify the grounds for appeal. The city manager shall hold an appeal hearing as promptly as practicable and in no event more than 60 days after the appeal is filed. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-27; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Secs. 8-51-8-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MASSAGE THERAPIST PERMIT 

Sec. 8-74. - Permit required. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to offer or administer a massage in the city, unless such person has a valid massage therapist permit issued by the chief of police. 
(b)  It is unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any massage establishment to allow any person who does not have the permit required by this section to administer any massage in the establishment. 
(c)  The chief shall not issue a massage therapist permit to any person who is not certified by the board of nursing of the commonwealth, as a massage therapist. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-5; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
State Law reference- Certification of massage therapists, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-3005. 
Sec. 8-75. - Permit application, duty to update. 
    Each application for a massage therapist permit shall be upon a form prepared by the chief. The applicant shall provide full answers to all questions on the application under oath. The completed application shall contain the following information, as well as other information which the chief deems necessary to properly evaluate the application: 
(1)  The applicant's full name, names by which the applicant previously was known, date and place of birth, current residential and business addresses and telephone numbers, and e-mail address. 
(2)  A copy of the applicant's massage therapist certification from the board of nursing of the commonwealth. 
(3)  The applicant's personal characteristics, such as, height, weight, eye color, hair color, sex and race. 
(4)  The names and addresses of all massage establishments where the applicant has been employed as a massage therapist within the past three years. 
(5)  Whether the applicant currently holds or previously held a permit or license to offer or administer massages anywhere in the state or in any other state. If the applicant holds or has held any such permit or license, the applicant shall provide the license or permit number and the identity of the issuing authority, and whether such permit or license has ever been revoked or suspended and the reason. 
(6)  The applicant's criminal record, if any, other than misdemeanor traffic violations or traffic infractions, a complete set of the applicant's fingerprints which shall be taken as directed by the chief, a consent form allowing the chief to obtain a search of the central criminal records exchange, and an investigation fee in the amount as established by the state police for conducting the records search. 
(7)  One full-face and one profile photograph, in a size designated by the chief. 
(8)  The application fee of $50.00. The fee is in addition to any business or occupation or occupation license tax imposed by the city and any other taxes or fees which may be required to engage in the business. During the term of the permit, each person to whom a massage therapist permit is issued under this section must report to the chief any change in the information required by subsection (1), (2), (5) or (6) of this section within 21 days of learning of the change. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-6; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-76. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  The chief shall act upon the application for a massage therapist permit within 21 days from the date the chief receives the application. 
(b)  If the chief determines from the information contained in the permit application and from the chief's investigation that the applicant has committed no disqualifying offenses and that the applicant is otherwise qualified, under this division, to administer massage therapy in the city, the chief shall issue the permit. Each permit issued by the chief shall be the property of the city and it shall be returned to the chief in the event the permit is suspended or revoked in accordance with section 8-50 or section 8-78. 
(c)  If the chief determines from the information contained in the permit application and from the chief's investigation that the applicant has committed one or more disqualifying offenses or is otherwise unqualified under this division to administer massage therapy in the city, the chief shall deny the application. 
(d)  If the chief denies an application, the chief shall provide the applicant with written notice setting forth the grounds for the denial. Any appeal shall be filed by the applicant with the city police department within 30 days after the applicant receives the notice and shall specify the grounds for appeal. The city manager shall hold an appeal hearing as promptly as practicable and in no event more than 60 days after the appeal is filed. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-7; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-77. - Term. 
    A massage therapist permit shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked. Within 30 days before the expiration date, a permitted massage therapist may apply for a new permit. 
(Code 1982, § 19.1-8; Ord. No. 1726, 12-9-2002) 
Sec. 8-78. - Validity of permit dependent upon validity of state certification.
