(2)  To adopt, in addition to the provisions contained herein and in the franchise and in any existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its police power. 
(f)  Employment requirement. A grantee shall not refuse to hire, nor discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person regarding compensation, terms, conditions or privileges of employment because of age, sex, race, color, creed, or national origin. A grantee shall take affirmative action to ensure that employees are treated, during employment, without regard to their age, sex, race, color, creed or national origin. This condition includes, but is not limited to, the following: recruitment, advertising, employment interviews, employment, rates of pay, upgrading, transfer, demotion, layoff and termination. 
(g)  Time essence of agreement. Whenever this article or the franchise sets forth any time for any act to be performed by or on the behalf of a grantee, such time shall be deemed of the essence and the grantee's failure to perform within the time allotted shall, in all cases, be sufficient grounds for the city to invoke the remedies available under the terms and conditions of this article and the franchise. 
(h)  Acceptance. 
(1)  A franchise and its terms and conditions shall be accepted by a grantee by written instrument filed with the city manager within 30 days after the granting of the franchise. In its acceptance, the grantee shall declare that it has carefully read the terms and conditions of this article and the franchise and accepts all of the terms and conditions imposed by this article and the franchise and agrees to abide by same. 
(2)  Acceptance of a franchise by a grantee shall operate as a waiver by the grantee of any claim to operate a cable television system within the city as against the regulatory power of the city because of the previous operation of the same, whether by franchise or otherwise. 
(i)  Liquidated damages. Notwithstanding any other remedy provided for in this article, or otherwise available under law, the city shall have the power to recover monetary amounts from a grantee under certain conditions, such monetary amounts being in the nature of liquidated damages. By accepting a franchise, a grantee automatically agrees that these conditions will cause damages to the city and that the monetary amounts are established because it is difficult to ascertain the exact amount of the damages: The damages resulting to the city include, but are not limited to, loss of franchise fees that would have otherwise been paid to or would have become due the city, and administrative costs incurred by the city. The conditions for and amounts of such damages are listed as follows: 
(1)  For failure to submit plans indicating expected dates of installation of various parts of the system: $100.00 per day. 
(2)  For failure to commence operations in accordance with this article and/or franchise: $200.00 per day. 
(3)  For failure to complete construction and installation of the system within the required time limits: $300.00 per day. 
(4)  For failure to supply data requested by the city in accordance with the requirements of the franchise and this article such data pertaining to installation, construction, customers, franchise or financial reports, or rate review: $50.00 per day. 
(5)  For failure to otherwise provide service to a subscriber in accordance with the requirements of this article: $10.00 per day per subscriber affected, but not to exceed $50.00 per subscriber per month, and further not to exceed $1,000.00 per day in the aggregate. This amount shall be reduced by any refunds of subscriber fees made to subscribers affected by the failure, etc., to provide service. 
(j)  Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to attach or affix, or to cause to be attached or affixed, any equipment or devices which allows access or use of the cable television service without payment to the grantee for same. 
(k)  Penalties. 
(1)  The following acts shall be deemed class 1 misdemeanors under this article and each day of a continuing offense is a separate offense: 
a.  Willful failure, refusal or neglect by a grantee to construct, operate, or maintain its cable television system in accordance with the terms of this article or the franchise granted pursuant to this article. 
b.  Transmission or reception by a grantee of a signal from a subscriber's premises in violation of section 10-64(h). 
c.  The attaching or affixing, or causing to be attached or affixed, any equipment or device as described in subsection (j) of this section. The attaching of or affixing of each unit of such equipment or device shall constitute a separate offense. 
(2)  The violation of any other provision of this article shall be subject to such other penalties as shall be prescribed by law or ordinance. Each day of a continuing offense is a separate offense. 
(l)  Severability. If any section of this article or the franchise, or any portion thereof, is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction or administrative agency, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, except as otherwise provided for herein. 
(m)  Financial disclosure by applicants. 
(1)  Every request for a proposal shall require, and every cable franchise application shall contain, a complete and detailed listing, under oath, of the following information: 
a.  The names and positions with the city of all city officers and employees known to the applicant to have any interest in the entity making application, and the extent of such interest. 
b.  The names and last known addresses of all persons who have acted as attorney, broker, consultant, or agent of the applying entity with respect to the application. 
c.  The names and last known addresses of all persons who own or control any interest in the applying entity; in the case of a partnership or joint venture or syndicate, the names and last known addresses of all partners or participants; in the case of a corporation having fewer than 200 stockholders, the names and last known addresses of all stockholders. 
d.  The names and last known addresses of all holders of debt of the applying entity, other than stockholders or suppliers of goods and services paid on current account, in excess of $5,000.00 or one percent of the total outstanding indebtedness of the entity, whichever is lesser. 
e.  The name and position of each city officer or employee to whom, or to whose immediate family, the applying entity or any person described in subsection (m)(1)c of this section has made any gift or donation of $100.00 or more within three years preceding the filing of the application, the name of the donor and the amount or value of the gift or donation. As to elected city officials, this requirement includes disclosure of donations to their principal campaign committees and authorized committees as defined by 2 USC 431, and campaign committees formed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 24.1-251 et seq. 
(2)  The city council, in its discretion, shall eliminate from consideration any applicant for the award of a cable television franchise within the city who is not in compliance with the provisions of the disclosure requirements of this article. 
(n)  Financial disclosure by officers and employees. Within 30 days after receipt of notification that application for a franchise has been received by the city and again within 30 days after notification of the adoption of an ordinance granting a cable television franchise, each city officer and employee shall file with the clerk to the city council a complete and detailed statement, under oath, to the best of their information, knowledge and belief, after a duly diligent search, containing the following information: 
(1)  The name of each entity which has applied for a franchise in which the city officer or employee, a member of his immediate family or any of his business associates, has any interest; the amount, nature, and extent of the interest; and the name of the person possessing such interest. 
(2)  The name of any partner, participant, stockholder, officer, or employee, or any member of the immediate family of any of them, of any applying entity, who has made any gift or donation of $100.00 or more to the officer or employee or to a member of such person's immediate family within three years prior to the filing of the entity's franchise application, and the name of the recipient and amount or value of the gift or donation. 
(o)  Interconnection of cable television system. 
(1)  Interconnection generally. 
a.  The company shall interconnect origination, access and institutional channels of the cable system with any or all other systems upon the directive of the city. Interconnection of systems may be done by direct cable connection, microwave link, satellite or other appropriate method. 
b.  Any connection whatsoever of the company's cable communications system with any other kind of system, including but not limited to a cable communications system, shall not relieve the company of any of its obligations under this article. 
(2)  Interconnection procedures. Upon receiving the directive of the city to interconnect, the company shall immediately initiate negotiations with the other affected system or systems in order that costs may be shared equally for both construction and operation of the interconnection link. 
(3)  Relief. The company may be granted reasonable extensions of time to interconnect or the city may rescind its order to interconnect upon petition by the company to the city. The city shall grant such request if it finds that the company has negotiated in good faith and has failed to obtain an approval from the system of the proposed interconnection; or that the cost of the interconnection would cause an unreasonable or unacceptable increase in subscriber rates. 
(4)  Cooperation required. The company shall cooperate with any interconnection corporation, regulatory interconnection authority or city, county, state and federal regulatory agency which may be hereafter established for the purpose of regulating, financing or otherwise providing for the interconnection of cable systems beyond the boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 7-27; Ord. No. 984, 10-13-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Secs. 10-66-10-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AWARD OF FRANCHISE 

Sec. 10-89. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1939, § 4, adopted July 27, 2015, repealed § 10-89, entitled "Media General Cable of Fairfax County, Inc" which derived from: Code 1982, § 7-28; and Ord. No. 1053, adopted June 13, 1983. See cable franchise agreement on file with the city. 
Sec. 10-90. - Verizon Virginia, Inc. franchise. 
    At a meeting of the city counsel held in council chambers of City Hall on Monday, January 23, 2006, the council, after having first given notice of its intention to do so, in a manner prescribed by law, adopted the ordinance from which this article is derived awarding a cable franchise to Verizon Virginia, Inc., for the city in accordance with chapter 10 of this Code, said ordinance reading in its entirety as follows: 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FALLS CHURCH, VIRGINIA THAT: 
1.  The city council has received an application from Verizon Virginia, Inc., dated January 3, 2006, seeking a cable franchise in the City of Falls Church and after a review of the application and the holding of a public hearing, finds that the public welfare will be enhanced and the public interest will served by granting the requested cable franchise. 
2.  The city council has determined that the application of Verizon Virginia Inc., and the public hearing demonstrate that Verizon Virginia, Inc., has the resources and technical ability to construct and operate a cable system in the City of Falls Church in accordance with the terms of the "Cable Franchise Agreement By and Between the City of Falls Church, Virginia, and Verizon Virginia, Inc.," and chapter 10 of the Falls Church City Code. The city council has further determined that the cable franchise with Verizon Virginia, Inc., will have minimal effects on property rights and public convenience. 
3.  The city council has determined that grant of the franchise agreement will include the following terms and conditions that, amongst others, will be of benefit to the City of Falls Church and its residents: 
a.  A franchise acceptance fee of $100,000.00; 
b.  An advance against the PEG Grants of $66,474.00 for the purpose of extending the city's institutional network from city hall through the library to the property yard, and from city hall through court services to the Aurora House, and for the wiring of service outlets for each classroom in Thomas Jefferson and Mount Daniel Elementary Schools; 
c.  Provision of up to 19 PEG channels, including two channels dedicated for use by the City of Falls Church; 
d.  Provision of cable outlets and digital cable service to government facilities; 
e.  A franchise fee of five percent of annual Gross Revenue from the provision of cable services by Verizon Virginia, Inc., in the City of Falls Church; 
f.  PEG Grants of three percent of annual gross revenue (less the franchise fee) from the provision of cable services by Verizon Virginia, Inc., in the City of Falls Church; and, 
g.  Customer service standards. 
4.  Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2108, the city council hereby accepts, approves, grants, and awards to Verizon Virginia Inc., a nonexclusive cable franchise to provide cable service to the city. The duration for this grant shall be 15 years. The cable franchise agreement is incorporated into this ordinance. 
5.  The provisions of this franchise shall be liberally construed to effectuate their objectives. In the event of a conflict between the cable law and this agreement, this agreement shall prevail. 
6.  The grant of the cable franchise to Verizon Virginia, Inc., is subject to the city's receipt of: (i) the acceptance of the franchise, as set forth in exhibit G to the cable franchise agreement, signed by an authorized representative of Verizon Virginia Inc.; (ii) the acceptance fee of $100,000.00; (iii) the advance against the PEG Grants of $66,474.00; (iv) certificates of insurance for each insurance policy required by section 10 of the cable franchise agreement; (v) the performance bond required by section 13 of the cable franchise agreement; and (vi) the letter of credit required by section 13 of the cable franchise agreement. 
7.  If Verizon Virginia, Inc., satisfies each and every condition of paragraph 7 above on or before February 22, 2006, then the cable franchise shall take effect on February 22, 2006. 
8.  If Verizon Virginia, Inc., does not satisfy each and every condition set forth in paragraph 7 above on or before February 22, 2006, then it is not authorized to provide cable service under the cable franchise agreement unless and until all such conditions are fulfilled. 
    BE IT FURTHER ORDAINED, that the cable franchise must be accepted by Verizon Virginia, Inc., by the delivery of the written acceptance of such cable franchise. 
    BE IT FURTHER ORDAINED, that the city manager shall have the right to make minor changes or amendments to the cable franchise agreement prior to it being signed by the City of Falls Church, if the city manager first obtains Verizon, Virginia Inc.'s prior written consent to such minor changes or amendments. 
    The ordinance shall become effective as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1783, 1-23-2006) 
Chapter 12 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate installation and maintenance of alarms, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-911. 

Sec. 12-21. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article and the public policy of the city to regulate the use and operation of security alarm systems in commercial and residential premises whose activation results in an alarm or signal to which the city police are expected to respond. It is also the purpose of this article to regulate the use of security alarm systems and thereby reduce the number of false alarms and protect the health, safety, welfare and property of the residents of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 22-54; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-22. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Audible alarm means a device located at, or on, the protected premises, which generates an audible signal when activated at the protected premises, thus indicating a breach of security. 
    Automatic dialing device means a device at the protected premises location which is interconnected to that location's telephone line and is programmed to select a telephone number which terminates at the police department and transmits a prerecorded voice message or code which signals the existence of criminal activity or other emergency at the protected premises. 
    Bank means a financial institution which is required by federal law or regulation to maintain an alarm system or other device for notification to the police department of criminal or emergency activity. 
    Central station means a commercial company whose business is monitoring and receiving alarm signals from protected premises and performing contracted services for alarm users, including transmission of these alarm signals to the alarm board of the police department. 
    Chief of police means the chief law enforcement official of the city or such official's designee. 
    False alarm means any signal request or similar event, the purpose of which is to alert and/or summon police department assistance, but which is not in response to actual or threatened emergency or criminal activity. The term "false alarm" includes any communication, either directly or indirectly, to the police department either by a central station, intermediary or signal device which is in response to a signal or warning issued intentionally or accidentally; negligently or accidentally activated signals; signals which are the result of faulty, malfunctioning or improperly installed or maintained equipment; and signals which are purposely, but improperly, activated to alert and/or summon the police department. The term "false alarm" shall not include signals activated by unusually severe weather conditions or other natural causes. 
    Protected premises means the premises upon which a security alarm system is located. 
    Security alarm system means any assembly of equipment or devices designed to detect and signal a breach of security at the protected premises or to signal an attempted burglary, robbery or other criminal activity or emergency at the protected premises. The term "security alarm system" may include a system connected to a central station or any other system which directly signals the police department. 
    User means any person, at a private residence or commercial establishment, using a security alarm system and/or performing contractual service with respect to monitoring such a system, regardless of ownership of the premises on which the security alarm system is located. 
(Code 1982, § 22-55; Ord. No. 929) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-23. - Intentional false alarms prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly, intentionally and without just cause activate a security alarm to notify the police department in situations where there is no actual or threatened emergency or criminal activity for which the security alarm is designed. 
(Code 1982, § 22-56; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-24. - Automatic dialing device. 
    It shall be unlawful for any user to install or operate an automatic dialing device which is programmed to transmit a prerecorded message or a code signal directly to the police department or to any central station or other telephone number where the intent is to transmit an alarm or signal to the police department. 
(Code 1982, § 22-57; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-25. - Audible alarms; posting of notice. 
    Every person maintaining or using an audible alarm shall provide the chief of police a current notice containing the names and telephone numbers of the persons to be notified for rendering repairs, service and securing the protected premises during any hour of the day or night when the audible alarm may be activated. Failure for any person maintaining an audible alarm to respond, within a reasonable time, not to exceed two hours, to his place of business after being summoned by the police department shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 22-58; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-26. - Responsibilities of user. 
    The user or the user's designee shall be responsible for: 
(1)  Installation and hookup of the alarm. 
(2)  The maintenance and testing of the security alarm system. 
(3)  A continuous training program for employees and other persons who may have occasion to activate the security alarm system. The training shall emphasize the proper setting, activation and resetting of alarms. 
(4)  A service charge of $30.00 shall be assessed for each false alarm which results in a response by the police department. 
(5)  The chief of police will be responsible for billing the user for the service charge. Such service charge will be paid to the treasurer of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 22-61; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-27. - False alarms. 
    A service charge of $30.00 shall be assessed for each false alarm to any protected premises. Such service charge shall be billed to the owner or person responsible for the protected premises. After review of the reason or cause of any first false alarm, the chief of police may waive the service charge. 
(Code 1982, § 22-66; Ord. No. 929) 
Sec. 12-28. - Exceptions. 
    The penalty provisions of this article shall not apply to residential premises until such time as those premises shall incur three instances of false alarms within a three-month period, but in any event shall comply with the provisions of section 12-26. 
(Code 1982, § 22-67; Ord. No. 929) 
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIR POLLUTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate the emission of smoke, etc., § 2.04(l). 
State Law reference- Air pollution, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1300 et seq. 

Sec. 14-20. - Purposes. 
    Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1321, as amended, there is hereby established in the city an air pollution control program for the purpose of preserving, protecting and improving the air resources of the city. To the maximum extent possible, such air pollution control program shall be conducted in cooperation with similar programs of other local jurisdictions and of the state and federal governments. In the administration and enforcement of this article due regard shall be taken for all of the facts and circumstances bearing upon the reasonableness of the activity involved and the regulations proposed to control it, including: 
(1)  The character and degree of injury to, or interference with safety, health or the reasonable use of property which is caused or threatened to be caused. 
(2)  The social and economic value of the activity involved. 
(3)  The suitability or unsuitability of such activity to the area in which it is located. 
(4)  The practicability, both scientific and economic, of reducing or eliminating the discharge resulting from such activity. 
(Code 1973, § 3-2; Code 1982, § 3-2; Ord. No. 613) 
Sec. 14-21. - Department. 
    Wherever the word "department" appears in this article it shall be deemed to refer to the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 3-3; Ord. No. 613, § 3-3) 
Sec. 14-22. - Air pollution control officer position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of air pollution control officer. 
(Code 1973, § 3-3; Code 1982, § 3-4; Ord. No. 613) 
Sec. 14-23. - Board. 
    Wherever the word "board" appears in this article, it shall be deemed to refer to the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 3-5; Ord. No. 613, § 3-3.2) 
Sec. 14-24. - Powers of department. 
    In addition to any other powers vested in it by law, the department shall: 
(1)  Conduct studies, investigations and research relating to air pollution and its prevention, abatement and control. 
(2)  Issue such orders as may be necessary to effectuate the purposes of this article and enforce the same by all appropriate administrative and judicial proceedings. 
(3)  Hold hearings relating to any aspect of or matter in the administration of this article. 
(4)  Secure necessary scientific, technical, administrative and operational services, including laboratory facilities, by contract or otherwise. 
(5)  Prepare and develop a comprehensive plan or plans for the prevention, abatement and control of air pollution. 
(6)  Advise, consult and cooperate with other local governmental units, agencies of the state, industries, interstate or interlocal agencies, and the federal government, and with interested persons or groups. 
(7)  Review those matters having a bearing upon air pollution referred by other agencies, such as planning, zoning, building and fire departments, and make reports, including recommendations, to the referring agencies with respect thereto. 
(8)  Collect and disseminate information and conduct educational and training programs relating to air pollution. 
(9)  Encourage voluntary cooperation by persons or affected groups to achieve the purposes of this article. 
(10)  Administer grants or other funds or gifts from public and private agencies, including the state and federal governments, for the purpose of carrying out any of the functions of this article. 
(11)  Do any and all acts which may be necessary for the successful prosecution of the policy of this article and such other acts as may be specifically enumerated herein. 
(Code 1973, § 3-4; Code 1982, § 3-6; Ord. No. 613) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 14-25. - Reporting of information. 
    Owners engaged in operations which may result in air pollution shall, if so required, file with the department reports containing information as to: 
(1)  Location and description of source; 
(2)  Rate, duration and composition of contaminant emission; and 
(3)  Such other information related to air pollution as the department may require. 
(Code 1973, § 3-5; Code 1982, § 3-7; Ord. No. 613) 
Sec. 14-26. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Whenever the department has reason to believe that a violation of any provision of this article or a rule or regulation issued pursuant thereto has occurred, it may cause written notice to be served upon the alleged violator or violators. The notice shall specify the provision of the ordinance, rule or regulation alleged to be violated and the facts alleged to constitute a violation thereof, and may order that the necessary corrective action be taken within a reasonable time. Any such order shall become final unless, no later than five days after the date such order is served, the owner named therein requests in writing a hearing before the department. In lieu of such order the department may require that the alleged violator appear before the department for a hearing at a time and place specified in the notice, to answer the charge complained of, or the department may initiate appropriate action for the recovery of a penalty pursuant to section 14-30. 
(b)  Whenever it is necessary for the purposes of this article, the board or any member, agent or employee when duly authorized by the board may at reasonable times enter any establishment or upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of obtaining information or conducting surveys or investigations. 
(c)  After such hearing the department shall affirm, modify or rescind its order or issue an appropriate order or orders for the prevention, abatement, or control of the air pollution involved. Such order shall prescribe the date by which the violation shall cease and may prescribe timetables for necessary action in preventing, abating, or controlling the air pollution. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall prevent the department from making efforts to obtain voluntary compliance through warning, conference or any other appropriate means. 
(Code 1982, § 3-10; Ord. No. 613) 
State Law reference- State law as to search warrants generally, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-52 et seq.; circumstances when search without warrant is lawful, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-59. 
Sec. 14-27. - Hearings and judicial review. 
(a)  Any owner aggrieved by any final order of the department may have review thereof by petition to the circuit court of Arlington County. 
(b)  At all times during the investigation, permit administration or enforcement proceedings, the department or the owner may request the intervention of the state air pollution control board which itself by regulation has retained power to take corrective action, and to afford a hearing for aggrieved owners. 
(Code 1982, § 3-11; Ord. No. 613) 
Sec. 14-28. - Confidentiality of records. 
    Any records or other information which relate to processes or production unique to the owner or operator, or which would tend to affect adversely the competitive position of such owner or operator shall be only for the confidential use of the department and other departments, agencies and officers of the city unless such owner or operator shall expressly agree to their publication or availability to the general public. Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the use of such records or information by any department, agency or officer of the city in compiling or publishing analyses or summaries relating to the general condition of the outdoor atmosphere; provided, that such analyses or summaries do not reveal any information otherwise confidential under this section. 
(Code 1982, § 3-12; Ord. No. 613) 
Sec. 14-29. - Adoption by reference of state regulations and standards. 
    The regulations and standards in Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution, AQCR VII, Virginia Air Quality Control Region VII, is hereby adopted by reference and is incorporated into this Code as if set out at length herein. Three copies of such regulations, together with a copy of the air pollution control ordinance attached to each such copy, shall be filed and maintained in the office of the city clerk. Whenever the words "state air pollution control board or executive secretary" are used in section IV of such state regulations, those words shall mean "Department, the office of the city manager." 
(Code 1982, § 3-13; Ord. No. 613, § 3-11) 
Sec. 14-30. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any owner who violates any provision of this article, or any rule or regulation in force pursuant thereto shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00, nor more than $1,000.00 for each violation. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Action pursuant to section 14-29 shall not be a bar to enforcement of this article, rules and regulations in force pursuant thereto, and orders made pursuant to this article, by injunction or other appropriate remedy, and the department shall have the power to institute and maintain in the name of the city any and all such enforcement proceedings. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to abridge, limit or otherwise impair the right of any person to damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property and to maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding. 
(Code 1982, § 3-14; Ord. No. 613) 
Secs. 14-31-14-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 4; buildings, ch. 6; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 26; miscellaneous offenses, ch. 28; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference- Noise from shooting ranges, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-917; regulation of motorcycle, moped, etc., noise, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-919; aircraft noise, Code of Virginia, §§ 5.1-157, 15.2-2295; exhaust systems, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1049. 

Sec. 14-49. - Policy of city. 
    Whereas, at certain levels, sounds are detrimental to the health and welfare of the citizenry, it is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to prohibit excessive and annoying sound from all sources subject to its police power. 
(Code 1982, § 21-1; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Sec. 14-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Construction means any or all activity necessary or incidental to the erection, demolition, assembling, altering, installing or equipping of buildings, public or private highways, roads, railroads, premises, parks, utility lines including such lines in already constructed tunnels, or other property, including land clearing, grading, excavating and filling. 
    Continuous sound denotes a sound the intensity of which remains essentially constant during a given period of time. Continuous sound shall be measured by the slow response setting of a sound level meter. 
    Daytime denotes the local time of day between the hours of 7.00 a.m. and 9.00 p.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 9.00 a.m. and 9.00 p.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and local legal holidays. 
    dBA (decibel A-weighted) means sound pressure level as measured on the "A" scale of a sound level meter manufactured in accordance with the specifications of the American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI), Type 2, ANSI-S1.4(1971), calibrated within two hours of being used for measurement. Unless otherwise noted, measurements shall be made in the slow response mode of the meter. 
    Decibel (dB) is a unit of sound pressure, equal to 20 times the logarithm to the base ten of the ratio of the pressure of the sound measured to the reference pressure, which is 20 micropascals (20 micronewtons per square meter). 
    Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. 
    Emergency signal device means any audible warning device, such as a gong, whistle or siren or any air horn or any similar device. 
    Emergency work means work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from immediate exposure to danger, including work performed by public service companies when emergency inspection, repair of facilities, or restoration of services is required for the immediate health, safety, or welfare of the community. 
    Impulsive sound means sound having the following qualities: 
(1)  The peak of the sound level, as measured with an impulse sound level meter S1.4-1971, is maintained for less than one second; 
(2)  Such time is short compared to the occurrence rate; 
(3)  The onset is abrupt; and 
(4)  The decay is rapid. 
    Mobile source denotes any moving sound source on a public right-of-way. 
    Motor vehicle means every land vehicle which is self-propelled or designed for self-propulsion. This definition includes motorcycles. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, and any four wheeled vehicle weighing less than 500 pounds and equipped with an engine of less than six horsepower. 
    Nighttime denotes those times excluded from the definition of the term "daytime." 
    Noise means any sound which annoys or disturbs humans or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on humans. 
    Noise disturbance denotes any sound which: 
(1)  Endangers or injures the safety or health of humans or animals; 
(2)  Annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities; 
(3)  Endangers or injures personal or real property; or 
(4)  Exceeds the applicable maximum permissible sound levels as they appear in the table in section 14-52. 
    Octave band analyzer means an instrument capable of measuring individual octave band levels of a sound by means of a bandpass filter attached to a sound level meter. They shall meet the specifications of the ANSI S1.4-1971, S1.6-1967 and S1.11-1966 for the class II filter. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, cooperative, partnership firm, association, trust, estate, public or private institution, group, agency, political subdivision of this state or any legal successor, representative, agent or agency of the foregoing. 
    Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, alley or public space which is owned or controlled by a public governmental entity. 
    Real property boundary means an imaginary line along the ground surface, and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, but the term "real property" does not include intra-building real property divisions. 
    Small power equipment means any motorized or engine-powered device, including but not limited to lawn mowers, lawn and garden tools, riding tractors and power saws, excluding other motor vehicles. 
    Sound means vibratory disturbance, including an oscillation, in the pressure and/or density of a liquid or gas or in the particulate displacement of a solid or liquid. Such disturbance takes place at a rate between approximately 20 and 20,000 hertz (cycles per second); and the physiological perception of such a vibration of displacement. 
    Sound level shall be as measured with the A-weighting network on a sound level meter unless otherwise specified. 
    Sound level meter means the instrument, meeting the requirements of ANSI S1.4-1971 type II rating, used for making sound level measurements. 
    Sound pressure level is the intensity in decibels (dB) of a sound. 
    Stationary source denotes any sound source operating or occurring on any public or private property, not including a public right-of-way. 
    Weekday means any day Monday through Friday which is not a legal holiday in Falls Church, Virginia. 
    Zoning district refers to the scheme of land use classification contained in chapter 48, pertaining to zoning, or similar classifications contained in zoning ordinances in adjoining jurisdictions. For the purposes of this article: 
(1)  Industrial district includes zones designated in chapter 48 as M-1. 
(2)  Commercial district includes zones designated in chapter 48 as B-1, B-2, B-3, T-1, T-2, and OD. 
(3)  Residential district includes zones designated in chapter 48 as R-1A, R-1B, R C, RTH, RM and CD. 
(Code 1982, § 21-2; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-51. - Prohibited acts. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, and in addition thereto, it shall be unlawful for any person within the city to willfully make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any sound of such character, intensity and duration which disturbs the peace or quiet or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitivity within the city. 
(1)  Animals. No person within the city shall keep or maintain, or permit the keeping of, upon any premises owned, occupied or controlled by such person, any animal otherwise permitted to be kept which, by any sound, shall cause a noise disturbance. 
(2)  Construction of buildings and projects. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to operate equipment or perform any outside construction, demolition, alteration or repair work on buildings, structures or projects or to operate any equipment, including but not limited to, any pile driver, pneumatic hammer, derrick, hoist or other construction device during the nighttime, or during the daytime in such a manner to cause a noise disturbance. No permit shall be required in order to perform emergency work, as defined in this article. 
(3)  Hawkers and peddlers. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to sell or promote anything by outcry within any area of the city. The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the selling by outcry of merchandise, food, and beverages at permitted or licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses and other similar permitted or licensed public entertainment events. 
(4)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to make any sound from any horn, bell or signaling device from any motor vehicle on any street, alley, roadway, private or public way in the city, or any stationary source, except as a danger warning. Emergency signal devices and church bells are exempt from this section. 
(5)  Loading and unloading, commercial. Loading, unloading, opening, closing of commercial vehicles or other handling of boxes, crates, containers, building materials, garbage cans, or similar objects in such a manner as to cause a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary is prohibited. 
(6)  Loudspeakers, public address systems. The following are prohibited: 
a.  Using or operating for any noncommercial purpose any loudspeaker, public address system, or similar device, such that the sound creates a noise disturbance across a real property boundary within or adjacent to any residentially-zoned district, or within 100 yards of any school during school hours. 
b.  Using or operating for any commercial purpose any loudspeaker, public address system, or similar device: 
1.  Such that the sound creates a noise disturbance across a real property boundary or within 100 yards of any school during school hours; or 
2.  Between the hours of 8:00 p.m., and 10:00 a.m., the following day on a public right-of-way or public space. 
(7)  Machinery, power equipment, fans and air conditioning. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to operate any air conditioning, refrigerator, heat pump, fans, swimming pool equipment or other equipment, regardless of location, in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a real property boundary. 
(8)  Small power equipment. It shall be unlawful to operate or permit the operation of any powered saw, drill, sander, grinder, lawn or garden tool, lawn mower, or similar device between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. the following day on weekends and local legal holidays, and 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day on weekdays, so as to cause a noise disturbance across a real property boundary, and it is prohibited. 
(9)  Public places adjacent to institutions of learning, libraries, hospitals and churches. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to create any sound: on any street, sidewalk or public place adjacent to any library, institution of learning or church while the same is in use; or adjacent to any hospital which sound reasonably interferes with the workings of such institution or which disturbs or annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets, sidewalks or public place indicating the presence of an institution of learning, library, church or hospital. 
(10)  Radios, television sets and similar devices. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, television set or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance. 
(11)  Refuse collection vehicles and equipment. The collection of trash or refuse with a refuse vehicle or by the use of any type of motorized equipment during the nighttime is prohibited. The phrase "vehicle and equipment" includes, but is not limited to, trash compactors, gasoline powered blowers used also to collect clippings, leaves or trash, vacuum equipment, and sweeping machines. 
(12)  Engine repairs and testing. It shall be unlawful for any person to repair, rebuild or test any engine so as to create a noise disturbance. 
(13)  Parked or standing motor vehicles. It shall be unlawful to operate the auxiliary engine of a motor vehicle for more than ten minutes within any given hour when the vehicle is parked, or is standing for other than traffic reasons, so as to create a noise disturbance. 
(14)  Operation of motor driven vehicles. It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle other than an authorized emergency vehicle or a vehicle moving under special permit, which creates a noise disturbance. 
(15)  Yelling, shouting, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to yell, shout, talk loudly, whistle or sing on any public street or private property in the city at anytime, so as to cause a noise disturbance. This section shall not apply to any person who is participating in a duly permitted or licensed event or who has been duly authorized to engage in such conduct. 
(Code 1982, § 21-3; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981; Ord. No. 1268, 6-12-1989) 
Sec. 14-52. - Maximum permissible sound pressure levels. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause a sound from a stationary source which exceeds any sound level as set forth in the applicable column in the following table entitled "Maximum Permissible Sound Levels" when measured at any point within any other property affected by the sound. Measurement shall be made by a duly authorized individual who is knowledgeable in the proper use of the measurement equipment. Measurement shall be made at slow response, A-weighting, except in the case of impulsive sound which shall be measured with an impulsive sound level meter, ANSI S1.4-1971. Octave band measurements, where noted, shall be made with an octave band analyzer. When a noise source can be identified and its noise measured in more than one zoning district, the most restrictive limits shall apply.

(Code 1982, § 21-4) 
Sec. 14-53. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Whenever the city manager or an agent of the city manager determines that any noise source fails to meet the requirement set forth in this article or in applicable regulations issued pursuant thereto, the city manager may obtain a warrant or summons for the prosecution of such violation. In addition, if the agent is a duly qualified law enforcement officer of the city, the city manager may issue a summons to, or arrest, without a warrant, any person who, in the presence of the officer, violates this article. Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to restrict the right of any person to secure a summons or warrant for a violation of this article through a duly authorized magistrate. 
(b)  Furthermore, the city manager or an agent of the city manager may issue a notice of violation setting forth the alleged failures and advising the owner, occupant, operator or agent that such failures must be corrected. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Set forth the alleged violations of this article or of applicable regulations issued pursuant thereto; 
(3)  Describe the premises where the violations are alleged to exist and/or other identifications of the noise source; 
(4)  Set forth a reasonable time within which any violation alleged is required to be corrected; 
(5)  Be served upon the owner, occupant or operator of the noise source, or upon the agent of any of the foregoing, by: 
a.  Personally delivering the same to such person; 
b.  Mailing the same to such person by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known place of residence of such person; or 
c.  Posting same in or about the premises described in the notice, if service under subsection (b)(5)a of this section cannot be effected. 
At the end of the period of time allowed for correction of any violation alleged, the city manager shall reinspect the noise source described in the notice. 
(Code 1982, § 21-5; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981; Ord. No. 1268, 6-12-1989) 
Sec. 14-54. - Variance. 
(a)  Any person responsible for any noise source may apply to the city manager for a variance or partial variance from the provisions of this article. The application shall be accompanied by such information and data as the city manager may require. The city manager may grant such variance or partial variance if such manager finds that: 
(1)  The potential danger to the community is outweighed by the benefit to the public interest during the period of variance; 
(2)  Compliance with the provision of this article from which variance is sought would produce serious hardship without equal or greater benefits to the public. 
(b)  No variance or partial variance issued pursuant to this section shall be granted for a period to exceed one year, but any such variance or partial variance may be renewed for like periods if after being duly considered at a hearing held by the city manager, he finds that renewal is justified under subsection (a) of this section. No renewal shall be granted except on application. Any such application shall be made at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the variance or partial variance. Any renewal granted pursuant to this subsection shall be on the same grounds and subject to the same limitations and requirements as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  A variance, partial variance or renewal thereof shall not be a right of the applicant or holder thereof but shall be in the discretion of the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 21-6; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Sec. 14-55. - Emergencies. 
    An exemption from the provisions of this article is automatically granted for noise caused in the performance of emergency work. Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit law enforcement, ambulance, fire or other emergency personnel to make excessive noise in the performance of their duties when such noise is clearly unnecessary. 
(Code 1982, § 21-7; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Sec. 14-56. - Noise suppression devices. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit the removal, disconnection or disabling of any noise suppression system or device which has been installed on any noise source: 
(1)  In accordance with federal or state laws or regulations; 
(2)  As a requirement for obtaining a permit to construct, modify, or install such noise source. 
(b)  No person shall defeat the purpose of any noise suppression system or device by installing or modifying therein or thereon any part or component which does not meet the minimum design specifications for that system or device. 
(c)  No noise source shall be operated with its noise suppression system or device removed or otherwise rendered inoperable or in disrepair. 
(Code 1982, § 21-8; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Sec. 14-57. - Penalties; violations deemed nuisances. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished in accordance with subsection 28-1(1). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(b)  As an additional remedy, the operation or maintenance of devices, instruments, vehicles or machinery in violation of any provision of this article, which operation or maintenance cause discomfort or annoyance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness or which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents in the area, shall be deemed, and is declared to be a public nuisance and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 21-9; Ord. No. 982, 9-14-1981) 
Secs. 14-58-14-87. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - OUTDOOR LIGHTING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; condominiums, § 6-48 et seq.; housing, ch. 22; outdoor advertising, § 28-89; utilities, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; subdivisions, ch 38; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq.; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate outdoor lighting in certain areas, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-920. 

Sec. 14-127. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Average illumination intensity means the average of meter readings in footcandles at grade level at several points, all of which shall be the average of all points in the area of projected lighting pattern. 
    Glare means the sensation produced by brightness within the visual field that is sufficiently greater than the luminance to which the eyes are adapted to cause annoyance, discomfort, or loss in visual performance and visibility. 
    Glare, direct, means glare resulting from high brightness of insufficiently shielded light sources in the field of view emanating or reflecting from areas of high brightness. 
    Glare, disability, means glare which reduces visual performance and visibility and which is often accompanied by discomfort. 
    Glare, reflected, means glare resulting from spectacular reflections of high brightness in polished or glossy surfaces in the field of view. It is usually associated with reflections within a visual task of areas in close proximity to the region being viewed. 
    Grade level means the average natural topographical elevation or average elevation established either by earth grading or hard-surfacing at which the major portion of the adjacent site area lies; except, that no specially constructed or graded area, ornamental or protective earthwork or raised landscape areas shall be determinant of ground level. 
    Height. The height of a light source shall be the measured vertical distance between the light source and the grade level. The height of a light structure shall be the vertical distance between the uppermost extremity of any light structure, pole, supporting member or structural or nonstructural trim and the grade level. 
    Light source means a single artificial point source of luminescence that emits measurable radiant energy within the visible spectrum. 
    Measurement of intensity. Where the average intensity of artificial illumination is determinable, it shall be measured in footcandles vertically or horizontally corrected for the angle of incident from grade level. 
    Spillage means any light flux or diffusion, glare or other artificial light emission onto any adjoining property above a defined maximum intensity as specified in section 14-131. 
(Code 1973, § 25-1; Code 1982, § 23-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-128. - Purpose and intent of article. 
    It is the purpose and intent of this article to prevent the creation of nuisance caused by unnecessary intensity of artificial illumination of property and buildings, to promote the safety and general welfare of the public by the regulation of glare producing sources of light and to ensure the required minimum illumination to facilitate enforcement of law. 
(Code 1973, § 25-2; Code 1982, § 23-2) 
Sec. 14-129. - Zoning districts where required; exception; compliance with article. 
    Outdoor lighting shall be required in all zoning districts with the exception of R-1A, R-1B, R-TH and shall meet the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 25-3; Code 1982, § 23-3) 
Sec. 14-130. - Permits. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a permit for the installation of exterior light sources, a plan and elevation to scale shall be prepared in duplicate and submitted to the zoning administrator. Such drawing shall depict the proposed number, specific locations, intensity, projected lighting patterns, style of fixtures and type of illumination of all light sources. The plans submitted in compliance hereto shall not be deemed sufficient to fulfill the requirements of the building code, but are in addition thereto. All plans and elevations shall be prepared to show conformity with this article and shall be certified by a registered engineer, registered electrical contractor, architect or other such licensed person qualified to make such certification. 
(b)  Approval of an application for an outdoor lighting permit by the planning commission shall be required whenever it: 
(1)  Is in conjunction with a site plan or PUD plan application submitted under the zoning regulations. 
(2)  Is for an area of greater than one acre, 43,560 square feet. 
(3)  Is proposed for an installation of greater than 25 fixtures. 
(4)  Includes common lighting proposed for two or more establishments of different ownership. 
(5)  Is requested for an outdoor recreation or assembly area as governed by section 14-140. 
(c)  Any and all exterior artificial light sources requiring a permit, and not having specific special regulations, shall be governed by the provisions of this article. 
(d)  No zoning application or permit shall be required for the installation of any exterior light sources permitted in residential districts R-1A, R-1B and R-TH, except as specified in section 14-135. This subsection shall not in any way impair the validity of the requirements of the building code. 
(e)  No application or permit shall be required for warning lights to be erected in conjunction with construction, excavation, maintenance, repair, etc., as required by sections 36-12 and 36-70. All exterior light sources installed, erected or maintained under this subsection shall be subject to section 14-129. 
(f)  All installations shall conform where applicable to chapters 6 and 36, as certified by the division of inspections and zoning administrator. 
(g)  No permit shall be required of the city or the state or of any public utility corporation when performing contractual arrangements for the city or state for the installation of any light source, except as provided for in chapter 42, and subject to the provisions of section 14-131. 
(h)  When a public utility has contracted for the installation of outdoor lighting with a private concern, a lighting permit is required and the application filed with the zoning administrator. The public utility is exempt from all the provisions of chapter 6. 
(i)  Prior to the approval of a certificate of occupancy for any establishment having previously permitted exterior light sources requiring a permit under this article, an application shall be submitted in the same form as that required for new light sources. Approval of a certificate of occupancy shall be contingent upon approval of an outdoor light permit. 
(Code 1973, § 25-4; Code 1982, § 23-4) 
Cross reference- Business, professional, occupational licenses, § 40-456 et seq. 
Sec. 14-131. - Spillage control. 
(a)  All light sources installed, erected or maintained in any district shall be shielded or directed so as to confine the area of diffusion to the property which it is intended to illuminate. No light source shall be maintained in any manner or located where it creates a nuisance to the users of adjoining properties, nor shall any light source remain erected which would create a traffic hazard. Spillage of light exceeding 0.1-1.0 footcandles measured at any point seven feet beyond a property line shall be prohibited, unless otherwise specified in this article. 
(b)  Whenever a contiguous property is compatibly illuminated and is in business or commercial use, subsection (a) of this section may be waived. 
(Code 1973, § 25-5; Code 1982, § 23-5) 
Sec. 14-132. - Prohibited installations. 
    The following shall be prohibited throughout all districts and in conjunction with all uses within the city unless otherwise provided: 
(1)  Any artificial light source exceeding 45 feet in height above grade level. 
(2)  Any permanent festoon lighting or any light source suspended from wires, cables, tubes or ropes that are subject to noticeable movements from wind or weather related conditions. 
(3)  Any artificial light source which creates glare observable within the normal range of vision from any public walk, thoroughfare or contiguous property under normal weather conditions. 
(4)  Bare fluorescent tubes, neon tubes, incandescent bulbs or unprotected gas lamps. 
(5)  Display of intermittent lights or any flashing, blinking or moving lights, or beacon or search lights except as required by state or federal law. 
(6)  Any artificial light source or supporting structure installed over any street or side-walk, except as otherwise provided by section 36-5. 
(Code 1973, § 25-6; Code 1982, § 23-6; Ord. No. 1948, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 14-133. - Sources deemed accessory uses. 
    Any exterior light source and accompanying structural support shall be deemed an accessory use in all zoning districts. 
(Code 1973, § 25-7; Code 1982, § 23-7) 
Sec. 14-134. - Existing systems. 
    This article shall also apply to existing systems. 
(Code 1973, § 25-8; Code 1982, § 23-8) 
Sec. 14-135. - R-1A district. 
    Exterior light sources shall not be permitted in an R-1A one-family residence district, with the exception of the following: 
(1)  No artificial light source shall create a nuisance observable within the normal range of vision from a public walk or thoroughfare or contiguous property. 
(2)  Floodlighting of single-, double- or triple-cluster type shall be limited to 150 watts per light source, to be so directed or shielded to confine the area of illumination to the immediate property. The number of floodlights shall not exceed five per residence property. 
(3)  Porch, portico and doorway light sources shall be so directed or shielded to confine the area of light to the entranceway. 
(4)  Festive lighting of a temporary nature shall be erected no more than three days before and shall be removed no later than three days after the activity or event. When the festive lighting denotes celebration of a recognized national, legal or religious celebration, these periods shall be extended to cover such time as is customarily appropriate to the celebration, but in no instance to exceed a total time lapse of 30 days. 
(5)  All exterior light sources shall also be regulated by the provisions of section 14-132. 
(Code 1973, § 25-10; Code 1982, § 23-10) 
Sec. 14-136. - R-1B district. 
    Exterior light sources shall not be permitted in an R-1B one family residence district, except for those permitted in and regulated by the R-1A district provisions. 
(Code 1973, § 25-11; Code 1982, § 23-11) 
Sec. 14-137. - R-TH townhouse district. 
    Exterior light sources shall not be permitted in an R-TH townhouse district, with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Any exterior light sources permitted in and regulated by the R-1B district provisions. 
(2)  Lighting of any common green space provided in compliance with shall be properly shielded as required in section 14-131. 
(Code 1973, § 25-12; Code 1982, § 23-12) 
Sec. 14-138. - R-M general residence district. 
    Exterior light sources shall not be permitted in an R-M general residence district with the exception of the following: 
(1)  The average intensity of illumination of off-street parking areas shall not exceed 5.0 footcandles. 
(2)  Such lighting of yards, walkways, gardens and entranceways as required for the safety and well-being of the tenants may be provided but shall not exceed an average illumination of 5.0 footcandles. 
(3)  No light source extending above any parking area, street, alley, driveway or other area intended for the use of motor vehicles shall be less than 16 feet in height unless the structural support is surrounded at grade level by a six-inch concrete header curb at a minimum radial distance of four feet, in which instance a light source may be a minimum height of eight feet above the traveled surface. Where this lower minimum is utilized there shall be no projections, arms, davits or other supporting structures nor any light source extending to within three feet of any vehicular traffic lane, aisle or driveway. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit driveway lighting, properly screened to prevent glare and spillage, and not exceeding a height of 24 inches, from being erected provided it is protected by a six-inch concrete header curb and is at least three feet from any traffic lane, parking aisle or driveway. 
(4)  Festive or temporary lighting shall be governed by the provisions of section 14-135(4). 
(Code 1973, § 25-13; Code 1982, § 23-13) 
Sec. 14-139. - T-1 transitional district. 
    Exterior light sources shall not be permitted in a T-1 transitional district, except for those permitted in and regulated by the R-M district provisions. 
(Code 1973, § 25-14; Code 1982, § 23-14) 
Sec. 14-140. - Other districts and uses. 
    All zoning districts and uses not otherwise provided for shall be regulated by the following: 
(1)  Side and rear service yards. 
a.  Side and rear yards of all buildings shall be lighted during the period from one-half hour before sunset to one-half hour after sunrise. Such light sources shall be shielded and mounted on the walls of the building in the immediate area of each service or exit door and at a height not less than 16 feet above grade level. No light source required by this subsection shall be erected at a height greater than the roof, cornice line or 45 feet, whichever is the lesser. 
b.  Wall-mounted floodlights or spotlights installed to provide general illumination of the service area shall be prohibited unless installed in such a manner as to prevent glare from the light source being visible from any adjacent property. 
c.  Illumination in the vicinity of each service or exit door shall be a minimum average of 5.0 footcandles. The maximum illumination at grade level shall not exceed 10.0 footcandles. 
(2)  Parking areas. 
a.  Average intensity of illumination of parking areas shall be limited to 10.0 footcandles. In all other respects parking areas shall be regulated by section 14-131 and section 14-138(3). 
b.  No light source shall be mounted at a height greater than 45 feet nor shall any portion of the lighting structure exceed that height. 
c.  Freestanding structures shall be mounted on or in concrete bases of sufficient size and strength to adequately support the structures and fixtures without the use of guy wires. 
d.  The illumination level of entrances into off-street parking areas and exits onto public thoroughfares shall not exceed 10.0 footcandles. 
(3)  Automobile service stations. 
a.  Artificial illumination of pump islands shall not exceed a maximum level of illumination of 20 footcandles, with light sources shielded and directed downward. All structures and fixtures for the purpose of illuminating pump islands shall be located thereon. 
b.  In general service areas the maximum illumination at grade level shall not exceed 10.0 footcandles; provided, that fixtures for such illumination are shielded and directed downward in such manner to prevent the source of light from being visible within the normal angle of vision from any public walk or thoroughfare. 
c.  The illumination level of entrances and exits from and onto public thoroughfares shall be governed by subsection (2)d of this section. 
(4)  Outdoor sales areas. 
a.  All lighting sources shall be contained within shielding devices directed in such a manner to prevent the source of light from being visible within the normal angle of vision from any public walk or thoroughfare. 
b.  The maximum average illuminating intensity at grade level shall not exceed 10.0 footcandles average of area. 
c.  Whenever the movement of on-site vehicles is inherent in the arrangement of display, the provisions of section 14-138(3) shall apply. 
(5)  Canopy lighting. Artificial illumination of sidewalk areas beneath canopies, where intended for use by the general public, shall be limited to a maximum of 5.0 footcandles directly under the canopy at grade level. 
(6)  Building illumination. 
a.  Nothing in this article shall prohibit the artificial illumination of building facades, statues, monuments and foundations or other such ornamental structures; provided, that such illumination is achieved by the use of shielded lamps or fixtures which shall direct illumination only onto the subject to be illuminated. 
b.  Light sources for such illumination shall be mounted at sufficient height to prevent the source of light from being visible within the normal angle of vision and so positioned to prevent the source of light from being visible from any public walk or thoroughfare. The height of the light source shall not exceed 45 feet or one-half the actual building height, whichever is the lesser, except when the light source is directed downward to the base of the structure and is situated wholly within an overhanging roofline projection or decorative parapet wall enclosure constructed of materials compatible with the building facade. 
c.  Whenever such light source is mounted on or within six feet of the grade level, it shall be effectively screened by dense evergreens or other decorative means to prevent the source of light from being visible from any public walk or thoroughfare. 
(7)  Sign illumination. All signs illuminated in any manner shall conform to the restriction, limitations and prohibitions of both the general provisions of this article and such other regulations in chapter 48, article VI, pertaining to signs. 
(8)  Festive or temporary lighting. 
a.  All temporary or festive lighting shall be subject to the general provisions of this article as well as any special regulations by the district in which it is located. In addition, all festive and temporary lighting shall conform to section 14-135(4). 
b.  All lighting erected in conjunction with any carnival or outdoor assembly shall comply with section 6-41. 
(9)  Outdoor recreation or assembly. 
a.  Artificial illumination of any outdoor recreation or assembly area or facility shall conform to the provisions of section 14-131 and the general prohibitions of section 14-132, except subsection (1) of such section. 
b.  The height limit of section 14-132(1) shall apply to all outdoor recreation or assembly areas or facilities except when this limitation is considered inappropriate because of the nature of the existing or intended use of such areas or facilities, or because of considerations of safety. In such instance an application may be made to the planning commission for permission to erect such lighting at a height suitable to the special nature of the use, area, or facility. The planning commission may approve such application with any stipulations they deem necessary and make such a condition to the granting of the permit subject to the general requirements of section 14-130. Violation of stipulations shall be grounds for revocation of such permit. 
(Code 1973, § 25-15; Code 1982, § 23-15) 
Sec. 14-141. - Appeals. 
(a)  Except for instances relating to projecting light sources or supporting structures located or proposed to be located on or over public property, any person who has been ordered by the zoning administrator to incur an expense for the alteration or removal of light sources or supporting structures, or any person whose application for a permit for a light source or supporting structure has been refused, may appeal to the board of zoning appeals by serving written notice to the zoning administrator and electrical inspector. Such appeal may be transmitted to the board of zoning appeals. Upon the filing of a notice of appeal the electrical inspector shall take no further action with regard to the light source or supporting structure involved until the final decision of either board has been rendered, unless the electrical inspector or zoning administrator finds that the light source or supporting structure involved, by reason of its condition, presents an immediate and serious danger to the public, in which instance the electrical inspector shall proceed immediately. 
(b)  The board of zoning appeals, pursuant to the same powers and authority and in accordance with the same procedures of sections 48-172 and 48-173, may only grant variances of siting height and light sources. 
(Code 1973, § 25-16; Code 1982, § 23-16) 
Sec. 14-142. - Enforcement of article. 
(a)  The zoning administrator shall make inspections and tests necessary to obtain compliance with the provisions of this article, and shall have absolute right of entry upon any premises for inspection between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on normal working days. In all cases the inspector shall present proper identification to and request entry from the owner or occupant of the premises. If entry is refused, the inspector showing reasonable cause to believe the existence of a violation shall apply to the bailing justice or municipal court for a warrant authorizing entry. 
(b)  The zoning administrator shall revoke any outdoor lighting permit which violates any provision of this article or of this Code, or which has been secured by subterfuge, or is void, or which has been issued by mistake, misunderstanding or error by the city. 
(c)  All rights and privileges required under the provisions of this article or any amendments thereto are mere licenses revocable at any time by the zoning administrator, and all such permits shall contain this provision. 
(d)  Every light source or supporting structure unlawfully placed upon or projecting within at least three feet from a public right-of-way or unlawfully on public property or declared to be hazardous or unsafe by the zoning administrator is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(e)  The zoning administrator shall issue a violation notice and order in writing for violation of this article. A violation notice may be issued without an order to comply or may order compliance and grant a time limit for compliance. 
(f)  The notice and order shall be deemed to give actual notice, if given in either or all the following manners: 
(1)  By handling in person either to the owner or occupant of the premises on which the light source is located, the owner of the light source, the person responsible for the light source or the permittee; and the time for compliance with the order shall start from the date of notice. 
(2)  Registered mail, return receipt requested, addressed to either or all of the persons described in subsection (f)(1) of this section to addresses shown on the commissioner of the revenue's current records or as shown on the permit; and the time for compliance with the order shall start on the date of receipt of delivery. 
(3)  By posting on the light source or on the supporting structure or on the premises; and time for compliance shall start on the date of posting. 
(Code 1973, § 25-17; Code 1982, § 23-17) 
Sec. 14-143. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12. 
(b)  Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Code 1973, § 25-18; Code 1982, § 23-18) 
Secs. 14-144-14-163. - Reserved.
