Chapter 15 - FEES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - General fees. 
(a)  Fees for photo copies will be determined by the city clerk and updated annually. The current fee is: 
(1)  Black and white copies at $0.25 per page. 
(2)  Color copies at $0.50 per page. 
(b)  An insufficient funds charge (returned check) will be determined by the treasurer. The current fee is: 
(1)  The cost for a returned check shall be $35.00. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4), 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 15-2. - Mobile food service fees. 
    The annual fee for a mobile food service permit will be $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 1913, 12-9-2013; Ord. No. 1922, 4-28-2014) 
Editor's note- At the request of the city, § 15-2 has been added back to the City Code which was inadvertently deleted by Ord. No. 1922. 
Secs. 15-3-15-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF DEVELOPMENT SERVICES 

Sec. 15-20. - General department of development services fee information. 
    The following shall apply to permits and activities performed by the department of development services: 
(1)  Nonemergency work without a permit shall be charged an investigation fee of $55.00. Applicant must apply for a permit within one week or a further fee of $330.00 will be charged. Approved permits for work without a permit must be picked up within two weeks of approval, or a fee of $330.00 will be charged. 
(2)  The minimum fee for any permit shall be $55.00. 
(3)  All permits shall have the required state levy collected. 
(4)  A reinspection fee of $55.00 shall be charged for rejected work or work found not ready to be inspected. 
(5)  Fees must be collected prior to any permit being issued. For any projects that exceed 15,000 square feet in finished floor area, a nonrefundable down payment equal to the estimated plan review fee shall be collected at time of submission. 
(6)  Inspection may be conducted after hours at an applicant's request and with the consent of the building official. Such inspections will incur an additional charge of $110.00 per hour, billed in half-hour increments, or portion thereof, with a minimum of one hour. 
(7)  Appeals to the local board of building and fire prevention code appeals shall be charged $550.00 
(8)  When a notice of violation or notice of unsafe structure is issued to a commercial property, the violator shall pay $110.00 for each month, or portion thereof, the violation remains outstanding. 
(9)  Amendment to a permit: Any amendment to a permit shall be subject to additional costs based on the fee schedule. 
(10)  Extension of time: Upon written application by the permitee and prior to expiration of the permit, the building official or his designee may extend the time limit of the permit for a period of six months in accordance with the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and the Code of the City of Falls Church at no additional fee. Extensions for permits already expired may also be requested. A fee of $55.00 will be charged if the extension is granted. 
(11)  Outside agency reviews: At the discretion of the building official, plans may be sent to an outside agency for additional plan review. In such cases the applicant shall pay a plan review fee of ten percent of the square footage charge (reduced from the normal 30 percent) plus the full cost of the outside agency review. 
(12)  Refunds: In cases where the permit is revoked or the project is withdrawn or abandoned, the base permit fee, not including any plan review or third-party fees, shall be refunded provided the permittee's written request to the city building official has been received within the life of the permit. Refund shall be issued only after a final inspection to confirm the noncompletion of the project and that any area involved has been left in a satisfactory condition. The amount refunded shall be proportional to the remaining work, as determined by the building official. 
(13)  All transactions paid by credit or debit card shall be subject to an additional charge as established by the city treasurer. This fee shall be clearly posted at the permits counter. 
(14)  Any application for a building safety permit requiring review of plans shall have a plan review fee added to the permit fee. This plan review fee shall be 30 percent of the permit fee or $100.00, whichever is greater. The building official may waive all or part of this fee for plan reviews of a minor nature. 
(15)  Technology and office automation and integration fee: Each permit issued shall have added to its base approved fee a ten percent technology and office automation, integration fee, to be dedicated exclusively to fund the purchase, upgrade and maintenance of equipment, electronics, software, peripherals and associated equipment, and employed by the department of development services. Exception: Certificates of occupancy shall be exempt. 
(16)  Administrative fee: Each DDS permit and application taken in by DDS shall have added to its base approved fee a ten percent administrative fee to be dedicated to fund staff who perform administrative services in the department of development services associated with development project coordination and intake, project review, evaluation and implementation; administration and enforcement of the zoning ordinance; and permit processing and inspection. Exception: Certificates of occupancy shall be exempt. 
(17)  Waiver of certain fees: Where a business has been operating at a location for a year or more (as determined by issuance of a certificate of occupancy) and relocates due to redevelopment, the fees enumerated in sections 15-21 through 15-27 shall be waived where each of the following conditions apply: 1) the business owner is a lessor on the property being redeveloped and such lease has been in effect for one year or more; 2) the business owner's lease is subject to termination or non-renewal due to the redevelopment of the leased property; 3) the property of the leasehold is subject to an application for a special exception under City Code section 48-90 that the city has formally accepted for review; 4) the business is relocating to another location in the city, as evidenced by a new lease; and 5) the business owner submits an application for a fee waiver on a form provided by the department of development services. Eligibility to apply for a waiver of fees by a business owner meeting these conditions shall be retroactive to January 1, 2015, and refunds shall be paid to businesses eligible for the waiver who have paid fees after January 1, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4), 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 1901, 7-22-2013; Ord. No. 1922, 4-28-2014; Ord. No. 1943, 12-14-2015; Ord. No. 1958, 6-13-2016) 
Sec. 15-21. - Building permits. 
    The following applies to fees for building permits as noted in the table below: 
(1)  Square footage calculation includes basement and roof areas, in addition to all floors in between. 
(2)  Amusement ride permits are not subject to a minimum permit fee. Ride must be ready for inspection during normal business hours prior to the event. Alternatively, the ride may be inspected by a properly-licensed third-party inspector, who shall provide the results to the city in writing within seven days of any such inspection. If a properly-licensed third-party inspector carries out the inspection of an amusement ride, the permit fee shall be reduced by 50 percent. At the discretion of the building official, the city may inspect the ride outside of normal business hours. In this case, the permit fee is not reduced and the normal charges for after-hours inspection will be added to the permit fee. 
(3)  In addition, a permit for the demolition of a building or structure shall require posting of a cash escrow bond in the amount of $1.00 per square foot of building to be demolished, with a minimum of $1,000.00. Said escrow shall be released to the permit holder upon satisfactory completion of the work and the certification by the building inspector that the premises have been made safe and sanitary. 
(4)  Additionally, for new single-family dwellings, the charge of $0.55 per square foot applies to the foundation and any decking. For new commercial and multifamily construction, the charge of $0.65 per square foot applies to the foundation and any decking. For temporary trailers, a $550.00 cash bond shall be posted with the city to ensure removal and cleanup. 
(5)  In addition to the permit fee, NEIS will charge the permit recipient directly for necessary construction and maintenance elevator inspections. 
(6)  The actual cost to the city of plan review by an outside agency shall be added to the permit fee in the event of any such review by an outside agency.

ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 15-35. - General department of public works fee information. 
    The following shall apply to permits and activities performed by the department of public works: 
(1)  Technology, office automation and integration fee: Each permit issued shall have added to its base approved fee a ten percent technology and office automation and integration fee to be dedicated exclusively to fund the purchase, upgrade, and maintenance of equipment, electronics, software, peripherals, and associated equipment employed by the department in the administration of permits. 
(Ord. No. 1958, 6-13-2016)

ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 15-46. - Fire prevention-General. 
(a)  In accordance with the Fire Prevention Code (City Code chapter 18, state law reference-Fire protection, Code of Virginia, § 27-1 et seq.), operational permits are required for those items listed in Table 107.2 which includes activities involving the handling, storage or use of substances, materials or devices regulated by the fire prevention code. 
(b)  In addition, operational permits are required for those occupancies conducting processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property; and establishing and operating certain types of occupancies such as a place of assembly/education, and special amusement building or carnival/fair. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4), 4-25-2011) 
Sec. 15-47. - Fire prevention permits. 
(a)  Note a: All inspection fees where applicable are based on an hourly rate of $130.00. The minimum charge is $65.00. After the first half hour, the fee charge is $32.50 per quarter hour. 
(b)  Note b: Plans review and inspection fees may be waived if the fee is included as part of a fee that includes all agencies, such as special events. 
(c)  Note c: Hourly inspection rate doubles in the event of continued noncompliance. 
    The fire marshal requires an inspection for those occupancies identified in the table below prior to the issuing a fire prevention code permit. Operational permits issued by the city fire marshal are known as "fire prevention code permits" (FPCP). An FPCP is required for each process, installation, storage, occupancy or use as follows along with associated fees:

Chapter 16 - FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Financial powers of city, § 2.02; budgets, § 6.01 et seq.; borrowing, § 7.01 et seq.; financial administration, § 8.01 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; director of finance, § 2-185 et seq.; taxation, ch. 40; business, professional, occupation licenses, § 40-456 et seq. 
State Law reference- Security for public deposits act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4000 et seq.; contracts and purchases, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4300 et seq.; investment pool act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4600 et seq.; public debt, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4900 et seq.; interest on obligations of local government, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-5000 et seq.; taxes and assessments, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1104; borrowing money, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1105; management of financial affairs, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1106; budgets, audits, reports, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500 et seq.; public finance act, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2600 et seq.; taxation, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin on July 1 and end on June 30 of each year. 
(Code 1973, § 9-1; Code 1982, § 10-1) 
Charter reference- Fiscal year, § 6.01. 
State Law reference- Fiscal year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500. 
Sec. 16-2. - Payment of taxes and other fees by checks, credit cards, debit cards and electronic funds. 
(a)  The treasurer is hereby authorized, pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 2.2-614.1, as amended, to accept payment of local taxes and other fees, penalties and interest by the use of any commercially acceptable means, including, but not limited to, checks, credit cards, debit cards and electronic funds transfer and may add to any amount due a sum, not to exceed the amount charged to the city for acceptance of any payment by a means that incurs a charge to the city or the amount negotiated and agreed to in a contract with the city, whichever is less. The treasurer is authorized to investigate credit card entities and determine those that are responsible, efficient and capable of cooperating with the city for the collection of local taxes and other fees, and to establish a list of credit cards so determined that may be accepted for payment of local taxes and other fees, penalties and interest. 
(b)  If any credit card transaction tendered for payment of any tax or other fee, penalty and interest due is not paid by the bank or credit card company, the taxpayer for whom such credit card transaction was tendered shall remain liable for the payment of the tax or other fee, penalty and interest, the same as if such credit card transaction had not been tendered. 
(c)  A penalty of $50.00 shall be imposed for the uttering, publishing or passing of any check, draft or order for payment of taxes or any other sums due the city, which is subsequently returned for insufficient funds or because there is no account or the account has been closed, or because such check, draft or order was returned because of a stop-payment order placed in bad faith on the check, draft or order by the drawer. This penalty shall be in addition to any other penalty provided by law, except the penalty imposed by the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-12 shall not apply. 
(d)  The city manager will provide to the treasurer a list of fees eligible to be paid by credit card. 
(Code 1982, § 1-17; Ord. No. 1494, 10-11-1994; Ord. No. 1961, 8-8-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority to accept payment by commercially acceptable means, service charge, bad check charge, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-614.1; payment of tax by bad check, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106. 
Sec. 16-3. - Fines and costs. 
(a)  Any person liable for any local account, who fails to pay the amount due by the due date, shall incur a penalty thereon in the amount of $10.00 or ten percent of the amount due, whichever shall be greater. Such penalty shall be added to the amount of the account due from such person. No penalty shall be imposed for the failure to pay any account if such failure was not in any way the fault of the debtor. Interest at the rate of ten percent annually shall be collected on the principal and penalty of all such accounts, from the first day following the day such account is due. 
(b)  Any city department may enter into an agreement with the city treasurer for the collection of such accounts. 
(Ord. No. 1961, 8-8-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose late fees and penalties on city debt, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-105. 
Sec. 16-4. - Application of payment. 
    The treasurer shall not be required to apply all payments to the most delinquent account and may use discretion in applying payments where the taxpayer has entered into a bona fide payment agreement with the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1961, 8-8-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority to give the treasurer discretion in applying payments, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3913. 
Secs. 16-5-16-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURCHASES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Virginia Procurement Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4300 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-23. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Construction means building, altering, repairing, improving or demolishing any structure, building or highway, and any draining, dredging, excavation, grading or similar work upon real property. 
    Goods means all material, equipment, supplies, printing and automated data processing hardware and software. 
    Governing body means the city council. 
    Nonprofessional services means any services not specifically identified as professional services as defined in this section. 
    Professional services means work performed by an independent contractor within the scope of the practice of accounting, architecture, land surveying, landscape architecture, law, dentistry, medicine, optometry, pharmacy, actuarial services, or professional engineering. 
    Public body means any legislative, executive or judicial agency, office, department, authority, post, commission, committee, institution, board, or political subdivision created by law to exercise some sovereign power or to perform some governmental duty, and empowered by law to undertake the activities described in this article. 
    Services means any work performed by an independent contractor, except for construction, which does not consist primarily of acquisition of equipment or materials, or the rental of equipment, materials and supplies. 
(Code 1982, § 10-4; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4301. 
Sec. 16-24. - Application. 
    This article applies to all contracts for goods, services, insurance and construction entered into by this city. All public bodies in the city, as defined in section 16-23, that are funded in whole or in part by the city, except the school board, are required to comply with the provisions of this article and purchase goods, services, insurance and construction through the central purchasing system established under this article. When the procurement involves the expenditure of federal assistance or contract funds, the procurement shall be conducted in accordance with any applicable mandatory federal law and regulation which is not reflected in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 10-3; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Sec. 16-25. - City council approval of certain contracts. 
    No contract for professional services that exceeds $60,000.00 or any other contract that exceeds $100,000.00 shall be awarded without city council approval. 
(Ord. No. 1798, § 10-10, 11-27-2006) 
Secs. 16-26-16-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING AGENT 

Sec. 16-54. - Establishment and appointment. 
    The purchasing system shall operate under the direction and supervision of the purchasing agent who shall be appointed by the director of finance, subject to the direction of the city manager or the designee of such purchasing agent. 
(Code 1982, § 10-5; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Sec. 16-55. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  Authority. The purchasing agent shall serve as the principal public purchasing official for this city and shall be responsible for the procurement of goods, services, insurance and construction in accordance with this article, as well as for the management of the disposal of surplus supplies and equipment. 
(b)  Duties. In accordance with this article, and subject to the supervision and direction of the city manager or the city manager's designee, the purchasing agent shall: 
(1)  Contract for all goods, services, insurance and construction needed by this city; 
(2)  Sell, trade or otherwise dispose of surplus goods belonging to the city; 
(3)  Establish and maintain programs for specification development, contract administration, inspection, and acceptance, in cooperation with the city agency or public body that has requested the goods, service, insurance or construction; 
(4)  Prepare and update standard specifications; 
(5)  Inspect or require the using agency to inspect all deliveries of goods, services, or construction purchased through the purchasing agent to ensure conformance with the contract specifications; 
(6)  Procure for the city the highest quality goods, services, insurance and construction at the lowest cost; 
(7)  Endeavor to obtain maximum feasible competition for all purchases and sales; 
(8)  Keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing, prices, market conditions, and new products; 
(9)  Secure for the city the benefits of research done in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions, national societies, national trade associations, and private businesses and organizations; 
(10)  Prepare and adopt standard purchase definitions and forms; 
(11)  Prepare, adopt, and maintain a contract file containing descriptions of commodities, prices and discounts of goods and services available for purchase under term contracts established by the purchasing agent; 
(12)  Maintain a current file of sources of goods, services, insurance and construction to be known as a bidder list on which vendors can request to be included; 
(13)  Ensure that sufficient money has been appropriated to cover the cost of all purchases or contracts; and 
(14)  Perform other functions and duties as required by this article, the city Charter, or as the city manager or the designee of the city manager may assign. 
(Code 1982, § 10-6; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Sec. 16-56. - Delegation. 
    With the written approval of the city manager or the designee of the city manager, the purchasing agent may delegate the authority to purchase certain supplies, services, or construction items to other city employees or public bodies, if such delegation is deemed necessary for the effective procurement of those items. 
(Code 1982, § 10-7; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Sec. 16-57. - Revisory authority. 
    The purchasing agent shall have the authority to disapprove any purchases to the quantity or quality of the commodity requested, and shall have the authority to change specifications. Decisions under this section may be appealed to the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 10-8; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Sec. 16-58. - Rules and regulations. 
    The purchasing agent may prepare and maintain a purchasing manual containing detailed rules and regulations consistent with this division and the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia governing the operation of the city purchasing system. Publication of this purchasing manual requires approval by the city manager, as will all subsequent amendments and reissuance. 
(Code 1982, § 10-9; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995) 
Secs. 16-59-16-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COOPERATIVE PROCUREMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Cooperative procurement, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4304. 

Sec. 16-90. - Conditions for use. 
(a)  The city may enter into a cooperative agreement, including those under Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4304, for the purpose of combining requirements to increase efficiency or reduce administrative expenses. 
(b)  All cooperative contracts entered into or used by the city shall be based on general procurement principles contained in this article or otherwise allowed by law. 
(c)  The city may participate in or purchase goods and services through contracts awarded by other governmental or regional bodies, such as the council of governments, when it is determined by the purchasing agent that such use is in the best interest of the city and the contract is based on competitive principles. 
(Code 1982, § 10-11; Ord. No. 1524, 9-26-1995; Ord. No. 1798, § 10-11, 11-27-2006) 
Secs. 16-91-16-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS FEES AND FUNDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-109-16-129. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COURTHOUSE MAINTENANCE AND SECURITY FUNDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Assessment for courthouse maintenance, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281; assessment for courthouse security personnel, Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120. 

Sec. 16-130. - Courthouse maintenance fund. 
(a)  The city clerk of the General District Court shall collect, as part of the fees taxed as costs in each civil action, criminal or traffic case and in addition to any other costs, a sum of $2.00. 
(b)  The collected fees shall be transferred to the treasurer, who shall record them as revenue collected under this section. 
(c)  The city council or its designee may use the revenue collected under this section for any purpose allowed by state law relating to the courthouse, including but not limited to the construction, renovation, or maintenance of the courthouse, jail, or any courthouse-related facility and the payment of increases in the cost of heating, cooling, and electricity. 
(Code 1982, § 1-15(a); Ord. No. 1326, 8-27-1990; Ord. No. 1411, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 1723, 7-22-2002; Ord. No. 1808, 6-25-2007) 
State Law reference- Assessment for courthouse maintenance, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281. 
Sec. 16-131. - Courthouse security fee and jail processing fee. 
(a)  The city clerk of the General District Court shall collect a fee of $10.00 as part of the cost of each criminal or traffic case in the district court in which the defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance. The collected fees shall be remitted to the treasurer, which fees shall be subject to appropriation by the city council for funding of courthouse security. 
(b)  The city clerk of the General District Court shall collect and remit to the treasurer of the city a processing fee of $25.00 on any individual admitted to jail following conviction of an offense that occurred within the city, which fee shall be used by the city sheriff's office to defray the cost of processing arrested persons. 
(Code 1982, § 1-15(b); Ord. No. 1326, 8-27-1990; Ord. No. 1411, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 1723, 7-22-2002; Ord. No. 1808, 6-25-2007) 
State Law reference- Assessment for courthouse security personnel, Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120. 
Secs. 16-132-16-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVE FUND FOR PERMANENT PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 16-161. - Established. 
    Pursuant to the Charter, § 6.21, there is hereby established a reserve fund for permanent public improvements into which the council may, from time to time, appropriate any portion of the general fund cash surplus not otherwise appropriated at the close of any fiscal year, and into which there shall be assigned that portion of the ad valorem tax on real estate and tangible personal property that shall be specified for permanent public improvements, and to which may be assigned such other funds as may be by law deemed proper. 
(Code 1973, § 9-2; Code 1982, § 10-2) 
Charter reference- Provision as to reserves for public improvements, § 6.21. 
Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[1]

State Law reference- Fire protection, Code of Virginia, § 27-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - CITY FIRE MARSHAL 

Sec. 18-1. - City fire marshal-Creation of office; appointments; powers and duties; compensation; term. 
    The office of city fire marshal is hereby established. The council may, upon recommendation of the city manager, appoint the city fire marshal, and assistant fire marshal(s). The term "fire marshal" as used in this chapter may include the local fire official and local arson investigator when appointed pursuant to this section. The fire marshal shall have such powers and duties as are prescribed by this chapter and as authorized by the Code of Virginia. The city fire marshal shall receive such annual salary as the city manager may allow. The city fire marshal shall not be appointed for a definite tenure, but shall continue contingent upon and subject to the personnel rules of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-2. - Oaths of office. 
    The city fire marshal and the assistant city fire marshal(s), before entering upon their duties, shall, respectively, take an oath, before any officer authorized to administer oaths, to faithfully discharge the duties of their respective offices. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-3. - Notification of fire department. 
    In any building, structure or premises subject to inspection under any provision of this chapter, when a fire or evidence of there having been a fire is discovered, even though it has apparently been extinguished, it shall be immediately reported to the local emergency communications center - 911. This shall be the duty of the owner, manager, or person in control (as defined herein) of such building, structure or premises at the time of discovery. This requirement shall not be construed to forbid or otherwise restrict the owner, manager, or person in control of said building, structure or premises from using all diligence necessary to extinguish such fire prior to the arrival of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-4. - Investigation of fires. 
    The city fire marshal shall investigate, or cause to be investigated, every fire or explosion occurring within the city that is of a suspicious nature or which involves the loss of life, causes injury to persons or causes destruction of or damage to property. Such investigation shall be made at the time of the fire or at a subsequent time, depending on the nature and circumstances of the fire. The city fire marshal shall also investigate, or cause to be investigated, the possession or manufacture of explosive devices, substances, and fire bombs within the city, attempts or threats to commit such offenses, and false alarms relating to such offenses or to fires or explosions. The city fire marshal shall take charge immediately of the physical evidence and, in order to preserve any physical evidence relating to the cause or origin of such fire or explosion, take means to prevent access by any person or persons to such building, structure or premises until such evidence has been properly processed. The City of Falls Church Police Department, upon request of the city fire marshal, shall assist in the investigation as needed. The results of any such investigation shall be forwarded by the fire marshal to the commonwealth's attorney for proper disposition. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-5. - Powers of arrest. 
(a)  The city fire marshal and the assistant city fire marshal(s), permitted under Code of Virginia, tit. 27 (1950, as amended), shall have the same police powers as a member of the City of Falls Church Police Department in the investigation and prosecution of all offenses involving fires, arson, fire bombings, bombings, attempts or threats to commit such offenses, false alarms relating to such offenses, possession and manufacture of explosive devices, substances, and fire bombs, the storage, use and transportation of hazardous materials and hazardous waste, environmental crimes, and any other offenses involving fire or fire safety or the calling, causing to dispatch, or summonsing of fire or rescue equipment without just cause, in violation of the Code of Virginia (1950, as amended) or the Code of the City of Falls Church, and other criminal or civil offenses arising out of, or incidental to the investigation of the enumerated offenses. 
(b)  The county fire marshal, assistant fire marshal(s) and authorized deputy fire marshal(s) or designee(s) shall have the authority to exercise all those powers described in Code of Virginia, §§ 27-34.2 and 27-34.2:1 (1950, as amended). 
(c)  The police powers granted in this section shall not be exercised by any fire marshal until such person has met the requirements of Code of Virginia, §§ 27-34.2 and 27-34.2:1 (1950, as amended) and has been designated by the city fire marshal to exercise such powers. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-6. - Summoning or dispatching the city fire marshal. 
    The fire department officer-in-charge of any fire or explosion within the City of Falls Church shall immediately summon or cause to be dispatched the city fire marshal to the scene to investigate the circumstances involved. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-7. - Effect of repeal of chapter; revival. 
    Neither the adoption of this chapter, nor the repeal hereby of the prior fire codes or ordinances shall in any manner affect the prosecution for violations of this chapter, which violations were committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of any permit, fees or penalty at the effective date due and unpaid under such ordinance, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such code relating to the collection of any such permit, fees or penalty or the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof required to be posted, filed or deposited pursuant to any ordinance, and all rights and obligations thereof appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. Any repeal of the fire prevention code shall not be construed as reviving such former ordinance, clause or provision, unless expressly provided therein. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-8. - Penalty and continuing violation. 
(a)  Any person, owner, firm, entity or corporation who violates any sections of this chapter, fails to comply with any provisions of the City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code or of the Virginia State-wide Fire Prevention Code, or violates or fails to comply with any order made thereunder, or who fails to comply with such an order within the time fixed therein, shall separately, for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a violation of this chapter and upon conviction, be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor in accordance with Virginia law, including by imprisonment for not more than 12 months and/or a fine of not more than $2,500.00. Each day that a violation continues after service of notice, as provided for in the Virginia State-wide Fire Prevention Code, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  The imposition of the criminal penalties herein prescribed, shall not preclude the city from enforcing any administrative remedies set forth elsewhere in this chapter or the Code of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, as amended or preclude the city from instituting appropriate civil action, including but not limited to injunction, to restrain, correct or otherwise abate a violation of this chapter. The suspension or revocation of any license, permit, certificate or other privilege conferred by the city shall not be regarded as a penalty. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-9. - Fines and costs. 
    The city fire marshal shall recover or impose fees and penalties for fire department response to the location of a false, faulty or nuisance alarm. As used herein, the term "false alarm" also means a faulty or nuisance alarm. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-10. - Authority to adopt, set, and modify fees by city council. 
    The city manager, in consultation with the city fire marshal, shall recommend and the city council shall adopt a schedule of fees to be paid for each application, permit, inspection/re-inspection, testing and other specified acts required by this chapter. Any fee authorized or referenced herein, other than fees for false alarm response, shall be established in this manner. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-11. - Unlawful or prohibited acts include causing, permitting, concealing. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act or omission is made unlawful or prohibited, it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-12. - Damage or injury to fire department vehicles, equipment or personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, deface, attempt, or conspire to damage or deface any fire department vehicle or equipment at anytime, or to injure, or attempt or conspire to injure any fire department personnel while such personnel are in performance of their departmental duties. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-13. - Unlawful boarding or tampering with fire department vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without proper authorization from the officer in charge of the vehicle, to attempt or to cling to, attach oneself to, climb upon or into, board or swing upon any fire department vehicle whether such vehicle is in motion or at rest, or to sound any warning device thereon, or to manipulate, tamper with, remove or destroy any lever, valve, switch, starting device, brake, pump or any equipment, protective clothing, tool or any part of such fire department vehicle and/or property. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-14. - Impersonation and solicitation by use of the City of Falls Church Fire Marshal name. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use a badge, uniform, or any other credentials so as to gain access to any building, marine vessel, vehicle or premises or to otherwise falsely identify himself as the fire marshal, code official, fire official, or fire code official or his/her designated representative. The use of the name of the City of Falls Church Fire Marshal for any purpose of solicitation or to imply that any solicited funds will be used for the City of Falls Church is prohibited and shall be subject to the penalties of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-15. - Unlawful to cross fire line. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cross or to remain within designated fire lines or barricades, which have been established to prevent public access to the scene of fires, wrecks, explosions, crimes and/or emergency situations where life, limb or property may be endangered. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 18-17. - City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code. 
    The regulations set forth herein shall be known as the City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code, and shall be herein referred to as such or as this code [chapter]. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-18. - Enforcement of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code and the City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code. 
    The City of Falls Church shall enforce the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code promulgated by the Board of Housing and Community Development of the Commonwealth of Virginia pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 27-98. The provisions of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code and the additional regulations to this code adopted by the city shall be enforced by the city fire marshal, and, under the authority of the city fire marshal, the assistant fire marshal(s). The city fire marshal and assistant fire marshals shall have all of the powers of the local fire official set forth in Code of Virginia, tit. 27, and all of the powers of the fire official and the enforcing agency set forth in the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code and the additional regulations to this code adopted by the city. In the absence of the city fire marshal, assistants, and/or mutual aide by another jurisdiction, concurrent authority is granted to the Fire Marshal of Arlington County under Code of Virginia, § 27-36 and is appointed with the powers and duties of an assistant fire marshal to investigate fires and to enforce the City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. No. 1856, 4-11-2011) 
Sec. 18-19. - Incorporation amendments, additions and deletions to the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code as City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code. 
(a)  The City of Falls Church shall enforce the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code promulgated by the Board of Housing and Community Development of the Commonwealth of Virginia pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 27-98 (1950, as amended). All future editions of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code as promulgated by the Virginia Board of Housing and Community Development are hereby automatically adopted and incorporated into this Code. 
(b)  The 2009 edition of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, referred to herein as such or as "SFPC" is hereby amended and changed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 27-97 in the following respects: 
SFPC.103.1.2. Appendices. The following revisions are made to this section. IFC Appendices A shall be deleted and replaced with Appendix A, Fire Watch. The following appendices are hereby incorporated herein as fully enforceable provisions of this code and relabeled as follows: 
Appendix A - Requirements For a Fire Watch 
Appendix B - Flow Requirements for Buildings ( IFC Appendix B) 
Appendix C - Fire Hydrant Locations and Distribution (IFC Appendix C) 
Appendix D - Fire Apparatus Access Roads (IFC Appendix D) 
Appendix E - Hazard Categories (IFC Appendix E) 
Appendix F - Hazard Ranking (IFC Appendix F) 
Appendix G - Cryogenic Fluids (IFC Appendix G) 
SFPC-106.3.2. Inspection by others. Add the following 106.3.2. 
The City Manager may designate such other persons through inter-jurisdictional agreements, to make fire safety inspections and/or surveys. Such persons shall use the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code and this code as the basis for such inspections. 
SFPC-106. Duties and powers of the fire official. After 106.7, add the following 106.8, 106.9, 106.9.1, 106.9.2, 106.9.3. 
SFPC-106.8. Cost recovery. Add Subsection as follows: 106.8 
Fees will be charged and collected from the proper individual(s) or entities by the City of Falls Church in order to defray the cost of code enforcement and appeals under the SFPC. The fees will be assessed for permits in Sections 107.2 and 108. In addition, fees shall be assessed for conducting inspections and reviewing third party fire protection systems test results, monitoring the removal of hazardous materials and storage containers, for responding to and/or inspecting false, faulty, or nuisance alarms, and other fire prevention services that provide safety against conditions hazardous to life or property as well as cost recovery from the owner or person in control for impound, towing, recovery and/or disposal as appropriate. All service fees established by the City Fire Marshal shall be first submitted to the City Council for approval. An amendment to this Ordinance is not required to change any fee, cost recovery, or permit. 
SFPC-106.9. Notification. Add Subsection as follows: 106.9 
The City Fire Marshal shall be notified of all incidents involving fire, explosion/s, misfires, and/or spills, leaks, discharges, or other releases of materials as described in SFPC Chapter 27. 
SFPC-106.9.1. Responsibility and Reports. Add Subsection as follows: 106.9.1 
It shall be the responsibility of the Fire Department officer-in-charge, or his/her designee, to file with their Fire Chief, in such form as he/she shall prescribe, a report of every fire, explosion, or incident to which fire department apparatus or equipment responds into the City of Falls Church. These reports shall be provided to the City Fire Marshal upon request. 
SFPC-106.9.2. Summonsing or dispatching the Fire Marshal. Add Subsection as follows: 106.9.2 
The fire department officer-in-charge of any fire or explosion within the City of Falls Church shall immediately summon or cause to be dispatched the City Fire Marshal to the scene to investigate the circumstances involved where such circumstances require investigation. 
SFPC-106.9.3. Notification of fire department. In any building, structure, or premises subject to inspection under any provision of this code, when a fire or evidence of there having been a fire is discovered, even though it has apparently been extinguished, it shall be immediately reported to the City of Falls Church Emergency Communications Center. This shall be the duty of the owner, manager, or person in control (as defined herein) of such building, structure, or premises at the time of discovery. This requirement shall not be construed to forbid or otherwise restrict the owner, manager, or person in control of said building, structure, or premises from using all diligence necessary to extinguish such fire prior to the arrival of the Fire Department. 
SFPC-107.2.1. Permit classes. Add Subsection as follows: 107.2.1. 
Permits classes required by this code or by the SFPC shall be set forth in Table 107.2. No permit required by this code shall be valid until the prescribed fee, as approved from time to time by the City Council of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, has been paid to the Treasurer, of City of Falls Church, Virginia. 
Table 107.2. Fire Prevention Code Permit Requirement. Refer to City of Falls Church Code, Chapter 15, Article IV. Fees for each of the categories listed therein shall be established pursuant to Sec. 18-10 of the City code. 
SFPC-107.4.1 Duration of permit. Add Subsection as follows: 107.4.1 
SFPC-107.4.1 Duration of permit. Duration of permit. Permits shall remain in effect for 12 months from the date issued unless otherwise specified by Table 107.2 or unless suspended or revoked in accordance with the code. 
SFPC-108.3.8. Certificate of Occupancy. Add Subsection as follows: 108.3.8 
SFPC-108.3.8. Certificate of Occupancy. An operational permit shall be contingent on a valid certificate of occupancy and/or use permit issued by the City of Falls Church Building Official and/or the Zoning Administrator. 
SFPC-108.4. (6) Revocation. Delete and substitute as follows: 
SFPC-108.4. (6) Revocation. 6. The permitee failed, refused or neglected to comply with orders or notices duly served in accordance with the provisions of this code or any other code or City ordinance within the time provided herein. 
SFPC-108.4. Revocation. Add to the end of the Subsection as follows: 
SFPC-108.4. Revocation. 8. The certificate of occupancy and/or use permit has been revoked or suspended. 9. The building has been deemed unsafe, uninhabitable, or presents a hazardous condition to occupants. 
SFPC - 109. Inspection. Add the following 109.4, 109.5. 
SFPC - 109.4. Approvals. Add Subsection as follows: 109.4. 
Approvals made as the result of an inspection shall not be construed to be an approval or ratification of a violation of the provisions of this code or of any other City or state ordinances, laws, or regulations. Inspections or permits by any other entity or department presuming to give authority to violate, modify, or cancel provisions of this code shall not be valid and are void. Any modification to this code must be by written variance or modification issued by the City Fire Marshal. 
SFPC-109.5. Follow-up inspection/s from noncompliance. Add Subsection as follows: 109.5. 
Where follow-up inspections are required as a result of noncompliance with this Code, fees shall be assessed as listed under Table 107.2 and paid in full. 
SFPC-109.6 Inspections performed outside business hours. Add Subsection as follows: 109.6. 
Inspections performed outside business hours. Inspections may be performed outside business hours at the sole discretion of the fire official. Fees for these inspections shall be assessed at twice the rate listed under Table 107.2. Fees shall be assessed in 30 minute increments. 
SFPC-110.2.1. Maintenance; Responsibility. Add Subsection as follows: 110.2.1. 
A person, firm, owner, person in control (as defined herein) or corporation in charge of or responsible for any building, structure, premises, vehicle, device, other property, substance, material, gas, liquid, chemical, or condition, place, material, or substance regulated either by this code or by an ordinance under the Fire Marshal's jurisdiction shall be responsible for compliance with all such code and ordinance provisions and regulations relating thereto. 
SFPC-110.5.1. Evacuation; Imminent threat to human health or safety or to property. Add Subsection as follows: 110.5.1. 
If the fire official determines, in his/her professional judgment, that a violation/s creates an imminent threat to human health or safety or to property, the fire official may cause to restrain, correct, or abate such violation and institute appropriate legal proceeding to collect the full cost of such response from the owner, the tenant, or other person in control (as defined herein) of the premises. 
SFPC-112.1. Local Board of Fire Prevention Code Appeals (BFPCA). Delete and substitute as follows: 

SFPC-112.1. Local Board of Fire Prevention Code Appeals (BFPCA). Any person or entity cited for violation, when aggrieved by a decision or interpretation by the Fire Marshal made under the provisions of either the City of Falls Church Fire Prevention Code or the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, may appeal to the local board of appeals upon the grounds and in the manner set forth in the SFPC. The City of Falls Church Local Board of Building Code Appeals (BBCA) will serve under this provision and be established as the Local Board of Building and Fire Prevention Code Appeals (BBFPCA). An appeal case decided by the Local Board shall be final unless appealed to the State Building Code Technical Review Board (TRB). 
SFPC-301.2. Permits. Delete and substitute as follows. 
Permits shall be required as set forth in Section 107.2 for the activities or uses regulated by Sections 303.10, 307.2, 308.2, and 315. 
SFPC-303.10. Permit required. Add the following 303.10 
SFPC-303.10. Permit required. Prior to the use of an asphalt (tar) kettle to install or repair a portion of a structure, a permit shall be secured from the code official. A permit shall be obtained from the fire code official in accordance with Section 107.2 prior to the commencement of work. 
SFPC-307.1. General. Add the following 307.1.2. 
SFPC-307.1.2. Burning of leaves and yard waste. The open burning of leaves and yard waste is prohibited. 
SFPC-307.2. Permit required. This section and 307.2.1 are incorporated in full with the following revision. 
SFPC-307.2. Permit required. A permit is required for bonfires or other controlled burning approved by the code official. This permit requirement does not apply to recreational fires used solely for the cooking of food for human consumption. A permit shall be obtained from the fire code official in accordance with Section 107.2 prior to kindling a fire for recognized silvicultural, range or wildlife management practices, prevention or control of disease or pests, or a bonfire. Application for such approval shall only be made by, and permits issued to, the owner of the land upon which the fire is to be kindled. 
SFPC-307.4.2. Recreational fires. Add the following 307.4.2.1. 
SFPC-307.4.2.1. Allowable fuels. Only seasoned dry firewood or similar clean burning materials shall be permitted as fuel for outdoor warming fires, and recreational fires. Land clearing waste, leaves, yard waste, rubbish, or refuse shall not be used as fuel. 
SFPC-307.5. Attendance. Add the following 307.5.1. 
SFPC-307.5.1. Endangering other persons or property. No person shall kindle, authorize to be kindled or maintain any permitted fire in such a manner that could endanger the person or property of another. 
SFPC-307. Open burning, recreational fires and outdoor warming fires. After 307.5, add the following 307.6. 
SFPC-307.6. Prohibited conduct. Any person who carelessly or negligently sets fire to, burns, or causes to be burned any property, either real or personal, whether the property of himself or of another, shall be subject to the penalties of this code. 
SFPC-308.1.4. Open-flame cooking devices. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-308.1.4. Open-flame cooking devices. Charcoal burners and other open-flame cooking devices shall not be operated on combustible balconies, rooftops, decks of any building or within fifteen (15) feet of combustible construction. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Detached one- and two-family dwellings. 
2.  Where balconies and decks are protected by an automatic sprinkler system. 
3.  LP-gas cooking devices having LP-gas container with a water capacity not greater than 2 1/2 pounds [nominal 1 pound (0.454kg) LP-gas capacity]. 
SFPC-308.1.4.1. Open-flame cooking devices. Add the following 308.1.4.1. 
SFPC-308.1.4.1Notification of tenants. The person in control or management agent of multi-family residential occupancies which have balconies, patios, balconies, terraces, and/ or decks shall notify their tenants in writing of the prohibitions outlined in Section 308.1.4 this code when the tenant or occupant initially occupies the building, renews a lease, and periodically thereafter as may be necessary to ensure compliance. 
SFPC-316.3.1 Obstacles. Add the following 316.3.1. 
SFPC-316.3.1 Obstacles. No accumulation or concentration of materials or objects shall be placed and/or located inside a structure, dwelling or unit in such a manner or circumstance that, in the professional opinion of the fire official, an obstacle or hindrance to fire and emergency personnel or to fire fighting and/or EMS operations is created. 
SFPC-401. General. After 401.8 add the following 401.9 
SFPC-401.9. Posting of signage and instructions. The owner, lessee, or management agent of buildings shall post signs where, in the professional judgment of the fire official, such signs are deemed to be effective in minimizing the danger to persons and property in case of fire and fostering to the effective response of emergency personnel. 
SFPC-402.1 Definition. Add the following words, terms, and meanings. 
HIGH-RISE - Buildings with one (1) or more occupied floor/s located seventy-five (75) feet or more above the lowest level of fire department access. 
SPECIAL EVENT - An event in the community that is focused on a specific purpose such as a street fair, celebration, grand opening, or other significant occasion. 
SFPC-403.1.2. Permit required. Add the following 403.1.2 
SFPC-403.1.2. Permit required. A permit shall be required for all events, both indoor and outdoor, that in the professional judgment of the code official requires inspection by the Fire Marshal to ensure that all fire and life safety concerns are met. A permit shall be obtained from the fire code official in accordance with Section 107.2 prior to the event. 
SFPC-501.2. Permits. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-501.2. Permits. A permit shall be required as set forth in Sections 107.2 and 108. 
SFPC-503.2.1. Dimensions. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-503.2.1. Dimensions. Fire apparatus access roads shall have an unobstructed width of not less than 20 feet (6096 mm), exclusive of shoulders, except for approved gates in accordance with Section 503.6, and an unobstructed vertical clearance of not less than 15 feet. 
SFPC-503.3.1 Marking Specifications. Add the following 503.3.1. 
SFPC-503.3.1 Marking Specifications. The property owner or designee shall supply and install signs and other required markings to delineate fire lanes as directed by the code official. These signs and markings shall be installed and maintained by the owner in a manner approved by the code official. 
Fire lanes shall conform to the following specifications: 
1.  Approved fire lane signs must meet the following specifications: 
(a)  Metal construction, dimensions twelve (12) inches wide by fifteen (18) inches high. 
(b)  Red letters on a reflective white background with three-eighths (3/8) inch red trim strip around the entire outer edge of the sign. 
(c)  Wording and lettering size as follows, spacing between words to be uniform: 
NO PARKING [two (2) inches, capitalized] OR [one (1) inch, capitalized] STANDING [two (2) inches, capitalized] "FIRE LANE" [two and a half (2 1/2) inches, capitalized] ? ? [arrows as appropriate in one (1) inch thick graphic depiction]  
(d)  Other signs or markings as approved by the fire official. 
2.  Signs shall be posted at intervals and at a height above the finished grade as directed by the fire official. 
3.  Curbing shall be painted and maintained as solid yellow within the limits of the fire lane. 
4.  Signs and markings shall be maintained in accordance with Section 503.3. 
SFPC-503.3.2. Location. Add the following 503.3.2. 
SFPC-503.3.2. Location. Signs or markings shall be placed as follows: 
1.  Where fire lanes run through parking areas where there is no adjacent curbing and posting of an approved metal sign is not practical, "NO PARKING FIRE LANE" may be required to be painted on the pavement in letters at least two (2) feet high. 
2.  Signs shall be posted at intervals of seventy-five (75) feet with the bottom of the sign no less than seven (7) feet from the ground unless otherwise directed by the code official. The signs shall be installed so that the front of the sign is at an angle of thirty (30) to forty-five (45) degrees to the curb, facing toward the direction from which traffic would normally be approaching. 
3.  All curbs or paved spaces designated as fire lanes shall be indicated by yellow (highway grade) paint as approved by the fire code official. In areas without curbing, a 6 inch wide yellow stripe shall be applied to the edge of the pavement. The property owner or designee shall repaint whenever the paint begins to fade or when directed by the fire code official. 
SFPC-503.6. Security Gates. Delete and substitute first sentence only. 
SFPC-503.6. Security Gates. The installation of security gates across a fire apparatus access road shall be approved by the fire code official. 
SFPC-503.7.1. Existing signs. Add the following 503.7.1. 
SFPC-503.7.1. Existing signs. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, remove, destroy or impair the usefulness of any posted fire lane sign installed under the provisions of this code without the permission of the fire official. 
SFPC-504.2.1. Labeling of Required Fire Exits. Add the following 504.2.1. 
SFPC-504.2.1. Labeling of Required Fire Exits. All exterior fire exits which, in the opinion of the fire official, are subject to blocking from the exterior shall be labeled with (4) inch letters and contrasting background "FIRE EXIT - DO NOT BLOCK." In situations in which the exit serves a specific identified stairway, the stairway shall also be identified with labeling on the associated exterior door. 
SFPC-505.1. Address numbers. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-505.1. Address numbers. Every owner of a dwelling unit or building shall display the City assigned street address identification on each front entrance to the dwelling unit or building. These numbers shall be in Arabic numerals or Roman alphabet letters. Numbers or letters shall be a minimum of four (4) inches (102 mm) high with a minimum stroke with of 0.5 inches mm). The assigned street address identification shall be displayed in a manner so as to be visible and distinguishable from the curb line or pavement edge of the opposite side of the street on which the dwelling unit or building is located. If a dwelling unit or building is located on a parcel of land whose street frontage is at the end of a street such that there is no opposite side of the street, the street address identification number shall be clearly visible and distinguishable from a distance of thirty (30) feet into the street from the curb line or pavement edge of the street adjacent to the property line on which the dwelling unit or building is situated. In the event the location of the dwelling unit or building or other factors preclude compliance with the above requirements, an additional address identification number shall be displayed on, or in the vicinity of, the dwelling unit or building in such a manner as to be visible and distinguishable as provided above. Every exterior rear and side door of a structure containing (2) or more occupancies, such as a strip shopping center, shall have same address requirements as the front of the structure. Street address identification shall be maintained in a clean and plainly legible condition at all times and replaced or repaired when necessary to ensure clear visibility. Vegetation or ornamentation shall not obscure the street address identification. 
SFPC-506.1. Where required. Add the following sentence. 
SFPC-506.1. Where required. ...New installations of key boxes shall be with an attached hinged lid only. Secondary locations may be required by the fire official based upon the size of the structure and response needs. 
SFPC-506.1.2. Key Box Content Requirements. Add the following 506.1.2. 
SFPC-506.1.2. Key Box Content Requirements. In buildings with fire command centers, the person in control shall provide fifteen (15) sets of common keys, which shall be located in a key box in the fire control room. The keys are required for access to building services and systems regulated by Section 601 of this code; and to all storage, trash, and mechanical, electrical rooms, roof access doors, and doors to other secured areas. In all other buildings without fire command centers, the person in control shall provide up to eight (8) sets of keys to be located in a key box. The eight sets of keys, which shall be placed in an interior location of the building as approved by the fire official. Individual keys shall be clearly labeled as to function and each set of keys shall be individually tagged in a manner approved by the fire official. The number of sets of keys will be determined by the fire official.

SFPC-508.2. Procedure Manual and Contact List. All buildings equipped with a fire command center shall contain an Operations Procedure Manual. The contents of the manual shall be approved by the fire official. The manual shall be placed in the fire command center in a manner and location approved by the fire official. The owner or person in control shall maintain the manual and update it whenever necessary. This includes an Emergency Contact List of persons responsible to maintain systems on a 24/7 basis.

SFPC-901.6.3. Periodic retests. Periodic inspections and tests of all fire protection systems shall be tested in accordance with the respective NFPA standards and other codes as required under this Chapter. The test may be witnessed by the fire official. The fire official may collect fees from the building owner or tenant for the witnessing of tests required under this section. 
SFPC-901.6.3.1. Testing and inspection/reinspection fees. Fees for witnessing the testing and for inspection/reinspection of existing fire protection equipment and systems shall be assessed. Fees shall be based on the hours reserved by the Fire Marshal to perform the inspection/reinspection, witnessing third party tests and/or reviewing third party test results. The Fire Marshal must be notified of a cancellation of a scheduled inspection/reinspection or site visit. 
SFPC-901.6.4. Notification. The code official or his/her designee shall be notified before any routine test, repair, alteration or change to any fire protection system, regardless of whether such system is required by the building code, this code or other law or ordinance.

SFPC-907.2.9.3 Responsibilities of owner, agent or tenants for smoke alarms. The owner or management agent of a dwelling unit which is rented or leased in a residential building containing one (1) or more dwelling units, shall furnish the tenant at the beginning of each tenancy, at each renewal or extension of a tenancy or at least annually, with written certification that all smoke alarms required are present, have been inspected and are operational and in good working order. The person in control shall be responsible for interim testing, maintenance and reasonable care of the smoke detector, including installation of batteries if required. In accordance with Section 55-248.16 of the Code of Virginia (1950, as amended), the owner or management agent shall repair any inoperative or malfunctioning smoke detector. Such service, repair or replacement and/or restoration of the detector to normal operative condition shall occur immediately upon receipt of written notice from a tenant or others that a smoke detector is in need of repair, inoperative or otherwise not properly functioning.

SFPC-907.9.6. False, faulty or nuisance alarms. Whenever false, faulty, or nuisance fire alarm activations occur in any occupancy and exceed three (3) activations in a (90) day period, the fire official may require the owner or occupant to conduct a witnessed test of the fire protection system causing the false, faulty, or nuisance alarm; testing shall be in accordance with 901.6.

There shall be no overcrowding.

SFPC-2705.5. Hazardous materials transportation. Add the following 2705.5. 
SFPC-2705.5. Hazardous materials transportation. Hazardous materials transportation vehicles operating or housed within the City of Falls Church shall be maintained in accordance with the federal regulations contained in 49 Code of Federal Regulations (49 CFR) and the Code of Virginia (1950, as amended). Any duly sworn law enforcement officer of Virginia, including the Fire Marshal, may halt any hazardous materials transportation vehicle that is observed to have a condition or characteristic that suggests, in the professional judgment of the officer or code official, that there exists a violation of City, state, or federal regulations governing the transportation of hazardous materials. The vehicle may be detained long enough to determine if the permits required for transporting hazardous materials have been obtained, if the cargo is secure, and if the observed condition, or characteristic, presents an immediate threat of a transportation related spill and/or a catastrophic event. The hazardous materials transportation vehicle may resume operation if it is found to be in good repair and free of leaks, in accordance with the SFPC and its referenced standards. If that finding is not made, the vehicle shall be detained until the proper repairs or adjustments are made where it is situated, or it is removed to a safe location, as determined by the code official, and repaired or adjusted, whichever is appropriate. Upon refusal of the operator or owner of the vehicle to make the repairs or adjustments required by the code official, the vehicle shall be impounded by the code official until all necessary repairs are made and all accrued impound and towing fees are remitted by the owner to the Treasurer, City of Falls Church. 
SFPC-2705.5.1. Portable fire extinguisher. Add the following 2705.5.1. 
SFPC-2705.5.1. Portable fire extinguisher. Any vehicle required to have a DOT HAZMAT placard shall be equipped with a portable fire extinguisher complying with Section 906 and having a minimum rating of 2-A:20-B:C. During the unloading of the tank vehicle, the portable fire extinguisher shall be out of the carrying device on the vehicle and shall be fifteen (15) feet or more from the unloading valves.

SFPC-3301.1.3 Fireworks. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-3301.1.3 Fireworks. The possession, manufacture, storage, sale, handling, display, and use of fireworks within the City of Falls Church is prohibited. The fire official or designee shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed at the expense of the owner, all fireworks offered for sale, stored or held in violation of this code. 
Exception: For public and private displays as permitted by the fire official where a permit is obtained prior to any display in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
SFPC-3301.2 Permits Required. Delete and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-3301.2 Permits Required. Permits shall be obtained from the Code Official in accordance with Table 107.2 for all blasting operations, firework aerial displays, pyrotechnic events before an audience, the transportation, manufacture, possession, use, storage of explosives and fireworks and the operation of a terminal for handling explosive material and the delivery to or receipt from a carrier at a terminal between sunset and sunrise. An application for the display of aerial fireworks shall be completed and submitted to the fire official 45 days before the scheduled event. The application for aerial fireworks display shall include the following: 
1)  A copy of insurance policy with the City of Falls Church named as a co-insured. 
2)  A site plan with the layout of the discharge site, spectator site, viewing area, parking area, fallout area and distances for each; distances to all tents, buildings and structures. 
3)  Provide a complete list of aerial fireworks to be displayed. 
4)  Provide type and amount of fire protection. 
5)  The type of physical barrier that will be installed around display site and number of monitors that will be used during performance. 
6)  Identify the type of security and number of monitors that will be on-site during the display. 
7)  Provide the shooter/operator's name, address, social security number, and date of birth. 
8)  Provide fireworks display company address and emergency contact numbers. 
9)  Provide emergency contact information including the owner of the property name and number, third shooter/operator (within one hour of travel), and hazardous material transport company responsible for transportation and security. 
10)  Method of storage and location that display fireworks are to be stored. 
11)  Provide copy of certification as a Certified Blaster/Pyrotechnician approved by the Commonwealth of Virginia State Fire Marshal's Office. 
3301.2.2 Sale and Retail Display. Delete and substitute as follows. 
3301.2.2 Sale and Retail Display. The sale and retail display of fireworks, explosives or any explosive materials is prohibited within the City of Falls Church. 
SFPC-3301.2.4. Financial responsibility. Delete, rename, and substitute as follows. 
SFPC-3301.2.4. Financial responsibility. Before a permit is issued for the storage, transportation, disposal, or use of explosives, blasting agents or fireworks, the applicant shall file with the fire official a certificate of insurance which shows that the applicant has liability insurance in the amount of at least five million ($5,000,000) dollars combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage. The certificate of insurance shall show the City of Falls Church as a co-insured on the policy. This insurance policy shall be available for the payment of any damage arising from the acts or omissions of the applicant, his agents, or his employees in connection with the storage, transportation, disposal, or use of explosives or blasting agents. The applicant shall ensure that the insurance policy is in effect at the time of the commencement of the operations or activities authorized by the permit, and remains continuously in effect until such operations or activities are completed. 
SFPC-3302.1. Definitions. Add the following words, terms, and meanings. 
APPROVED - Approved by the City Fire Official. 
BLASTING - The process of moving, heaving, breaking, or shattering soils or rocks, or doing other work such as the demolition of structures or research and testing that generates seismic waves through the use of energetic materials in chemical reactions, explosions, or other detonations or deflagrations. 
FLYROCK - Any dirt, mud, stone, fragmented rock, or other material that is displaced from the blast area in an uncontrolled or unplanned manner by the effects of a blast. 
SFPC-3303.2.1. Transaction Record. Add the following 3303.2.1. 
SFPC-3303.2.1. Transaction Record. Daily records shall be kept of the amount of explosives received from a supplier and the amount delivered to the magazine. A daily record shall be kept of the amount of explosives removed from the magazine for daily use and the amount returned to the magazine. This record will be kept within the magazine so that, on inspection of the magazine, an inventory for all explosives can be made. The inventory shall be separated as to the different types of explosives stored and used. Forms for these records shall be approved by the fire official. 
SFPC-3304.5.2.3 Type 2 magazines. Add the following 3304.5.2.3. 
SFPC-3304.5.2.3 Type 2 magazines. Type 2 magazines may be used for temporary storage of explosives at the site of blasting operations where the amount constitutes not more than one day's supply for use is current operations. All explosives not used in the day's operation shall be returned to a Type 1 magazine at the end of the work day for overnight storage. In no case shall a Type 2 magazine be used for overnight storage unless approved by the Fire official. Type 2 magazines shall be allowed only in the I/Industrial Zone. 
SFPC-3307.3.1. Pre-blast surveys. Add the following 3307.3.1. 
SFPC-3307.3.1. Pre-blast surveys. A pre-blast survey shall be performed on each structure located within a minimum of one hundred and fifty (150) feet and any well located within a minimum of two hundred and fifty (250) feet of the blast site. Written confirmation that the pre-blast survey has been done shall be maintained by the blasting contractor. Requests for access to structures for pre-blast surveys shall be made by certified mail to the last known address of the owner(s) of any structures located within the pre-blast survey areas as defined herein. If permitted by the owner(s), said pre-blast surveys shall be conducted to determine the pre-blast conditions of these structures. A minimum of 14 days notice shall be provided for the scheduling of the pre-blast survey. Documentation consisting of a written acknowledgement that the survey has been performed or declined by the property owner and a map depicting the above referenced 150 and 250 feet radius, shall be provided to the Fire Official at the time of the Explosive Use Site Permit Inspection meeting. 
SFPC-3307.3.2. Pre-blast notification. Add the following 3307.3.2. 
SFPC-3307.3.2. Pre-blast notification. Pre-blast notification. Add Subsection as follows: 3307.3.2 Pre-blast notification. All structures located within a minimum of 300 feet of the blast site shall be notified of the scheduled blasting 10 days prior to blasting and no blasting shall occur until such notice has been given. 
SFPC-3308.11. Retail display and sale. Add the following 3308.11. 
SFPC-3308.11. Retail display and sale. The retail display or sale of fireworks is prohibited. 
SFPC-3308.12. Seizure and destruction of certain fireworks. Add the following 3308.12. 
SFPC-3308.12. Seizure and destruction of certain fireworks. Any Fire Marshal or law enforcement officer encountering fireworks in violation of this code may seize such fireworks and may hold such until final disposition of any criminal procedures related to the violation. If any person is judgment of conviction be entered against such person for violations of this code, then the court shall order destruction of such articles upon expiration of the time allowed for appeal for such conviction. 
SFPC-3308.12.1. Destruction of other seized fireworks. Add the following 3308.12.1. 
SFPC-3308.12.1. Destruction of other seized fireworks. Where no criminal proceedings can be instituted due to lack of knowledge as to who owns or is responsible for the fireworks, the fireworks in question shall be destroyed after thirty (30) days.
