No employee of any person or legal entity operating a theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place which presents such obscene exhibition or performance shall be subject to prosecution under this section if the employee is not the manager of the theatre or an officer of such entity, and has no financial interest in such theatre other than receiving salary and wages; or 
(2)  Own, lease or manage any theater, garden, building, structure, room or place and lease, let, lend or permit such theater, garden, building, structure, room or place to be used for the purpose of presenting such obscene exhibition or performance or to fail to post prominently therein the name and address of a person resident in the locality who is the manager of such theatre, garden, building, structure, room or place. 
(Code 1973, § 24-35; Code 1982, § 22-37; Ord. No. 948) 
Charter reference- Provision authorizing city to prevent lewd exhibitions, § 2.04(a). 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-375. 
Sec. 28-121. - Providing models and facilities for indecent purposes prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any establishment to operate a business of providing models or facilities for lewd and indecent sketching, painting or photographing of the human figure where either: 
(1)  The model postures; or 
(2)  The model is reproduced by sketches, painting or photographs; 
in a manner which appeals to prurient interests, is utterly without socially redeeming quality or character and patently offends contemporary community standards. Educational institutions, museums and art galleries are not within the purview of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 24-36; Code 1982, § 22-38; Ord. No. 948) 
Sec. 28-122. - Indecent exposure. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally make an obscene display or exposure of his person, or the private parts thereof, in any public place or in any place where others are present, or to procure another to so expose self. Violation of the provisions of this section, upon conviction, shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. No person shall be deemed to be in violation of this section for breastfeeding a child in any public place or any place where others are present. 
(Code 1982, § 22-39; Ord. No. 948) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-387. 
Sec. 28-123. - Public nudity in places of commercial entertainment. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    State of nudity means a state of undress so as to expose the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, or the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering or any portion thereof below the top of the areola. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. Every person who knowingly, voluntarily and intentionally appears in public or in a public place or in a place open to the public or open to public view in a state of nudity, or employs, encourages or procures another person to so appear, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Applicability. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to apply to the exhibition, presentation, showing or performance of any play, ballet, drama, tableau, production or motion picture in any theater, concert hall, museum of fine arts, school, institution of higher learning or other similar establishment which is primarily devoted to such exhibitions, presentations, shows or performances as a form of expression of opinion, communication, speech, ideas, information, art or drama; as differentiated from commercial or business advertising, promotion or exploitation of nudity for the purpose of advertising, promoting, selling or serving products or services or otherwise advancing the economic welfare of a commercial or business enterprise such as a hotel, motel, bar, nightclub, restaurant, tavern or dancehall. No person shall be deemed to be in violation of this section for breastfeeding a child in any public place or any place where others are present. 
(Code 1982, § 22-40; Ord. No. 748) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Obscene exhibitions and performances, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-375. 
Sec. 28-124. - Display of sexually explicit material. 
(a)  Restricted. No person shall display at a newsstand, newsrack or in a business establishment which is open to persons under the age of 18 years, any publication which exposes to public view any photograph, picture, painting, drawing or other pictorial representation which depicts less than completely and opaquely covered the human genitals, buttocks or that portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, or which depicts the human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, whether covered or uncovered; other than of a child under the age of puberty. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means any corporation or other legal entity which owns or leases the business premises as well as the managing agent of such business establishment on duty on the premises at the time of the offense. 
(c)  Violation. A person violating this section is guilty of a separate offense for each day or portion of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted and each offense is punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(d)  Applicability. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to apply to the exhibition, presentation, showing or performance of any play, ballet, drama, tableau, production, motion picture, painting or sculpture in any theater, concert hall, museum of fine arts, school, institution of higher learning and/or other similar establishment which is primarily devoted to such exhibitions, presentations, shows or performances as a form of expression of opinion, communication, speech, ideas, information, art or drama; as differentiated from commercial or business advertising, promotion or exploitation of nudity for the purpose of advertising, promoting, selling or serving products or services for otherwise advancing the economic welfare of a commercial or business enterprise such as a hotel, motel, bar, nightclub, restaurant, tavern or dancehall. 
(Code 1982, § 22-41; Ord. No. 767) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Secs. 28-125-28-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PEACE AND GOOD ORDER 

Sec. 28-147. - Public drunkenness prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to be drunk in public, which offense, upon conviction, shall be punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. In any area in which there is located a court-approved detoxification center, a law enforcement officer may authorize the transportation, by police or otherwise, of public inebriates to such detoxification center in lieu of arrest; however, no person shall be involuntarily detained in such center. 
(Code 1973, § 24-39; Code 1982, § 22-42; Ord. No. 948) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-388. 
Sec. 28-148. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person with the intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, to: 
(1)  In any street, highway, public building, or while in or on a public conveyance or public place, engage in conduct having a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person at whom, individually, such conduct is directed. Such conduct shall not be deemed to include the utterance or display of any words or to include conduct otherwise made punishable under this chapter; 
(2)  Willfully or being intoxicated, whether willfully or not, disrupt any meeting of the governing body of the city or a division or agency thereof, or of any school, literary society or place of religious worship, if such disruption prevents or interferes with the orderly conduct of such meeting or has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person at whom, individually, such disruption is directed. Such conduct shall not be deemed to include the utterance or display of any words or to include conduct otherwise made punishable under this chapter; or 
(3)  Willfully or while intoxicated, whether willfully or not, and whether such intoxication results from self-administered alcohol or other drug of whatever nature, disrupt the operation of any school or any activity conducted or sponsored by any school, if the disruption: 
a.  Prevents or interferes with the orderly conduct of the operation or activity; or 
b.  Has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person at whom, individually, the disruption is directed. 
The conduct prohibited under this subsection shall not be deemed to include the utterance or display of any words or to include conduct otherwise made punishable under this chapter. 
(b)  The person in charge of any such building, place conveyance or meeting may eject any person who violates any provision of this section, with the aid, if necessary, of any persons who may be called upon for such purpose. 
(c)  Violation of any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction, shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-40; Code 1982, § 22-43; Ord. No. 948) 
Charter reference- Provision authorizing city to prevent disorderly conduct, § 2.04(a). 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-415. 
Sec. 28-149. - Abusive language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, in the presence or hearing of another, to curse or abuse such other person or to use any violent abusive language to such person concerning himself or any of his relations, or otherwise use such language under circumstances reasonably calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, which offense, upon conviction, shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-41; Code 1982, § 22-44; Ord. No. 948) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-416. 
Sec. 28-150. - Carrying concealed weapons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry about his person, hidden from common observation, any pistol or any other firearm or weapon designed or intended to propel a missile of any kind, dirk, bowie knife, switchblade knife, ballistic knife, machete, razor, slingshot, spring stick, metal knucks, or blackjack or any weapon of like kind, or nunchahka or any other similar flailing instrument consisting of two or more rigid parts connected in such a manner as to allow them to swing freely, which instrument may also be known as a nun chahka, nun chuck, nunchuck, or nunchaku, shuriken, or fighting chain or any weapon of like kind, any disc, of whatever configuration, having at least two points or pointed blades, which is designed to be thrown or propelled and which may be known as a throwing star or oriental dart; or any weapon of like kind. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, and such weapon shall, by order of the court, be forfeited to the city and may be seized by an officer as forfeited, and, such as may be needed for police officers and conservators of the peace, shall be devoted to that purpose. The remainder shall be destroyed by the officer having them in charge. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, a weapon shall be deemed to be hidden from common observation when it is observable but is of such deceptive appearance as to disguise the weapon's true nature. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any person while in his own place of abode or the curtilage thereof or to any police officer, sergeants, sheriffs or deputy sheriffs. Except as provided in Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308 J.1, this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any person while in that person's place of business; 
(2)  Any law enforcement officer, wherever such law enforcement officer may travel in the commonwealth; 
(3)  Any regularly enrolled member of a target shooting organization who is at, or going to or from, an established shooting range; provided that the weapons are unloaded and securely wrapped while being transported; 
(4)  Any regularly enrolled member of a weapons collecting organization who is at, or going to or from, a bona fide weapons exhibition; provided that the weapons are unloaded and securely wrapped while being transported; 
(5)  Any person carrying such weapons between place of abode of that person and a place of purchase or repair; provided the weapons are unloaded and securely wrapped while being transported; 
(6)  Any person actually engaged in lawful hunting, as authorized by the Board of Game and Inland Fisheries, under inclement weather conditions necessitating temporary protection of the firearm of that person from those conditions; provided that possession of a handgun while engaged in lawful hunting shall not be construed as hunting with a handgun, if the person hunting is carrying a valid concealed handgun permit; 
(7)  Any state police officer retired from the department of state police, any local law enforcement officer, auxiliary police officer or animal control officer retired from a police department or sheriff's office within the commonwealth, any special agent retired from the State Corporation Commission or the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, any conservation police officer retired from the Department of Game and Inland Fisheries, and any state marine police officer retired from the Law Enforcement Division of the Virginia Marine Resources Commission, other than an officer or agent terminated for cause: (i) with a service-related disability; (ii) following at least 15 years of service with any such law-enforcement agency, board or any combination thereof; or (iii) who has reached 55 years of age, provided such officer carries written proof of consultation with and favorable review of the need to carry a concealed handgun issued by the chief law enforcement officer of the last such agency from which the officer retired or, in the case of special agents, issued by the State Corporation Commission or the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. A copy of the proof of consultation and favorable review shall be forwarded by the chief or the board to the department of state police for entry into the state criminal information network. The chief law enforcement officer shall not, without cause, withhold such written proof if the retired law enforcement officer otherwise meets the requirements of this section. For purposes of applying the reciprocity provisions of Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308 P, any person granted the privilege to carry a concealed handgun, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308, while carrying the proof of consultation and favorable review required shall be deemed to have been issued a concealed handgun permit. For purposes of complying with the federal Law Enforcement Officers Safety Act of 2004, a retired law enforcement officer who receives proof of consultation and review, pursuant to this section, shall have the opportunity to annually participate, at the retired law enforcement officer's expense, in the same training and testing to carry firearms as is required of active law enforcement officers in the commonwealth. If such retired law enforcement officer meets the training and qualification standards, the chief law enforcement officer shall issue the retired officer certification, valid one year from the date of issuance, indicating that the retired officer has met the standards of the agency to carry a firearm; and 
(8)  Any state police officer who is a member of the organized reserve forces of any of the armed services of the United States, national guard, or naval militia, while such officer is called to active military duty, provided such officer carries with the written proof of consultation with and favorable review of the need to carry a concealed handgun issued by the superintendent of state police. The proof of consultation and favorable review shall be valid as long as the officer is on active military duty and shall expire when the officer returns to active law enforcement duty. The issuance of the proof of consultation and favorable review shall be entered into the Virginia Criminal Information Network. The superintendent of state police shall not without cause withhold such written proof if the officer is in good standing and is qualified to carry a weapon while on active law enforcement duty. For purposes of applying the reciprocity provisions of the Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308 P, any person granted the privilege to carry a concealed handgun, pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308, while carrying the proof of consultation and favorable review required shall be deemed to have been issued a concealed handgun permit. 
(e)  This section shall also not apply to any of the following individuals while in the discharge of their official duties, or while in transit to or from such duties: 
(1)  Carriers of the United States mail; 
(2)  Officers or guards of any state correctional institution; 
(3)  Conservators of the peace, except that the following conservators of the peace shall not be permitted to carry a concealed handgun without obtaining a permit as provided in subsection (d) of this section: 
a.  Notaries public; 
b.  Registrars; 
c.  Drivers, operators or other persons in charge of any motor vehicle carrier of passengers for hire; or 
d.  Commissioners in chancery; 
(4)  Noncustodial employees of the department of corrections designated to carry weapons by the director of the department of corrections, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 53.1-29; and 
(5)  Harbormaster of the City of Hopewell. 
This section not apply to any person who has obtained a permit in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308. 
(Code 1973, § 24-44; Code 1982, § 22-45; Ord. No. 948; Ord. No. 1487, 9-12-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308 A-C. 
Sec. 28-151. - Willfully discharging weapons in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully discharge or cause to be discharged any firearm, beanshooter, slingshot, bow or crossbow, air rifle, BB gun, spring gun or similar gun or device for the propulsion of shot or other metal pellet by means of compressed air, mechanical spring action or other mechanical method, in any public street or in any place of public business or place of public gathering. This section shall not apply to the discharge or shooting off of such firearm, beanshooter, slingshot, bow or crossbow, rifle, pistol or shotgun in or upon a range or course, or similar facility when such range or course or similar facility has been approved in writing by the chief of police or designee as presenting no danger to persons, or to the property of others; and provided, further, that this section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer in the performance of the official duties of such law enforcement officer, nor to any other person whose willful act is otherwise justifiable or excusable at law in the protection of the life or property of that person, or is otherwise specifically authorized by law. 
(Code 1973, § 24-45; Code 1982, § 22-46; Ord. No. 948) 
State Law reference- Willfully discharging firearms in public places, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-280. 
Sec. 28-152. - Begging on streets. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accosting means approaching or speaking to someone in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon his person, or upon property in the immediate possession of that person. 
    Ask, beg, or solicit means and includes, without limitation, the spoken, written or printed word or such other acts as are conducted in furtherance of the purpose of obtaining alms. 
    Forcing oneself upon the company of another means continuing to ask for, beg, or solicit alms from a person after that person has made a negative response, blocking the passage of the individual addressed or otherwise engaging in conduct which could reasonably be construed as intended to compel or force a person to accede to demands. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to go about begging by accosting another or by forcing oneself upon the company of another or to stay upon any sidewalk or street or other public place within the city obstructing pedestrian or vehicle passage and beg. 
(c)  A violation of this section is punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-27; Code 1982, § 22-47; Ord. No. 948) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Obstructing passage of others, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-404. 
Sec. 28-153. - False fire alarms. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to, without just cause, call or summon, by telephone or otherwise, any ambulance, or firefighting apparatus, or to maliciously activate a manual or automatic fire alarm in any building used for public assembly or for other public use, including but not limited to schools, theaters, stores, office buildings, shopping centers and malls, coliseums and arenas, regardless of whether fire apparatus responds or not, shall be deemed guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  A violation of this section may be prosecuted either in the jurisdiction from which the call or summons was made or in the jurisdiction where the call or summons was received. 
(Code 1973, § 24-48; Code 1982, § 22-48; Ord. No. 948) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-212. 
Sec. 28-154. - Interference with fire or police department equipment; police dogs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or in any manner injure any fire equipment, fire alarm, police signal or any part of any of them established or installed within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tease, taunt, torment, strike, kick, mutilate, or to interfere or meddle with any dog while such animal is being utilized by the police department, or any officer or employee in the performance of any function or duty of said department, or of such officer or employee. 
(Code 1973, § 24-51; Code 1982, § 22-49; Ord. No. 948; Ord. No. 1343, 2-11-1991) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, ch. 18; police, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Injuring or killing police animals, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-144.1. 
Sec. 28-155. - Debris, etc., in streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited upon any highway any glass bottle, glass, nail, tack, wire, can, or any other substance likely to injure any person or animal, or damage any vehicle upon such highway; nor shall any person throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited upon any highway any soil, sand, mud, gravel or other substances so as to create a hazard to the traveling public. Any person who drops or throws, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any highway any destructive, hazardous or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the highway from such vehicle. This subsection shall not apply to the use, by a law enforcement officer while in the discharge of official duties, of any device designed to deflate tires. The division of purchase and supply shall, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 2.2-1112, set minimum standards for such devices and shall give notice of such standards to law enforcement offices in the commonwealth. No such device shall be used which does not meet or exceed the standards. 
(2)  Dump or otherwise dispose of trash, garbage or other unsightly matter on the street or on private property without the written consent of the owner; except that garbage and rubbish may be placed along the curbline for collection. 
(3)  Operate upon the streets any vehicle hauling any material so loaded as to spill, drop, sift or leak any such material upon the streets; provided, however, that sand or any substance for increasing traction during times of snow and ice may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction. 
(b)  Any persons violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-55; Code 1982, § 22-50; Ord. No. 948) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-324. 
Sec. 28-156. - Games in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any game in which a ball or other object is thrown with the hands or kicked with the feet or propelled by any stick, cane, bat or other means, in such a manner as to impede or obstruct vehicular traffic, in any street of the city. No person shall play on a highway, other than on the sidewalks, within the city or on any part of a highway outside the limits of a city or town designated by the commonwealth transportation commissioner exclusively for vehicular travel. No person shall use any toy vehicle on the roadway of any highway that: 
(1)  Has a speed limit greater than 25 miles per hour; 
(2)  Has more than two travel lanes; or 
(3)  Is located outside a residence district as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100. 
The city council may designate areas on highways under their control where play is permitted and may impose reasonable restrictions on play on such highways. Persons using such devices, except bicycles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, electric power-assisted bicycles, mopeds, and motorcycles, shall keep as near as safely practicable to the far right side or edge of the right traffic lane so they will be proceeding in the same direction as other traffic. No person riding on any bicycle, electric personal assistive mobility device, electric power-assisted bicycle, moped, roller skates, skateboards or other devices on wheels or runners shall attach the same or self to any vehicle on a highway. 
(Code 1982, § 22-51) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference- State law as to playing in streets, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-932. 
Sec. 28-157. - Discarded iceboxes, refrigerators and other containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discard, abandon, leave or allow to remain in any place any icebox, refrigerator or other container, device or equipment of any kind with an interior storage area of more than two cubic feet of clear space which is airtight, without first removing the door or hinges from such icebox, refrigerator, container, device or equipment. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any icebox, refrigerator, container, device or equipment which is being used for the purpose for which it was originally designed, or is being used for display purposes by any retail or wholesale merchant, or is crated, strapped or locked to such an extent that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any airtight compartment. 
(c)  Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-67; Code 1982, § 22-52; Ord. No. 948) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-319. 
Sec. 28-158. - Coasting prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person shall coast with any sleigh, sled, bobsled, wagon or other vehicle on any street within the city, except when such street has been barricaded and motor vehicular traffic has been temporarily prohibited by order of the city manager. 
(b)  The driver of any motor vehicle traveling on a downgrade on any highway shall not coast with the gears of the vehicle in neutral. 
(Code 1973, § 24-68; Code 1982, § 22-53; Ord. No. 948) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; use of coasters, roller skates, etc., on streets and sidewalks, § 36-10. 
State Law reference- Coasting, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-811; play and other vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-932. 
Sec. 28-159. - Urinating and defecating in public prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate on any street, alley, sidewalk, park or public place or area where the public gathers or has access, or within public view, other than in facilities designed for such purposes. Any person found guilty of any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 22-53.1; Ord. No. 1567, 2-10-1997) 
State Law reference- Expectorating in public places, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-322. 
Secs. 28-160-28-186. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WEAPONS[2]

Sec. 28-187. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Crime of violence includes any of the following crimes, or any attempt to commit any of the same: Murder, manslaughter, rape, mayhem, maliciously disfiguring another, abduction, kidnapping, burglary, housebreaking, larceny, any assault with intent to kill, commit rape or robbery, assault with a dangerous weapon, or assault with intent to commit any offense punishable by imprisonment in the penitentiary. 
    Sell and purchase include letting or hiring and similar forms of transferring. 
(Code 1973, § 40-1; Code 1982, § 37-1)

No. 1839, adopted Jan. 25, 2010. 
Sec. 28-190.1. - Transporting loaded weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, possess or carry a loaded shotgun or loaded rifle in any vehicle on any public street, road or highway in the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply to duly authorized law enforcement officers or military personnel in the performance of their lawful duties, or to any person who reasonably believes that a loaded rifle or shotgun is necessary for his personal safety in the course of his employment or business. Any person violating this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 1993, 1-28-2019) 
State Law reference- Regulation of transportation of a loaded rifle or shotgun, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-915.2. 
Secs. 28-191-28-200. - Reserved.

No. 1839, adopted Jan. 25, 2010; § 28-192, entitled "Concealed firearm permit requirements," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-6, Code 1982, § 37-6 and Ord. No. 1600, adopted Feb. 9, 1998; § 28-193, entitled "Sales of pistols to certain persons prohibited," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-7, and Code 1982, § 37-7; § 28-194, entitled "Purchasing and transferring firearms," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-8, and Code 1982, § 37-8; § 28-195, entitled "Weapon dealer's license-Required," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-9, and Code 1982, § 37-9; § 28-196, entitled "Issuance; conditions; records," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-10, and Code 1982, § 37-10; § 28-197, entitled "False information in sale of weapons," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-11, and Code 1982, § 37-11; § 28-198, entitled "Alteration of identifying marks of weapons," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-12, and Code 1982, § 37-12; § 28-199, entitled "Toy or antique pistols," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-13, and Code 1982, § 37-13; and § 28-200, entitled "Possession of certain dangerous weapons prohibited," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-14, and Code 1982, § 37-14. 
Sec. 28-201. - Destruction or sale of unclaimed firearms. 
(a)  Any unclaimed firearms and other weapons which have been in the possession of law enforcement agencies for a period of more than 120 days may be retained for use by the law enforcement agency, or destroyed as provided below. For the purposes of this section, "unclaimed firearms and other weapons" means any firearm or other weapon belonging to another which has been acquired by a law enforcement officer pursuant to his duties, which is not needed in any criminal prosecution, which has not been claimed by its rightful owner and which the state treasurer has indicated will be declined if remitted under the Uniform Disposition of Unclaimed Property Act. 
(b)  At the discretion of the chief of police, sheriff, or their duly authorized agents, any unclaimed firearm or other weapon that has been in the possession of law enforcement agencies for more than 120 days may be destroyed by any means which renders the firearm or other weapon permanently inoperable. Prior to the destruction of such firearms or other weapons, the chief of police, sheriff, or their duly authorized agents shall comply with the following notice provisions. 
(c)  The chief of police, sheriff or their duly authorized agents shall make reasonable attempts to notify the rightful owner of the property of its intent to retain or destroy such weapons, obtain from the attorney for the commonwealth, in writing a statement advising that the item is not needed in any criminal prosecution, and cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the locality, once a week for two successive weeks, notice that such weapons will be retained or destroyed together with the date, time and place of the for such retention or destruction. 
(d)  Any unclaimed item retained for use by the police department shall become the property of the city and shall be retained only if, in the opinion of the chief of police, there is a legitimate use for the property by the police department and that retention of the item is a more economical alternative than purchase of a similar or equivalent item. 
(e)  In lieu of destroying any such unclaimed firearm, the locality may donate the firearm to the department of forensic science, upon agreement of the department. 
(Ord. No. 1993, 1-28-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1993 adopted Jan. 28, 1993 repealed § 28-201 entitled "Seizure and disposition of dangerous articles," which derived from Code 1973, § 40-15, and Code 1982, § 37-15 and further added new provisions as § 28.201 "Destruction or sale of unclaimed firearms," as herein set out above. 
State Law reference- Disposal of unclaimed firearms or other weapons, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1719, 15.2-1721. 
Sec. 28-202. - Discharge of pneumatic guns in certain places prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot a pneumatic gun in any areas of the city. Pneumatic gun means any implement, designed as a gun, that will expel a BB or a pellet by action of pneumatic pressure; it includes a paintball gun that expels by action of pneumatic pressure plastic balls filled with paint for the purpose of marking the point of impact. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following acts are not prohibited by this section: 
(1)  Use of pneumatic guns at facilities approved for shooting ranges; 
(2)  Use of pneumatic guns on other property where firearms may be discharged; 
(3)  Use of pneumatic guns on or within private property with the permission of the owner or legal possessor thereof when conducted with reasonable care to prevent a projectile from crossing the bounds of the property; 
(4)  Shooting or discharge of a pneumatic gun by any law enforcement officer acting in the performance of the duties of a law enforcement agency. For the purposes of this section the term "law enforcement officer" includes any person defined as a law enforcement officer pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 9.1-101 and any animal control officer acting in the performance of his or her duty; and 
(5)  Shooting or discharge of a pneumatic gun by any representative of the Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries in the performance of duty for scientific collection or wildlife management purposes. 
(b)  Whenever any minor below the age of 16 uses any pneumatic gun, the minor must be supervised by a parent, guardian, or other adult supervisor approved by the minor's parent or guardian. Any minor using any pneumatic gun shall be responsible for obeying all laws, regulations and restrictions governing such use at all times. Violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1896, 4-22-2013) 
Chapter 30 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Provisions as to personnel, §§ 9.01-9.11. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- State law requiring city to establish personnel system, pay plan and grievance procedure, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1506. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City employee means any person employed by the city manager. 
    Grievance means a complaint or dispute by an employee based upon an event or condition that affects the circumstances under which an employee works, allegedly caused by misinterpretation, inconsistent or unfair application or lack of established policy pertaining to employment. 
    Immediate family includes parents, step-parents, grandparents, mother-in-law or father-in-law, children, stepchildren, siblings, step-siblings, grandchildren, spouse, domestic partner or other members of a family residing in the same household as the employee. 
    Layoff means the separation of an employee from a position to which such employee was appointed, as a result of the abolition of a position, lack of work or lack of funds. 
    Leadership team means a group of positions that are classified at the division director and general manager levels on the city's classification plan. Individuals employed on the leadership team are at-will employees who serve at the pleasure of the city manager, with the exception of police captains. 
    Police officers means sworn officers of the police department, who are empowered to enforce laws, have the power of arrest and have undergone or will be undergoing on-the-job training or similar instruction, as defined in the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-1, 3-12-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-2. - Application of provisions. 
(a)  The following persons in the service of the city are not subject to the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided by law and as mutually agreed to by the appropriate appointing authorities and the city council: 
(1)  Members of the city council. 
(2)  City clerk. 
(3)  City attorney. 
(4)  All other elected officials including constitutional officers and employees appointed by them. 
(5)  Members of boards and commissions. 
(6)  The city manager. 
(7)  The general registrar, deputy registrar, assistant registrars, and all officers of election employed by the electoral board. 
(8)  All persons appointed on a contractual or fee basis. 
(9)  Temporary employees. 
(10)  All others that are exempted by the city Charter or ordinance. 
(11)  School employees. 
(b)  All other positions other than temporary, which are under the administrative direction and control of the city manager, are subject to all provisions of this chapter and supplementary administrative regulations. 
(c)  In addition to the rules in this chapter, city police officers must also follow the general orders issued by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-2, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-3. - Acceptance of employment deemed consent to chapter provisions. 
    Upon employment, every employee consents and agrees to all the provisions of this chapter and to abide by the administrative regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-3, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-4. - Administrative regulations. 
(a)  The city manager is responsible for the general administration of personnel matters, including but not limited to leave policies, a classification plan for employees, a uniform pay plan, and procedures for resolving grievances of employees. These policies shall be promulgated by the city manager as administrative regulations. 
(b)  Copies of new administrative regulations shall be organized in a unified document and made available to all employees of the city. 
(c)  Proposed changes to the administrative regulations shall be made available to employees and posted for review and comment for no fewer than 30 days before final promulgation by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-4, 3-12-2007) 
Secs. 30-5-30-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GRIEVANCES 

Sec. 30-54. - Eligibility. 
(a)  All nonprobationary, regular fulltime and parttime employees working 20 or more hours weekly are eligible to file grievances, with the exception of the: 
(1)  City manager. 
(2)  City attorney. 
(3)  City clerk. 
(4)  Elected and appointed state and local officials. 
(5)  Employees of constitutional officers. 
(6)  Temporary, term, grant and seasonal employees. 
(b)  The exceptions listed in subsection (a) of this section do not apply to a city employee, if the complaint includes allegations of discrimination on the basis of race, color, creed, religion, age, disability, national origin, gender, political affiliation, sexual orientation or marital status. 
(c)  Leadership team employees' grievance rights are limited in that they may not grieve termination or demotion, with the exception of police captains. 
(d)  Law enforcement officers, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 9.1-500, who have a grievance may proceed under the guidelines cited in the Law Enforcement Officers Procedural Guarantee Act, Code of Virginia, § 9.1-500 et seq. or under the city's grievance procedure, but not both. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-5, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-55. - Types of grievances. 
    A grievance may include, but is not necessarily limited to: 
(1)  Disciplinary actions involving dismissals, demotions and suspensions, provided that the dismissals shall be grievable, whenever resulting from formal discipline or unsatisfactory job performance. 
(2)  The application, meaning or interpretation of personnel policies, procedures, rules and regulations. 
(3)  Complaint of discrimination on the basis of race, color, creed, religion, political affiliation, age, gender, disability, national origin, sexual orientation, or marital status. 
(4)  Sexual harassment. 
(5)  Acts of retaliation as the result of the use of, or participation in, the grievance procedure, or because the employee complied with any law of the United States or of the Commonwealth, has reported any violation of such governmental authority, has sought any change in law before the Congress of the United States or the General Assembly, or has reported an incidence of fraud, abuse, or gross mismanagement to a city councilmember, the city manager, or other governmental authority. 
(6)  Retaliation for exercising any rights otherwise protected by law. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-6, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-56. - Nongrievable actions. 
(a)  A grievance shall not be interpreted to include: 
(1)  The contents of ordinances, statutes, or established personnel policies, rules and regulations. 
(2)  Work activity accepted by the employee as a condition of employment or work activity, which may be reasonably expected to be a part of the job description. 
(3)  Establishment and revisions of wages or salaries, position classifications, or general benefits. 
(4)  Failure to promote, except where the employee can show established promotional policies or procedures were not followed or applied fairly. 
(5)  The methods, means, and personnel by which such work activities are to be completed. 
(6)  Discharge, demotion or layoff because of lack of work, reduction in workforce or job abolition, except where such action affects an employee who has been reinstated within the previous six months as a result of the final determination of a grievance. 
(7)  The hiring, promotion, transfer, assignment, and retention of employees within the city. 
(8)  The relief of employees from duties in emergencies. 
(9)  Oral reprimands. 
(10)  Decisions of a performance evaluation appeals panel. 
(b)  In any grievance brought under the exception to subsection (a)(5) of this section, the action shall be upheld upon a showing by the city that there was a valid business reason for the action and the employee was notified of such reason in writing prior to the effective date of the action. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-7, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-57. - Grievability determinations. 
(a)  Decisions regarding whether or not a matter is grievable shall be made by the city manager at the request of the grievant or the department, on the appropriate form. Such determination of grievability shall be made, subsequent to the placement of the grievance in writing, but prior to a hearing before the city employee review board. The form bearing the decision of the city manager must be returned to the grievant within 14 calendar days after receipt of the request. 
(b)  The issue of grievability may be raised at any step of the procedure prior to a hearing before the board; but once raised, the issue must be resolved before further processing of the grievance. In any event, the issue of grievability must be resolved prior to a board hearing, or it shall be deemed to have been waived. 
(c)  The city manager's decision regarding grievability may be appealed to the County Circuit Court for a hearing de novo on the issue of grievability as provided in section 15.2-1507 A.9.a of the Code of Virginia (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1507 A.9a), as amended. Such appeal shall be noted by returning the grievability form to the city manager within 14 calendar days after receipt of the initial decision on grievability. Within 14 calendar days thereafter, the city manager shall transmit the record, including copies of the decision of the city manager, the notice of appeal and any exhibits, to the clerk of the County Circuit Court. The procedure for the conduct of the appeal shall be provided for in section 15.2-1507 A.9.a and b of the Code of Virginia (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1507 A.9.a, b), as amended. The decision of the court is final and is not appealable. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-8, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-58. - Procedure. 
    Employee grievances, whether by an individual or a group of employees, shall be processed as follows: 
(1)  Step 1. Supervisory level. A grievance must be raised within 20 calendar days after the occurrence or condition giving rise to the grievance, or within 20 calendar days following the time the employee knows or should have known of its occurrence. 
a.  Part A. A grievant shall discuss the matter with the grievant's immediate supervisor, who shall attempt to resolve the matter informally. Within five calendar days of such discussion, the supervisor shall give response to the employee with respect to the grievance or shall advise the employee that additional time for such decision is needed, in which case a decision must be given to the employee within five calendar days thereafter. 
b.  Part B. If a satisfactory resolution is not reached by this process, the employee may put the grievance in writing, on the approved city form, stating the nature of the grievance and the expected remedy. Such written grievance shall be presented to the next level of supervision within ten calendar days after notice of the decision of the immediate supervisor. The second level supervisor shall hold a meeting with the employee and render a written decision within seven calendar days of receipt of the appeal. If the second level supervisor is the general manager, step 1, part B and step 2 are consolidated into a single step. 
(2)  Step 2. Management level. If the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the second level supervisor, the grievant may submit the grievance to the general manager within 15 calendar days of the reply received from step 1, part B as set forth in subsection (1)b of this section. At least three calendar days prior to the hearing, all documents, exhibits, and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties. The general manager shall hear the appeal within ten calendar days of receipt of the request and shall render a written decision to the grievant within five calendar days following the hearing. If the supervisor is the city manager, steps 2 and 3 as set forth in this subsection and subsection (3) of this section, are consolidated into a single step. 
(3)  Step 3. City manager. If the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the general manager, the grievant may file a written appeal to the city manager within 21 calendar days of receipt of the decision in step 2 as set forth in subsection (2) of this section. At least three calendar days prior to the hearing, all documents, exhibits, and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties. The city manager shall hear the grievant within 14 calendar days of receipt of the request, and render a written decision within an additional seven calendar days after completion of the hearing. 
(4)  Step 4. Board hearing. 
a.  If the grievant is not satisfied with the decision of the city manager, he may file a written appeal, on the appropriate city form, to the city employees review board, via the chairman, within 14 calendar days of receipt of the city manager's decision. The city employees review board shall hear the appeal within 40 calendar days of receipt. 
b.  At least ten calendar days before a scheduled hearing, the grievant and such grievant's attorney shall be allowed access to and copies of all relevant files intended to be used in the grievance hearing, and all documents, exhibits, and lists of witnesses shall be exchanged between the parties. 
c.  The board has the responsibility to interpret the application of appropriate city or department policies and procedures in the case. It does not have the prerogative to formulate or to change policies or procedures. A quorum of the board shall consist of all three members. 
d.  The city employees review board shall render a written decision within 14 calendar days after completion of the hearing and it shall be filed by the chairman with the city manager. The majority decision of the board shall be final and binding in all the determinations and shall be consistent with the provisions of law and written policies. Copies of the decision shall be transmitted to the director of human resources, the employee and the employee's supervisors via the general manager. Either party to the grievance may petition the county circuit court for an order requiring implementation of the decision of the board. 
(5)  Personal face to face meetings are required at steps 1 through 3 as set forth in subsections (1) through (3) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-9, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-59. - Employee review board. 
(a)  The board shall be composed of three members who are citizens of the city and are appointed by the city council. The members shall be appointed for staggered three-year terms and shall elect a chairman annually within two months following either: the annual appointment of new fulltime members, or the anniversary of their appointment. Members shall serve without compensation. In addition to serving as the final appeal board for grievance procedures, the board shall serve as the selection committee for the city employee of the year program. 
(b)  The board shall not be composed of any persons having direct involvement with the grievance being heard by the board or with the complaint or dispute giving rise to the grievance. Managers who are in a direct line of supervision of a grievant and the following relatives of a participant in the grievance process or a participant's spouse are prohibited from serving as board members: spouse, parent, and child, descendants of a child, sibling, niece, nephew and first cousin. No attorney having direct involvement with the subject matter of the grievance, nor a partner, associate, employee or co-employee of such an attorney shall serve as a board member. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-10, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-60. - Employee representation. 
    The employee shall be permitted to be accompanied or represented by an individual of such employee's choice at step 1, part B as set forth in section 30-58(1)b and any subsequent steps in the grievance procedure. The second level supervisor, general manager or city manager may have a witness of choice likewise in attendance at any meeting. If an employee using the grievance procedure elects to have legal counsel representation, the employee shall be responsible for the related expenses. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-11, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-61. - Mediation. 
    Mediation is a voluntary process and employees or supervisors may initiate a request for mediation to the city's human resources director. The human resources director will meet with the employees interested in mediation to explain the process, determine their commitment to reaching a resolution, and to assess the appropriateness of the issue for mediation. If mediation is requested prior to the initiation of a grievance, the employee may request an extension of the initial filing period. If the request for mediation is made during the course of a grievance, the applicable time periods are extended until the conclusion of the mediation process. Upon conclusion of the mediation process and the resulting written agreement that both parties to the complaint or dispute sign, an employee may agree that a written grievance will not be initiated or that a grievance in progress will be concluded. The city manager shall provide an administrative regulation setting forth the mediation procedure. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-12, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-62. - Waiver of time limits. 
    By mutual agreement in writing, the parties to a grievance at any and every step may extend any or all of the time periods established in the procedures. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-13, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-63. - Failure to comply with procedural requirements. 
    After the initial filing of a written grievance, failure of either party to comply with all substantial procedural requirements of the grievance procedure without just cause will result in a decision in favor of the other party on any grievable issue, provided the party not in compliance fails to correct the noncompliance within five work days of receipt of written notification by the other party of the compliance violation. Such written notification by the grievant shall be made to the city manager. Failure of either party without just cause to comply with all substantial procedural requirements at the board hearing shall result in a decision in favor of the other party. Compliance determinations made by the city manager shall be subject to judicial review by filing a petition with the circuit court within 30 days of the compliance determination. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-14, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-64. - Management rights and maintenance and analysis of records. 
(a)  Nothing in the procedure is intended to circumscribe or modify the existing management right of the city to do the following: 
(1)  Direct the work of its employees as well as establish and revise wages, salaries, position classifications and general employee benefits. 
(2)  Hire, promote, transfer, assign and retain employees within the city. 
(3)  Maintain the efficiency of governmental operations. 
(4)  Relieve employees from duties in emergencies. 
(5)  Determine the methods, means and personnel by which operations are to be carried on. 
(b)  Records relating to a grievance, including all written statements, forms, investigations and exhibits, are maintained in the human resources division. Such information is protected by the Privacy Act of Virginia, and access to the records is limited accordingly. The director of human resources shall conduct an annual review of all grievances filed and make a written report by each February 1 to the city manager should a trend, after analysis, require action to minimize the causes of such grievances in the future. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-15, 3-12-2007) 
Secs. 30-65-30-86. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LAYOFFS AND TRANSFERS 

Sec. 30-87. - Use of layoff procedure. 
    The city manager may invoke a layoff procedure when such manager determines that there are an excess number of employees as a result of the abolishment of a position, reorganization of functions, the lack of funds, or the lack of or curtailment of work. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-16, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-88. - Determination of employees to be laid-off. 
(a)  It is the responsibility of the director of human resources to develop layoff registers for each classification in which the city manager has invoked a layoff procedure. Each layoff register shall be divided into three categories and these shall be utilized in the separation of excess employees. These categories are: 
(1)  First category: temporary employees. 
(2)  Second category: probationary employees. 
(3)  Third category: permanent status employees. 
(b)  Within each classification in which a layoff procedure has been invoked, all employees in the first category shall be separated prior to separating any employees from the second category, and similarly all employees in the second category shall be separated prior to separating any permanent status employees in the third category. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-17, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-89. - Development of layoff register. 
(a)  First category. The names of employees in the first category shall be placed on the list in alphabetical order. No layoff rating value shall be assigned to these employees and the order of separation within this category shall be at the determination of the general manager. 
(b)  Second category. The names of employees in the second category shall be placed on the list in alphabetical order. No layoff rating value shall be assigned to these employees and the order of separation within this category shall be at the determination of the general manager. 
(c)  Third category. Each permanent status employee shall have a layoff rating value assigned by the director of human resources which will determine that employee's place within the category. The layoff rating value shall be a combination of months of creditable service with the city and an average performance evaluation score (APES) for the official performance evaluation ratings received within the last five years. The points assigned for months of service shall equal 40 percent of the total score, while the points assigned for the average performance evaluation score shall equal 60 percent of the total point value. The procedure is as follows: 
(1)  Points for service. One point is given for each full month of creditable service with the city. 
(2)  Points for performance evaluation rating. An examination shall be made of the employee's annual performance evaluation ratings and/or the evaluation ratings completed prior to a promotion/demotion action, dating back for no more than five years of creditable service. Each evaluation shall be assigned points as follows: 
a.  Three points for each "exceeds expectations" rating. 
b.  Two points for each "above expectations" rating. 
c.  One point for each "meets expectations" rating. 
d.  Zero points for each "needs improvement or below expectations" rating. 
The total points assigned are added together and then divided by the number of evaluations used to obtain the average performance evaluation score (APES). 
(3)  Formula to calculate the layoff rating value. (Number of months of creditable service x 0.4) + (the sum of points received for performance evaluations within the last five years ;ds; by number of evaluations) x 0.6. 
(4)  Separation of employees in third category. Separation of employees in the third category shall be in the order of those with the least layoff rating value on the layoff register to those with the highest layoff rating value. If two employees have the same layoff rating value, separation shall be at the determination of the general manager, taking into account any special skills or training the employee may possess. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-18, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-90. - Transfer in lieu of layoff. 
(a)  An employee designated as excess shall be transferred to a position in the same class, which may be vacant in another city department or division. If not accepted within five working days of the offer, the employee shall be deemed terminated. An excess employee may request a transfer to another class in the city's classification plan for which there is a vacancy, provided all the qualifications are met. If the vacancy is in a higher classified position, the employee designated as excess will be subject to the selection procedures in the city's administrative regulations. Applications for such transfers are voluntary. 
(b)  If a lateral transfer is not available, an employee shall be transferred to a lower classified position, the employee shall be placed in the new salary level equal to the employee's current rate of pay. This transfer could involve a gradual pay reduction. If not accepted within five working days of the offer, the employee shall be deemed terminated. When the employee's rate of pay prior to transfer exceeds the maximum step of the new, lower salary level, the employee's rate of pay shall be frozen at that existing rate for six months until the pay of the lower salary level matches or exceeds the employee's rate of pay from the time of the transfer. After six months, the employee shall receive a reduction in pay equal to five percent and shall be assigned to a salary level corresponding to this rate of pay, if possible. If the employee's rate of pay following the five percent reduction exceeds the maximum rate of pay for the salary level, the employee's rate of pay shall be frozen again for a second six-month period. At the end of the second six months, the employee's rate of pay shall be reduced again by five percent, and if it still exceeds the maximum rate of pay, it shall be frozen and then reduced by five percent in six month intervals until the maximum rate of pay for that salary level is achieved. The anniversary date shall not change. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-19, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-91. - Reemployment list. 
(a)  If there are no transfer opportunities, an excess employee in the second or third category of the layoff register shall be placed on a reemployment list for that class for a period of one year from layoff. If the excess employee on the reemployment list does not accept the first available permanent status vacancy of the same class as that from which he had been laid off that occurs within the year, the employee shall be removed from the reemployment list and may apply at any time for future city employment subject to the selection procedures in the personnel regulations. 
(b)  Vacancies in lower classes in the same class series shall also be offered during the period the excess employee is on the reemployment list if the excess employee meets all the qualifications. If an employee is offered and rejects an employment opportunity in a lower class in the class series, the employee shall remain eligible for reemployment in such employee's same class as that from which the employee had been laid off, but will be removed from the reemployment list of the class in which an employment opportunity is rejected. An employee who accepts reemployment in a lower graded class shall retain eligibility for reemployment rights within the same class for the one-year period. 
(c)  Temporary positions that become available in that same class will be offered to persons with reemployment rights. If an employee accepts a temporary position, such employee shall remain eligible for reemployment as described in this section. 
(d)  The city manager is authorized to provide severance pay to regular employees at the rate of pay at the time of layoff based on the regular number of hours worked weekly. The amount of severance pay shall be determined by the city manager, but shall not exceed six weeks. Temporary, grant and term employees are excluded form eligibility. Severance pay shall be forfeited by an employee who declines a transfer or reassignment to a position in the same class series where the general terms and conditions of employment are identical to those, which the employee enjoyed in the position held prior to layoff. The city manager shall establish other rules and regulations dealing with the payment of such severance pay. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-20, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-92. - Notification procedures. 
(a)  General managers whose departments are affected by a layoff shall issue a general notice indicating a layoff procedure is underway. This notice is issued when it is not yet determined what individual action shall be taken. 
(b)  Prior to layoff, a permanent employee shall receive at least 30 calendar days' notice. A temporary or probationary employee shall receive at least ten calendar days' notice. 
(c)  The employee's specific notice of layoff shall be accomplished in a written communication from the employee's general manager, notifying such employee of the layoff and the reasons for it. The communication may be either hand-delivered or sent by certified mail to the employee's home address. A copy of the communication shall be forwarded to the human resources office. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-21, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-93. - Job-sharing and reduced hours. 
    General managers whose departments are affected by a layoff procedure shall consider job-sharing and/or reduced working hours in an effort to reduce the number of employees who would otherwise be laid-off. A recommendation on the feasibility of job-sharing and/or reduced working hours shall be forwarded to the division of human resources with an analysis of the impact on city services rendered, fiscal cost comparisons and other pertinent data. The city manager shall either approve or deny the recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-22, 3-12-2007) 
Secs. 30-94-30-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PENSION PLANS 

Sec. 30-115. - City retirement system established. 
    A retirement system is established under the authority of state law. A trust fund is established for post-employment benefits, other than pensions. The general administration and responsibility for the operation of the city's basic and police pension plans and the trust fund for post-employment benefits other than pensions shall be vested in the retirement board of the city. The powers and duties, composition, accountability, term of office, officers, and vacancies shall be established in the city's basic and police pension plan documents and in the trust agreement for post-employment benefits other than pensions. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-23, 3-12-2007; Ord. No. 1903, 8-12-2013) 
Sec. 30-116. - Retirement board; powers and duties. 
    The general administration of and responsibility for the operation of the city's basic and police pension plans (hereafter referred to jointly as the "plans") and the trust fund for post-employment benefits other than pensions shall be vested in the retirement board of the city (hereafter referred to as the "board"). The board's powers and duties shall include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Selection of the person or other entity that will handle the investments, administration, and actuarial evaluation of the city's plans, including the other post-employment benefits (OPEB); 
(2)  Review the asset allocation of the pension plans and OPEB plan and the making of recommendations for changes; 
(3)  Review of the investment performance of the plans on a quarterly basis and the annual costs of the plans; 
(4)  The periodic review of the language of the plans as it impacts upon costs and the making of recommendations for change; 
(5)  The receipt and approval or denial of applications for disability retirements; and 
(6)  The discontinuance or reduction of retirement allowances based upon a periodic review of disability retirees to determine whether they have subsequently improved or have obtained other employment. 
(7)  The provisions of this section shall take effect on August 12, 2013. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-24, 3-12-2007; Ord. No. 1903, 8-12-2013) 
Sec. 30-117. - Accountability. 
    The retirement board shall be accountable to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-25, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-118. - Composition of board. 
    The retirement board shall consist of seven members as follows: 
(1)  Three members appointed by the city council, each of whom shall be residents of the city pursuant to City Charter, section 4.14; 
(2)  One member appointed by the city manager; 
(3)  One member who is a member of the police pension plan and who is elected by the police department officers or the officers of the public safety department, should one be established; and 
(4)  Two members who are members of the basic plan elected by those employees who are members of the basic pension plan. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-26, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-119. - Term of office. 
    The terms of office of the retirement board shall be three years. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-27, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-120. - Officers. 
    The retirement board shall elect annually one council appointee member as the chair and one employee elected member as the vice-chair. In the event of a vacancy in the chair, the board shall elect another of the council appointees to fill the remainder of the term. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-28, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-121. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies for the retirement board shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-29, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-122. - Compensation. 
    The members of the retirement board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-30, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-123. - Meetings. 
    The retirement board shall meet on a semiannual basis at a minimum and may meet more frequently as business requires. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-31, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-124. - Authorization to execute plans. 
    The city manager is authorized to execute amendments to the city's plans in order to effectuate the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-32, 3-12-2007) 
Sec. 30-125. - Assistance of city attorney. 
    The retirement board shall have the assistance of the city attorney, as required. 
(Ord. No. 1802, § 25-33, 3-12-2007) 
Chapter 32 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Provisions relative to public safety and the police department, §§ 11.01-11.05. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention, ch. 18; enforcement provisions relative to motor vehicles and traffic by officers, § 26-4; interference with police department equipment or police dogs § 28-154; security alarm systems, § 12-21 et seq. 
State Law reference- State law as to police generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1701 et seq. 

Sec. 32-1. - Performance of functions of public safety; joint fire department. 
(a)  The functions of public safety shall be performed by the police department and such other bureaus, divisions and units as may be provided by ordinance or by orders of the city manager consistent therewith. 
(b)  The city may enter into contractual relationships with neighboring political subdivisions for the support and utilization of a joint fire department which shall be responsible for the protection from fire of life and property within the city, and may, at any time, establish a city fire department for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 820, § 26.01) 
Sec. 32-2. - Police department. 
    The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other officers and employees of such ranks and grades as may be established by ordinance. The police department shall be responsible for the preservation of the public peace, prevention of crime, apprehension of criminals, protection of the rights of persons and property, and enforcement of the laws of the commonwealth, the ordinances of the city and all rules and regulations made in accordance therewith. The chief of police and the other members of the police force of the city shall have all the powers and duties of police officers as provided by the general laws of the commonwealth. 
(Ord. No. 820, § 26.02) 
Sec. 32-3. - Chief of police. 
    The head of the police department shall be the chief of police and shall be appointed by the city manager. Under the general supervision of the city manager, he shall be in direct command of the police department. He shall appoint all members of the department and assign all members of the department to their respective posts, shifts, details and duties. He shall, with the approval of the city manager, make rules and regulations in conformity with the city Charter, the laws of the commonwealth, and the ordinances of the city concerning the operation of the department, the conduct of the officers and employees thereof, their uniforms, arms and other equipment, their training and the penalties to be imposed for infractions of such rules and regulations. The chief of police shall be responsible for the efficiency, discipline and good conduct of the department. Orders of the city manager relating to the police department shall be transmitted in all cases through the chief of police or, in his absence from the city or incapacity, through an officer of the department designated as acting chief by the city manager. Disobedience to the lawful commands of the chief of police or violation of the rules and regulations made by him with the approval of the city manager shall be ground for removal or other disciplinary action as provided in such rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 820, § 26.03) 
Sec. 32-4. - Authority to dispose of lost, abandoned, property, etc. 
    The police department is hereby granted the authority to dispose of all property which has been turned in to the department as lost or stolen, and which has not been claimed, or which was found abandoned by the members of the police department and has not been claimed or any property which has been confiscated by the police department. All such property shall be disposed of in accordance with the directions of the city manager. In all cases each separate item of property shall be retained by the department for a period of at least 90 days from the time it came into the possession of the department before any attempt is made to dispose of it. 
(Code 1973, § 29-1; Code 1982, § 26-1) 
State Law reference- Disposal of unclaimed property, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1719, 15.2-1721. 
Sec. 32-5. - Unauthorized wearing of uniforms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a uniform of the police department except authorized department members. 
(Code 1973, § 29-2; Code 1982, § 26-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-175. 
Sec. 32-6. - Police department equipment. 
    All police equipment such as weapons, handcuffs and similar equipment shall be owned by the city, issued to police officers and periodically inspected. 
(Code 1973, § 29-6; Code 1982, § 26-3) 
Sec. 32-7. - Protection of city property located outside city. 
(a)  The police department of the city is directed to protect the city's property wherever located in the county, including but not limited to the George Mason Junior-Senior High School and Mount Daniel Elementary School, and the city's water, water lines and appurtenances. 
(b)  In all matters properly related to the protection of such city-owned property, the police are directed to apply the appropriate and pertinent statutes of the state or this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 29-7; Code 1982, § 26-4) 
State Law reference- Police jurisdiction over city lands, buildings, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1124. 
Sec. 32-8. - Impersonating officer. 
    Any person who shall falsely assume or exercise the functions, powers, duties and privileges incident to the office of sheriff, police officer, marshal or other peace officer, or who shall falsely assume or pretend to be any such officer shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 29-3; Code 1982, § 26-5) 
Sec. 32-9. - Giving false reports to police officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to give a false report as to the commission of any crime to any sheriff, deputy, member of the state police, police officer or any other law enforcement official with intent to mislead. 
(Code 1973, § 29-4; Code 1982, § 26-6) 
Sec. 32-10. - Interfering with arrests. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, obstruct or in any way interfere with any arrest made or attempted by any police or other officer having authority to make arrests. 
(Code 1973, § 29-5; Code 1982, § 26-7) 
Sec. 32-11. - Off-duty employment of law enforcement officers. 
    City law enforcement officers, to include deputy sheriffs, are authorized to engage in off-duty employment which may occasionally require the use of their police powers in the performance of such employment. The chief of police and sheriff shall promulgate reasonable rules and regulations which shall apply to all off-duty employment of city law enforcement officers within the respective organizations. 
(Code 1982, § 26-8; Ord. No. 1540, 3-11-1996) 
Sec. 32-12. - Trespass notices. 
    The owner or the agent of such owner of any real property within the city may designate the city police department as a person lawfully in charge of the property for the purpose of forbidding another to go on or remain upon the lands, buildings, or premises of the owner, as specified in the designation. Any such designation shall be in writing upon forms approved by the chief of police and notarized, which writing shall be kept on file with the city police department. 
(Code 1982, § 26-9; Ord. No. 1706, 6-25-2001) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate police to enforce trespass violations, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1717.1. 
Chapter 33 - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 
ARTICLE I. - INTENT 

Sec. 33-01. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish minimum standards to promote the maintenance, upkeep and repair of homes and businesses to encourage the prevention and elimination of blighted, unsightly conditions not addressed by the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. No civil penalty shall be imposed without a warning notice first being issued to the responsible persons. 
(Ord. No. 1872, 3-12-2012) 
ARTICLE II. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 33-1. - Enforcement, applicability and notice. 
(a)  Authorized officials. The departments of development services and police, and officials designated by the city manager, are hereby authorized to take corrective actions and issue a warning notice or a notice of violation for any violation of this chapter pursuant to the procedures in this section. 
(b)  Applicability. With respect to a residential or commercial property or use within the city, no owner or agent of the owner, person, tenant or corporation shall violate any provision of this chapter.
