Chapter 36 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city over streets and sidewalks, §§ 2.03, 2.04. 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; condominiums, § 6-48 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 34; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 26; permit for parades and processions, § 26-13; bicycles, § 26-105 et seq.; noise, § 14-49 et seq.; alcoholic beverage on city property, § 28-92; use of alcoholic beverages in public places, § 28-93; debris, etc., in streets, § 28-155; games in streets, § 28-156; coasting prohibited, § 28-158; outdoor lighting, § 14-127; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 26; utilities, ch. 42; subdivisions, ch. 38; sidewalk improvements in subdivisions, § 38-80; vehicles for hire, ch. 46; trees and shrubs, § 44-20 et seq.; planting of trees, shrubs and weeds along streets and public easements, § 44-24; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq.; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Authority of city with regard to streets and sidewalks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-967; streets and alleys generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2000 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City manager means the city manager or the duly appointed representative of the city manager. 
    Duly appointed representative city manager's duly appointed representative shall be understood to mean the director of public works. 
    Improved means opened, graded, constructed, maintained or repaired. 
    Planting means anything that is put or set in the ground for growth. 
    Road means any land, street, alley, avenue, appurtenant structure or right-of-way construction on any public right-of-way in the city, including those dedicated for public use. 
    Structure means an assembly of materials forming a construction for occupancy or use, including, among others, buildings, gospel and circus tents, reviewing stands, platforms, staging observation towers, water tanks, open sheds, shelters, fences and display signs. 
(Code 1973, § 33-1; Code 1982, § 32-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-2. - House numbering. 
(a)  For purposes of applying numbers to residences and other buildings now or to be hereafter erected within the corporate limits of the city, the city shall be divided throughout by Washington and Broad Streets in four sections to be known for purposes of address and location as north, south, east and west. 
(b)  Beginning in each of the sections, north, south, east and west, as the case may be in any and all streets and running from Broad and Washington Streets, the unit and ten digits for all buildings to be numbered shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  On the right side of all streets and avenues, the numbers are to be even and, beginning at zero, increased by two for each 50 feet linear measure on the property line. 
(2)  On the left side of all streets and avenues, the numbers are to be odd and, beginning at one, increased by two for each 50 feet linear measure on the property line. 
(c)  The building inspector shall maintain a map which shall designate and control the numbering of buildings. 
(Code 1973, § 33-2; Code 1982, § 32-2) 
Cross reference- Housing, ch. 22. 
Sec. 36-3. - Vision at intersections. 
    It shall be unlawful, at any intersections, to have any plantings or structures which might obstruct vision as set forth in section 48-1103(c). 
(Code 1973, § 33-3; Code 1982, § 32-3) 
Sec. 36-4. - Obstructions. 
    No person shall, except with the consent of the city manager, obstruct any street, curb, sidewalk, street right-of-way or the free passage thereof. The city manager may direct the removal of such obstruction at the expense of the person responsible. 
(Code 1973, § 33-4; Code 1982, § 32-4) 
Sec. 36-5. - Private lampposts, signs, etc. 
    No private lamppost or other lamp support, light or sign shall be installed over any street or sidewalk, except as provided for in the zoning and outdoor lighting regulations. 
(Code 1973, § 33-5; Code 1982, § 32-5) 
Sec. 36-6. - Barbed wire fences. 
    No person shall construct any fence of barbed wire or similar material or place any such barbed wire or similar material along the line of any street or sidewalk or lot line within the corporate limits of the city, except in commercial areas when approved by the city manager. Any such barbed wire or similar material so erected or placed shall be removed at once, as directed by the city manager at the expense of the offender. 
(Code 1973, § 33-6; Code 1982, § 32-6) 
Sec. 36-7. - Assessments for construction of sidewalks. 
    Assessment for the construction of sidewalks upon any accepted street within the corporate limits of the city shall be made in compliance with the state requirements, as set out in Code of Virginia, § 15.1-239 et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 33-7; Code 1982, § 32-7) 
Cross reference- Sidewalk improvement in subdivisions, § 38-80. 
Sec. 36-8. - Assessments for construction of driveways. 
    All driveways on any city right-of-way necessary for entrance to any private property shall be constructed and maintained at the expense of the owner of the private property and under the direction and supervision of the department of public works. The cost of constructing and maintaining such driveways shall be assessed and collected in the same manner as other costs or taxes are assessed and collected. 
(Code 1973, § 33-8; Code 1982, § 32-8) 
Sec. 36-9. - Gates opening onto streets and sidewalks. 
    No gate shall be hung so as to open over any sidewalk or street unless, by reason of the contour of the land, it shall be impracticable for such gate to open otherwise, in which event the consent of the city manager must be secured before such gate is hung, and such gate shall be provided at all times with a spring, weight or other device which will cause it to remain closed when not in use. 
(Code 1973, § 33-9; Code 1982, § 32-9) 
Sec. 36-10. - Use of coasters, roller skates, etc. 
    No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk. 
(Code 1973, § 33-10; Code 1982, § 32-10) 
Cross reference- Coasting, § 28-158. 
Sec. 36-11. - Interfering with or damaging street lights, markers or signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without legal authority, to extinguish, obstruct, damage or interfere with any streetlight, marker or sign within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 33-11; Code 1982, § 32-11) 
Sec. 36-12. - Emergency closing of streets. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the city manager, an emergency shall exist, construction or repair work upon any street or part thereof shall require or other conditions affecting traffic shall necessitate, the city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to close temporarily any street or any part thereof within the city. Streets shall be closed by placing or causing to be placed suitable barriers so marked and lettered and so lighted by night that it may be clearly apparent at all times that such street or highway, or part thereof, is closed to vehicular traffic. It shall be unlawful for any person to move such barriers or to operate a motor vehicle over such streets. 
(Code 1973, § 33-12; Code 1982, § 32-12) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, ch. 26. 
Sec. 36-13. - Temporary one-way streets. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized, during the course of any street construction or repair within the city or in the event of any temporary emergency which in the judgment of the city manager requires such action, to declare any street or part thereof to be a one-way street for the term of the construction, repair or other emergency. The city manager may cause to be placed suitable notices for the guidance of vehicular traffic. The city manager may make such rules as may be necessary for the regulation of traffic in the respective directions. The city manager may make all necessary arrangements for the proper policing of same. 
(Code 1973, § 33-13; Code 1982, § 32-13) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic generally, ch. 26. 
Sec. 36-14. - Permitting land to wash upon sidewalks, streets. 
    Owners of land or persons in control of land abutting upon streets shall protect such land so as to prevent sand, gravel, earth, trash or other like things from falling or being washed upon the streets, driveways or sidewalks. 
(Code 1973, § 33-14; Code 1982, § 32-14) 
Sec. 36-15. - Burning. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn, on any public street, alley or sidewalk of the city, any box, plank, packing, straw, paper, debris, trash, rubbish, leaves or any other substance or material. 
(Code 1973, § 33-15; Code 1982, § 32-15) 
Sec. 36-16. - Distribution of handbills, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, or cause to be distributed, handbills, circulars, cards or other advertising matter of any kind on the streets or on any utility poles, or on the sidewalks of the city by: 
(1)  Depositing such matter in or upon any automobile or other vehicle which may be located in the street or parking lots; 
(2)  Depositing them in the streets or on the sidewalks; or 
(3)  Placing them in doorways or other places opening directly on or abutting a street or sidewalk. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, or cause to be distributed, handbills, circulars, cards or other advertising matter by depositing or casting same in such a manner as to cause litter on the porches, in the vestibules or in the front yards of private residences in the city. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the distribution of envelopes containing the articles mentioned herein or of newspapers, by depositing same on the porches or in the vestibules of private residences, or by placing them in doorways or other places fronting directly on the streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 1973, § 33-16; Code 1982, § 32-16) 
Sec. 36-17. - Snow or ice removal. 
(a)  Whenever snow or ice shall fall and/or lie on the sidewalks of the city, it shall be the duty of each tenant in possession or, if there is none, the owner to clean the snow or ice from the sidewalk in front of the place possessed or owned by such person, as the case may be. The tenant in possession or owner shall clean the snow or ice within 12 hours after the snow shall have ceased to fall or the ice accumulate, unless same is at night; and if at night, then within 12 hours after sunrise the next day. In those instances where the abutting property is not used for residential purposes, the snow or ice shall be removed within six hours after the snow shall have ceased to fall or the ice accumulate, unless the same is at night; and if at night, then within six hours after sunrise the next day. It will be unlawful for any person to move into any city street any snow or ice that has fallen or accumulated on the property of such person. 
(b)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $100.00 for the first offense within any five-year period. In instances where the abutting property is used for residential purposes, a second offense within a five year period shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $200.00; and for a third offense within a five-year period, by a fine not to exceed $500.00. In instances where the abutting property is used for commercial purposes, a second offense within a five-year period shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $300.00; for a third offense within a five-year period, by a fine not to exceed $750.00. 
(Code 1973, § 33-17; Code 1982, § 32-17; Ord. No. 1044, 4-11-1983; Ord. No. 1369, 9-9-1991) 
Secs. 36-18-36-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 38. 

Sec. 36-38. - Subdivision plats. 
    All subdivision plats shall be submitted as required under chapters 38 and 48, pertaining to subdivision and zoning respectively. 
(Code 1973, § 33-18; Code 1982, § 32-18) 
Sec. 36-39. - Bond; issuance of permit. 
(a)  Before issuing any permit, the city manager shall require the posting of a performance bond issued by a reputable insurance company, surety or bonding company. The performance bond shall be in the amount estimated by the director of public works to cover the entire project, which shall include all underground utilities, storm sewers, streets, curbs and gutters, sidewalks and any other items of street improvement specified in the plans and specifications. 
(b)  When the required final approval has been granted and the approved plans and specifications have been placed on file in the office of the city manager and the proper bond posted as specified, the city manager shall then issue a permit for the improvement. 
(Code 1973, § 33-19; Code 1982, § 32-19) 
Sec. 36-40. - Term of permit. 
    A permit shall be valid for six months from the date that it is issued; except the city manager may renew any permit for good reason shown. 
(Code 1973, § 33-20; Code 1982, § 32-20) 
Sec. 36-41. - Inspections. 
    Inspection service shall be maintained at all times by the city to ensure the approved standards of the city are maintained as given in the approved plans and specifications for the project are complied with. 
(Code 1973, § 33-21; Code 1982, § 32-21) 
Sec. 36-42. - Construction standards. 
    All road construction in the city shall conform to the requirements as set forth in the state department of highway, road and bridge specifications of July 1, 1978, and the Virginia Department of Highways Road Design and Standards, 1978 edition, hereafter referred to as the city road construction standards. 
(Code 1973, § 33-22; Code 1982, § 32-22) 
Sec. 36-43. - Data sheets. 
    The city manager shall maintain a data sheet, giving all information of the required public utilities; the dates of completion; the names of the indemnity or surety companies; the amount of the bond; space for notations of inspections and approval or rejection. These data sheets shall be supplied to each department as a reminder and a guide, and a copy shall be attached to the bond and periodically brought up to date to reflect the necessary information. 
(Code 1973, § 33-23; Code 1982, § 32-23) 
Sec. 36-44. - Final approval of construction. 
(a)  Final approval by the city manager shall be granted only after a field inspection of the completed construction. 
(b)  Final approval by the city manager shall constitute eligibility for maintenance by the city, but in no sense shall require it. 
(Code 1973, § 33-24; Code 1982, § 32-24) 
Sec. 36-45. - Acceptance by city. 
    When a project has been constructed in accordance with the engineering and material requirements of the city road construction standards, upon recommendation of the city manager, the council can accept such street for maintenance and incorporation into the street system of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 33-25; Code 1982, § 32-25) 
Sec. 36-46. - Street name. 
    A city street name shall be assigned to any road accepted by the council, and it shall be added to the official list of the city streets on file in the office of the building inspector. 
(Code 1973, § 33-26; Code 1982, § 32-26) 
Secs. 36-47-36-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 36-66. - Permit; fees. 
(a)  No person shall damage, destroy, cut or dig in or on or drill or excavate under any part of any street, sidewalk or other public property within the corporate limits for the purpose of installing, connecting, locating, relocating or repairing any pipe, main, conduit, cable, wire, pole, sign or support or for any other purpose, unless and until such person has obtained a permit from the department of public works. 
(b)  Fees for excavating shall be as established by the city council which shall schedule fees by resolution. 
(Code 1973, § 33-27; Code 1982, § 32-27) 
Sec. 36-67. - Standards. 
    All excavations into any road in the city shall be done in accordance with section 36-42. 
(Code 1973, § 33-28; Code 1982, § 32-28) 
Sec. 36-68. - Roadway closure. 
    Unless specifically authorized by the city manager, no excavation shall be made in such a manner as to close more than one-half of any roadway. The first section of the excavation shall be filled and placed in proper condition for travel before the second section is excavated. 
(Code 1973, § 33-29; Code 1982, § 32-29) 
Sec. 36-69. - Restoration. 
    Subject to approval by the city manager, all public and private property shall be restored to condition as good as or better than before excavation or other work was commenced. All portions of any street excavated shall be put in condition as good as or better than before excavation was made. The excavation shall be backfilled with approved material and thoroughly rammed (and puddle, if required) within 48 hours after making any connections or repairs. The ramming shall be done in six-inch layers. All rubbish and foreign material shall be removed within the time designated for the completion of the work. 
(Code 1973, § 33-30; Code 1982, § 32-30) 
Sec. 36-70. - Correction of dangerous conditions by city. 
    Should any excavation or trench become dangerous to persons or property for any reason or interfere with traffic in any unnecessary manner, the necessary filling, shoring, repairs and like work may be done by the department of public works and the costs charged to and collected from the holder of the permit in the case. 
(Code 1973, § 33-31; Code 1982, § 32-31) 
Secs. 36-71-36-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TEMPORARY STORAGE SITES 

Sec. 36-99. - Requirements. 
    No permit is issuable under the provisions of this chapter without a provision for temporary storage of equipment and materials to be used in the work, if such storage is necessary in the performance of the work. The applicant for such permit shall exhibit a written permission or lease to use any land for a storage site, private or public, detailing the terms, but not necessarily the consideration therefor. The permit shall limit the use of a storage site to a certain day but for good cause, such use may be extended. Such application shall be accompanied by a corporate bond or cash deposit in the principal sum of $100,000.00, conditioned upon the removal of equipment and materials and the restoration of the grounds. A further condition of the bond or deposit shall provide that in event there is a default, after ten days' notice, the city may make such removals and restorations and be compensated therefor by the surety or from the cash deposit. In the event no necessity for storage was foreseen at the time of application for a permit but such need arose subsequently thereto, the permittee shall apply for an amended permit to meet the conditions imposed by this section. Failure to so apply within three days from the beginning of such temporary storage shall be cause for a cease and desist order directed to the use of such storage site. The director of public works is authorized to initiate a suit for the restraining order to obtain compliance with the conditions set out in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 32-32; Ord. No. 599) 
Secs. 36-100-36-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SAFETY STANDARDS FOR UNDERGROUND INSTALLATION OF UTILITIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 42; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq. 

Sec. 36-127. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to enumerate the policies of the city and utility operators serving the city for use in the effective prevention of construction-related accidents resulting in and/or from utility line disruptions. 
(Code 1982, § 32-33; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-128. - Goals and objectives. 
    This article is enacted in order to: 
(1)  Facilitate the protection of persons and property from death or injury which may result from the destruction of, disruption of, or damage to underground utility lines during excavation or demolition. 
(2)  Protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the community by preventing the interruption of essential services resulting from the destruction of, disruption of, or damage to underground utility lines during excavation or demolition. 
(Code 1982, § 32-34; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-129. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article are intended to encompass: 
(1)  All utility operators serving any portion of or maintaining any utility line within, the city, and the representatives thereof. 
(2)  All contractors performing demolition or excavation on any private property, public right-of-way, or public easement within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 32-35; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-130. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Blasting means the use of an explosive to excavate. 
    Contractor means any person, including a subcontractor, who contracts with an operator or property owner, public or private, for the purpose of engaging in excavation, demolition or blasting. 
    Demolition means the razing of any structure above the existing grade, or the demolition of any structure below the existing grade. 
    Emergency means any condition which may cause an interruption of essential services resulting from the destruction of, disruption of, or damage to underground utility lines. The term "emergency" is classified as less severe than the term "hazardous." 
    Excavate means the movement or removal of earth, using mechanized equipment or blasting, and includes auguring, backfilling, digging, ditching, drilling, grading, plowing-in, pulling-in, ripping, scraping, trenching and tunneling. 
    Hazardous means any condition which may cause an interruption of essential services and, in addition, may result in death or injury to persons or property due to destruction of, disruption of, or damage to underground utility lines. The term "hazardous" is classified as more severe than the term "emergency." 
    Mechanized equipment means powered equipment used to excavate, and includes equipment used for plowing-in or pulling-in cable or pipe. 
    Operator means any person who furnishes or transports any of the following materials or services by means of a utility line: 
(1)  Flammable, natural, toxic, or, corrosive gas. 
(2)  Petroleum, petroleum products and hazardous liquids. 
(3)  Electricity. 
(4)  Sanitary sewer. 
(5)  Communications. 
(6)  Water. 
    Property owner means any person who owns fee title to or leases a given area of land, excluding, however, any recorded easement or right-of-way. 
    Utility line means any underground conduit and its related facilities, including pipe or cable, by which an operator furnishes or transports materials or services. 
    Working days means Monday through Friday, excluding, however, any public and legal holidays. 
(Code 1982, § 32-36; Ord. No. 651) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-131. - Violations. 
(a)  Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a criminal penalty not to exceed 30 days' imprisonment or by a fine not to exceed $300.00, or both. Each day a violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  If, during excavation or demolition, an underground utility line is damaged by any person who has failed to comply with any provision of this article, any permit acquired through the city to perform work related to such excavation or demolition (including permits for building, grading, blasting, plumbing, electrical and/or mechanical) may be revoked and any fees paid to the city for such permit may be forfeited. In order to continue work, a new application for a permit must be filed; plans of the proposed excavation or demolition must be reexamined; the location of all existing utility lines must be verified in writing by each operator having facilities in the area of proposed excavation or demolition; and new fees, if forfeited, must be paid. 
(c)  Any person who is convicted of a violation of any provision of this article which resulted in damage to an existing utility line shall be subject to suspension or revocation of any license or permit to perform related work for a period not to exceed 12 months, if so convicted two or more times within a 12-month period. Furthermore, no subsequent permits or licenses to perform such related work shall be issued to such convicted persons during that suspension or revocation period. 
(Code 1982, § 32-37; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-132. - Applicability of existing ordinances. 
(a)  No provision of this article shall exclude any person from complying with the requirements and provisions of any existing ordinances including those of this Code, the State Corporation Commission, and the Office of Pipeline Safety of the U.S. Department of Transportation or the U.S. Department of Labor. 
(b)  In cases of conflict between this article and any other parts of this Code, this article takes precedence. 
(Code 1982, § 32-38; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-133. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The administrative authority of this article shall be the director of the department of public works and such duly appointed agents as may be authorized by the director, any one of whom may perform the tasks and may make inspections required by this article and may take steps as may be reasonably necessary to enforce its provisions. 
(Code 1982, § 32-39; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-134. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to any property owner who, without the aid of a contractor, is performing work within the boundaries of such owner's property which does not require the acquisition of any permit issued by the city. 
(b)  The requirements of section 36-135 shall not apply to any person acting as or for the operator of a damaged line in making repairs to its own underground facilities or repairs to the streets or alleys themselves in a condition of emergency when such repairs must be made within a shorter period of time than that provided for in section 36-135(a); provided this exemption from obtaining information shall not excuse the person making the excavation from any liability for damages caused by the negligence of such person. 
(Code 1982, § 32-40; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-135. - Demolition or excavation-Prior notice. 
(a)  Contractors shall notify all operators who maintain underground utility lines in the area of the proposed excavation or blasting at least two working days, but not more than ten working days, prior to commencement of such excavation or demolition. This notification shall consist at least of the following: 
(1)  The contractor's name and telephone number. 
(2)  The name of the person for whom the proposed work is being done. 
(3)  The date and approximate time work is to commence. 
(4)  The location and approximate depth of proposed work. 
(5)  The nature of work to be done. 
(6)  The contractor's field representative or field contact, if any. 
(7)  Any special remarks. 
(b)  The telephone number to be utilized for serving notice to operators as required in subsection (a) of this section shall be located at least on the approved site plan, subdivision plan, or engineering plan which is to be at the site during excavation or demolition as required in section 36-136(c). 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any contractor to commence excavation or demolition on any property without first receiving clearance for excavation from each operator as provided in section 36-137(a). 
(Code 1982, § 32-41; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-136. - Same-Performance. 
(a)  Verification that rough grading is to within six inches of finished grade must be provided to the operator in writing by the contractor or property owner before such operator shall commence excavation for the installation of its utility lines. 
(b)  When excavation approaches the estimated location of any existing utility line which shall have been previously located horizontally as provided in section 36-137(a), the exact location of such existing utility line must be determined by adequately exposing same by hand digging within the proposed limits of excavation before excavation may resume. To prevent damage to such exposed existing utility line or the protective coating, proper supports shall be provided where required. 
(c)  Any contractor performing excavation or demolition is required to have an approved site plan, subdivision plan or engineering plan indicating the plan view of all known existing and proposed utility lines, with the exception of house service laterals, at the site during excavation or demolition. 
(d)  Any person who is designated to operate mechanized equipment for the purpose of excavation or demolition shall not perform such excavation or demolition until such person has examined the plan provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(e)  The act of obtaining information, as required by this article, shall not excuse any person making any excavation or demolition from doing so in a careful and prudent manner, nor shall it excuse such person from liability for any damage resulting from negligence of such person. 
(Code 1982, § 32-42; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-137. - Excavation. 
(a)  An operator who has received notification of a proposed excavation pursuant to section 36-135(a) and who has received, if applicable, verification of site grading pursuant to section 36-136(a) shall provide clearance for excavation to the contractor before such excavation may commence by: 
(1)  At least one hour prior to the commencement of the proposed excavation, horizontally locating its utility lines at the site, and notifying the contractor that this marking has been accomplished; or 
(2)  Notifying the contractor that the proposed excavation will not affect its existing utility lines. 
(b)  Horizontal location of utility lines at the site of excavation shall consist of a permanent marking system approved by the department of public works, or the state corporation commission, or a temporary marking system approved by the city manager, clearly and definitely indicating the horizontal location of the operator's facilities. 
(c)  To expedite horizontal location of utility lines, each operation shall: 
(1)  Provide locating services to mark all facilities affected by the excavation. 
(2)  Provide to designing engineers horizontal location data on its utility lines prior to the field survey for designing new work so such information on existing utility lines may be included in survey notes. 
(3)  Have the option to allow the locating crew of another operator to horizontally locate such facilities provided clearance to do so has been given in writing. 
(4)  Indicate the horizontal location of their utility lines on a site map, if requested by the contractor. 
(d)  When trenches excavated for the installation of gas pipelines are backfilled, a continuous tape or similarly effective device shall be installed after tamping 18 inches above all direct burial plastic mains and 12 inches above services, stubs and stub extensions. The tap shall be not less than three inches wide, brilliant in color and imprinted with words clearly defining the utility line as "gas." The tape shall be impregnated with metal so that locating equipment can readily pick it up. The remainder of the backfill may then be placed. 
(e)  When repairs are made to underground gas pipelines, and/or the tape and related requirements, as provided in subsection (d) of this section, have been disrupted or severed during excavation, such tape shall be installed or replaced at the completion of repairs prior to backfilling. 
(Code 1982, § 32-43; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-138. - Demolition. 
    An operator who received notification of a proposed demolition, pursuant to section 36-135(a), shall ensure clearance for demolition by: 
(1)  Disconnecting, or causing to be disconnected, as agreed upon by the operator and contractor, all of its utility lines to the structure to be demolished, as well as capping where necessary. 
(2)  Advising the contractor of the appropriate means of ensuring adequate protection for its other utility lines in the vicinity which might be subject to unusual stress during the demolition. 
(3)  Notifying, or causing to be notified, the contractor that such disconnection has been accomplished or that its utility lines will not be affected by such demolition. 
(Code 1982, § 32-44; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-139. - Standards and procedures. 
(a)  The horizontal location of all existing underground utility lines and those underground utility lines proposed by any operator shall be indicated on all site plans, subdivision plans, or engineering plans prior to city approval. 
(b)  Depending upon the size and importance of the utility line to be affected, the affected operator shall determine whether or not an inspection by its representative at the site of excavation is necessary during the crossing of its utility lines. 
(c)  Meetings shall be scheduled by the city manager to be held at least quarterly. Those in attendance shall be the utility operator, the contractor, and the city representatives. Proposed projects of excavation or demolition, problems incurred on excavation projects during the previous time period and any other information pertaining to the operation of this article may be discussed. 
(d)  Preconstruction meetings between contractors and utility operators should be scheduled prior to all excavation projects. 
(Code 1982, § 32-45; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-140. - Responsibilities of contractor. 
(a)  Communication between the job site and the contractor's base office shall be maintained at all times through the use of a two-way radio system or some other means approved by the director of public works. 
(b)  When any person damages a utility line or its protective coating or accidentally exposes or severs a utility line during excavation or demolition, an emergency condition shall be deemed to exist and the operator of such utility line shall be directly notified at that time. 
(c)  When any gas or flammable liquid utility line is severed or damaged to the extent that there is escapement of its contents, a hazardous condition shall be deemed to exist and the operator of such utility line and the director of public works of the city shall be immediately notified. 
(d)  Contractors shall display in plain sight on the instrument or control pane, or dash of all trucks and mechanized equipment operated by them, the current telephone number which is to be utilized to serve a hazardous condition notice as required in subsection (c) of this section. 
(e)  The telephone numbers to be utilized in serving an emergency condition notice as required in subsection (b) of this section shall be located at least on the approved site plan, subdivision plan, or engineering plan which is to be at the site during excavation or demolition as required by section 36-136(c). 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to backfill around a damaged utility line, as described in subsection (b) or (c) of this section until the operator of such utility line has been notified of such incident and has repaired the damage and/or has given clearance to backfill in writing. 
(g)  During an emergency or hazardous condition, it shall be lawful to excavate without using blasting, if notification, as required in section 36-135(a), is given as soon as reasonably possible. 
(Code 1982, § 32-46; Ord. No. 651) 
Sec. 36-141. - Responsibilities of operator. 
(a)  All operators shall make available on a 24-hour basis adequate emergency response crews including answering personnel, radio dispatchers, appliance service personnel, and utility repair crews capable of performing all work tasks necessary to cope with emergency or hazardous situations. The number of emergency work crews shall be determined by the operator based upon reasonable response time (one hour maximum to emergency scene during other than work hours) and the number and frequency of experiences recorded. 
(b)  All reports of hazardous conditions received by operators shall be reported immediately to the director of public works for the city. All reports of hazardous conditions received by the director of public works shall be reported immediately to the appropriate operator. 
(c)  Emergency shutoff valves shall be provided for all new gas service line installations such that: 
(1)  All gas services supplying inside meters shall be equipped with an outside shutoff at the curb or property line. Access shall be through a stopcock box, the top of which is flush with the surrounding grade. 
(2)  Steel or copper services to outside meters shall be equipped with an outside shutoff, as provided in subsection (c)(1) of this section, and an aboveground shutoff at the meter. 
(3)  Plastic services to outside meters shall be equipped with an outside shutoff at the meter. 
(d)  The decision to shut off a utility line during a hazardous condition shall be vested in an appropriate representative of the utility company concerned. When time permits, the city manager or designated representative shall be notified before the operator decides whether or not to shut off a utility line during a hazardous condition. 
(e)  When adequate operator emergency response crews are not available during a hazardous condition, the operator involved shall employ the director of public works to take the necessary action to shut off specific utility line valves or breakers serving the area. 
(1)  In order to facilitate this, the department of public works shall have knowledge of and access to emergency shutoff valves and breakers. In addition, effective 90 days after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the appropriate staff of that department shall be trained in the use of implements employed to shut off a utility line during a hazardous condition. Information and training is to be provided by and through the cooperation of utility representatives. 
(2)  Only the appropriate utility line representatives shall be permitted to reopen any valve or breaker which was closed during such a hazardous condition and only after a thorough check has indicated that it is safe to place the affected lines back into service. 
(3)  The provisions of this subsection shall not be mandatory upon the operators of flammable, natural, toxic, or corrosive gas transmission pipelines. 
(Code 1982, § 32-47; Ord. No. 651) 
Secs. 36-142-36-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC PARKING LOTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 26. 

Sec. 36-166. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking lot means any surface area used for pedestrian ways, loading and standing spaces, aisles, entrances or exits on private property maintained for the parking of motor vehicles, excepting on a street, alley or other public place, where such parking is permitted upon payment of compensation or is made available free of charge to employees, patrons, clients or customers of any place of business or institution. The term "parking lot," as used in this article, also embraces the definitions for the terms "parking lot" and "public parking lot" found in section 48-2. 
(Code 1982, § 32-48; Ord. No. 618) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-167. - Required maintenance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or extend to public use a parking lot in the city which is in disrepair by reason of potholes, excavations or broken surfaces which constitute a hazard to the health and safety of users or which may reasonably cause damage to vehicles operated thereon. 
(Code 1982, § 32-49; Ord. No. 618) 
Sec. 36-168. - Notice of violation. 
    Wherever a parking lot is in disrepair, the director of public works shall give the owner or agent written notice. Such notice shall require the correction of such disrepair within 30 days. 
(Code 1982, § 32-50; Ord. No. 618) 
Sec. 36-169. - Failure to make repairs; assessment of costs. 
    If correction of any disrepair of a parking lot complained of is not made by the owner or agent within the required 30 days, the director of public works shall cause the disrepair to be corrected, and the cost shall be assessed against the owner of such parking lot. 
(Code 1982, § 32-51; Ord. No. 618) 
Sec. 36-170. - Assessment to constitute lien. 
    The assessment provided in section 36-169, if not promptly paid, shall constitute a lien on such property. Such lien shall be promptly recorded in the land records of the county by the city treasurer and such lien and costs of its recording shall be collected in the same manner as tax liens. 
(Code 1982, § 32-52; Ord. No. 618) 
Secs. 36-171-36-193. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY USE FEE 

Sec. 36-194. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Access lines includes residence and business telephone lines and other switched common lines connecting a customer's or end user's premises located in the city to the end office switch, but does not include local, state and federal government lines, access lines used to provide service to users as part of the state universal service plan, interstate and intrastate dedicated WATS lines, special access lines, off-premises extensions, and official lines used by certificated providers of telecommunications services for administrative, testing, intercept and verification purposes, or commercial mobile radio service lines. 
    Certificated provider of telecommunications services or certificated provider means a public service corporation holding a certificate issued by the State Corporation Commission of Virginia to provide local exchange or inter-exchange telephone service. 
    Public rights-of-way use fee means a fee charged and billed monthly to the ultimate end user of each access line of a certificated provider of local exchange telephone service, the rate of which fee shall be established annually by the Virginia Department of Transportation in the manner specified in Code of Virginia, § 56-468.1. 
(Code 1982, § 32-53; Ord. No. 1617, 8-10-1998) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-195. - Public rights-of-way use fee. 
(a)  Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 56-468.1, as amended, the city elects to adopt the public rights-of-way use fee provided for by said code section. Accordingly, there is hereby imposed upon each access line of every certificated provider of telecommunications services a public rights-of-way use fee in the amount to be calculated annually by the state department of transportation under Code of Virginia, § 56-468.1 C. 
(b)  Every certificated provider that provides local exchange telephone service to end users in the city shall collect the public rights-of-way use fee on a per-access-line basis by adding the fee to each end user's monthly bill for local exchange telephone service. 
(c)  Until the end user pays the public rights-of-way use fee to the certificated provider, the fee shall constitute a debt of the user that is owed to the city. Whenever an end user fails or refuses to pay the fee, the certificated provider shall notify the city treasurer of the end user's identity and the total amount of fees that the user has refused or failed to pay. Such notification of unpaid use fees shall be provided to the city treasurer within two months after the end of each calendar quarter. 
(d)  After an end user pays the public rights-of-way use fee to the certificated provider, the collected fee shall be deemed to be held in trust by the provider until remitted to the city treasurer. Within two months after the end of each calendar quarter, the certificated provider shall remit directly to the city treasurer all public use fees that it has collected from end users during the quarter. 
(e)  Every certificated provider shall keep complete records showing all public rights-of-way use fees collected in each calendar quarter. Such records shall be kept open for inspection by the city treasurer or designee. 
(Code 1982, § 32-54; Ord. No. 1617, 8-10-1998) 
Sec. 36-196. - Purpose; other allowable fees. 
    The public rights-of-way use fee shall be in lieu of, and not in addition to, the permit inspection and other fees of general application imposed under this Code on certificated providers of telecommunications services. No certificated provider of telecommunications services shall be required to pay such permit or inspection fees or any other city fees (except for zoning, subdivision, site plan and comprehensive plan fees of general application) as a condition of, or as compensation for, its use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 32-55; Ord. No. 1617, 8-10-1998) 
Sec. 36-197. - Other requirements. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall relieve any certificated provider from complying with the requirements and restrictions imposed by this Code, or by other law or regulations, regarding its use of and activities within public rights of way in the city, including but not limited to the placement, construction, repair, maintenance and removal of its facilities; provided that any permit or other permission required by this Code or city regulations that is sought by a certificated provider shall be granted or denied within 45 days of the submission of a complete application, and that any denial shall be accompanied by a written explanation of the reasons for the denial and the actions required to cure the denial. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall affect the amount payable by a certificated provider for the right to locate towers, place facilities, or otherwise use property of the city other than public rights-of-way. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall affect the authority of the city to impose a franchise fee upon cable television franchisees, or the obligation of such franchisees to pay the franchise fee imposed upon them pursuant to chapter 10. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall affect the authority of the city to impose a franchise fee upon persons who locate facilities or otherwise use public rights-of-way for purposes other than the provision of local exchange or inter-exchange telephone service or the provision of cable television service. 
(Code 1982, § 32-56; Ord. No. 1617, 8-10-1998) 
Chapter 38 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city as to land subdivision, §§ 17.26 through 17.35. 
Cross reference- Planning department, § 2-90 et seq.; buildings, ch. 6; condominiums, § 6-48 et seq.; housing, ch. 22; outdoor lighting, § 14-127 et seq.; water recreation facilities, § 8-425 et seq.; utilities, ch. 42; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36; street improvements, § 36-38 et seq.; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq.; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Land subdivision and development, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2240 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a minor public street, primarily designed to serve as access to the side or rear of those properties whose principal frontage is on some other street. 
    Condominium means the ownership of single units in a multiunit organization, consisting of land and building, in which the owner has title to own such unit and, with the owners of other units, has an individual, undivided interest in the common areas and facilities that serve the development. 
    Condominium project means a real estate development, plan or project, whereby a group of apartments, rooms, offices or other commercial or noncommercial units, existing or proposed, whether the unit involves a single structure attached to or detached from other units or is in one or more multiple unit structures on single or contiguous parcels of real estate are offered or proposed to be offered for sale. 
    Cooperative means the individual ownership of stock in a corporation with the right, through a proprietary lease, to occupy a unit in an apartment building or other multiunit development. 
    Cul-de-sac means a local street with only one outlet and having an appropriate terminal for the safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose. 
    Street means a strip of land subject to vehicular or pedestrian traffic and providing direct or indirect means of access to property, including but not limited to road, lane, drive, trail, court, place, terrace, alley, avenue, highway, boulevard or any other thoroughfare. 
    Street, public, means an existing or platted street graded and paved or to be graded and paved, and dedicated for the use of the general public. 
    Street width means the shortest distance between the lines which delineate the right-of-way of a street. 
    Subdivision means a division of land into two or more lots for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all changes in street or lot lines or the consolidation of two or more lots or parcels. 
(Code 1982, § 31-1; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-2. - Authority. 
    This chapter was adopted pursuant to the terms and provisions of the Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2240 et seq. and the Charter of the city, section 17.26 et seq. 
(Code 1982, § 31-2; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-3. - Applicability; plats required; recordation. 
    Any tract of land lying wholly or partly within the corporate limits of the city shall be subdivided, as provided for in this chapter, and a plat of such subdivision with reference to known or permanent monuments shall be made in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter. A copy of the plat shall be recorded in the office of the clerk of the circuit court. 
(Code 1982, § 31-3; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-4. - Approval of plat required. 
    No person shall sell or transfer any land in a subdivision, nor shall a permit for the erection of a structure or the installation of public improvements be granted for any area laid out wholly or partly within the corporate limits of the city, until a final subdivision plat, prepared in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter, shall have been approved by the planning commission and recorded with the clerk of the circuit court, unless such subdivision was lawfully created prior to the adoption of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 31-4; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-5. - Recordation of plat subject to approval. 
    The clerk of the circuit court shall not file or record any plat or any copy required by this chapter to be recorded, unless such plat or copy shall have been approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Recordation shall not be valid unless such approval is evidenced on the plat or copy and unless the plat is presented for recordation prior to expiration of the validity period of plat approval, all in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 31-5; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Secs. 38-6-38-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REQUIREMENTS FOR PLATS 

Sec. 38-29. - Submission of plats. 
    Copies of all plats required by the provisions of this article shall be submitted to the office of the planning department. The number of copies required for submission shall be determined by the planning director. 
(Code 1982, § 31-6; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-30. - Preliminary and final plats required. 
(a)  Preliminary survey documents. As the first step in the subdivision process, the applicant shall provide an accurate survey of existing features on and around the site, as provided for in section 48-1135(1). 
(b)  Preparation. Preliminary and final plats or combined preliminary-final plats shall be required and every such plat shall be prepared by a registered surveyor or registered engineer duly authorized by the state to prepare such plates. 
(Code 1982, § 31-7; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982; Ord. No. 1334, 11-12-1990) 
Sec. 38-31. - Conditions for approval of plat. 
    No plat of any subdivision shall be approved unless the land included within the subdivision is suitable for the various purposes for which it is intended to be used, and in particular, unless all land intended as building sites can be used safely for building purposes without danger from flood or other inundation or from any other menace to health, safety or public welfare. However, when plans for elimination of such dangers are approved by the planning commission and the accomplishments thereof are provided for in the same manner as set forth for the other physical improvements in article IV of this chapter, or in some other manner acceptable to the commission, such subdivision may be approved. 
(Code 1982, § 31-8; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-32. - Preliminary plats. 
    Preliminary plats shall be submitted to the planning commission for preliminary approval provided the provisions of this chapter are complied with in the preparation and submittal. Approval of preliminary plats shall be valid for a period of six months from the date and such approval shall not be considered to be acceptance of such plats for recordation. 
(Code 1982, § 31-9; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-33. - Final plats. 
(a)  Final plats shall be submitted to the planning commission for approval. In the case of minor adjustments to property lines which do not involve the creation of any new lots or parcels, and which are in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and chapter 48, pertaining to zoning, the planning commission may delegate approval authority to the planning director to approve such plats, following appropriate review by the other city departments. 
(b)  Approval of each final plat shall be evidenced on the plat by the signatures of the chair or vice-chair of the planning commission and the date of approval of the plat by the commission or planning director, provided: 
(1)  Such plats conform to the preliminary plats, if any, as approved, to the provisions of this article, and to the requirements of the planning commission's approval action, if any; and 
(2)  All physical improvements required by the provisions of article IV of this chapter for the subdivision so platted shall have been installed at the expense of the subdivider, except that in lieu of actual installation of the physical improvements, the subdivider shall have submitted an acceptable form of agreement and/or bond with surety in amount equal to the total cost of such improvements guaranteeing that the required improvements will be installed within a designated reasonable length of time. Bond, surety and choice of guarantee shall be established by the director of public works, according to the nature and extent of the improvements required. 
(c)  Approval of the final plats of subdivisions or sections shall not be deemed the acceptance by the city of any street, alley or other public space shown on the plats and shall be null and void if copies of the plats are not offered for recordation within six months after the date of approval, unless an application for extension of time is requested in writing and granted by the director of planning. Evidence of such recordation shall be provided by the subdivider to the directors of planning and public works to issuance of other permits required for development or occupancy of the property involved. 
(Code 1982, § 31-10; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-34. - General regulations. 
    The following shall be considered minimum requirements and shall be varied only for specific reasons, stated of record by the planning commission in connection with the final approval of the plat to which related: 
(1)  Master plan conformance. Proposed subdivision within the corporate limits of the city shall conform to such parts of the official master plan of the city, as exist at the time of approval of the final plats. 
(2)  Subdivision names. The names of new subdivisions or renaming of subdivisions shall not duplicate or too closely approximate the names of existing subdivisions or place names within the city. Applicants shall submit the proposed name to the historical commission in care of the planning department for review and comment on appropriateness. The historical commission shall report its recommendation within 14 days of the transmittal to the historical commission, in writing to the planning commission. Conflict in project naming shall be resolved by the planning commission. 
(3)  Street names. Names of new streets shall not duplicate existing or platted street names unless the new street is a continuation of or in alignment with an existing or platted street. Street names may be provided by the planning commission, subject to approval by the city council. 
(4)  Building sites. Building sites shall have frontage on existing or recorded public streets and shall have the dimensions and areas in the provisions of this Code relative to zoning. Orientation of houses shall be shown for all new lots. 
(5)  Easements. Easements for utilities and other public use purposes of appropriate widths for the purpose intended shall be provided. 
(6)  Street layout. Streets shall be provided to give access to adjoining acreage and to connect with the principal streets in adjoining subdivisions or to connect with existing or proposed streets, as determined by the planning commission. Reserve strips intended to protect the use of dead-end and boundary streets are prohibited. Cul-de-sac streets shall not exceed 400 feet in length and shall be provided with a turnaround with a minimum right-of-way radius of 50 feet. Blocks in general shall not be longer than 1,000 feet between street intersections unless warranted by some unusual condition. Only two new pipestem lots shall be permitted to be subdivided from any existing lot. 
(7)  Street right-of-way. Street right-of-way width shall conform to the master plan and the applicable provisions of the chapter pertaining to zoning. No street right-of-way shall be less than 50 feet wide, except where permitted by this chapter. When a subdivision abuts one side of any street the subdivider shall not be required to dedicate more than one-half of any right-of-way necessary to make the street comply with the maximum width fixed for same. 
(8)  Public open spaces. Due consideration shall be given the allocation of suitable areas for schools, parks and playgrounds to be dedicated for public use or reserved for the common use of all residents of the proposed subdivision. In the interest of public welfare, the planning commission may require that at least five percent of the area of every subdivision, exclusive of streets, be set aside for recreational purposes. Where the tract contains less than ten acres, such reservation for open space may be combined with similar reservations in adjoining tracts. 
(9)  Trees. Whenever deemed necessary by the planning commission in consultation with the city arborist, street trees and/or additional screening shall be planted in a manner as approved by the city arborist. All trees to be preserved shall be shown on the final plat. 
(Code 1982, § 31-11; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982; Ord. No. 1792, § 31-11, 8-14-2006) 
Secs. 38-35-38-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PREPARATION OF PLATS 

Sec. 38-57. - Conformance with article provisions; exception. 
    Preliminary and final plats of a subdivision shall be prepared in accordance with the regulations set forth in this article, except that in the case of small subdivisions the preliminary and final plats may be combined at the discretion of the planning director, provided that the information required for both plats is included, and the size of the plat and drafting standards conform to the requirements for final plats. 
(Code 1982, § 31-12; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-58. - Preliminary plats. 
    Preliminary plats shall be drawn to a scale of not smaller than one inch equals 50 feet and may be of one or more sheets as necessary to show the following information: 
(1)  Name of subdivision, owner, subdivider, surveyor or engineer; date of drawing, number of sheets, north point and scale. 
(2)  Location of proposed subdivision by an insert map, at a scale of not less than two inches equals one mile, indicating adjoining roads and streets, their names and numbers, subdivisions and other landmarks. 
(3)  A boundary survey or existing survey of record, provided such survey shows a closure error of not more than 1 in 2,500; total acreage, acreage of subdivided area, number, location and approximate areas and dimensions of all building sites; existing buildings within the boundaries of the tract, name of owners and their property lines within the boundaries of the tract and adjoining such boundaries. 
(4)  All existing platted and proposed streets and easements, their names, numbers and width; location of all building setback lines, existing utilities, watercourses, their names, proposed method of water supply and sewage disposal and other pertinent data. 
(5)  Topography with two-foot-contour intervals, or lesser intervals, when required by the director of public works. 
(6)  Location of all historic trees and specimen trees, as defined in chapter 44 and, further, location of other trees that, in the opinion of the public works director or planning commission, should be preserved. 
(7)  Elevation of existing and proposed ground surfaces at all street intersections and points of major grade change along centerlines of streets, together with proposed grade lines connecting therewith when required by the director of public works. Elevations shall be used based on the National Geodetic Survey (NGS) datum. Benchmark evaluations and descriptions are available at the office of the director of public works for areas contiguous to the Tripps Run watershed. 
(Code 1982, § 31-13; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-59. - Final plats. 
    Final plats shall be drawn in ink on reproducible medium to a scale of 50 feet to the inch or larger, on a sheet not less than 81/2 inches by 14 inches or, if larger, not to exceed 24 inches by 36 inches and shall show the following information: 
(1)  Name of subdivision, city and state, owner, north point, the scale and date of drawing and number of sheets. If shown on more than one sheet, match lines shall clearly indicate where the several sheets join. An oblong space three inches by five inches high shall be reserved for the use of the approving authority. 
(2)  Location of proposed subdivision by an insert map at a scale of not less than two inches equal to one mile indicating adjoining roads and their names and numbers, subdivisions and other landmarks. 
(3)  A boundary survey with an error of closure within the limit of one in 10,000 related to the true meridian and showing the location of all monuments and type of material. The survey may be related to N.G.S. state grid north, if the coordinates of two adjacent corners of the subdivisions are shown. 
(4)  Certificate signed by the surveyor or engineer setting forth the source of title, of the owner of the land subdivided and the place of record of the last instrument in the chain of title. 
(5)  A statement to the effect that the subdivision, as appears in this plat, is with the free consent and in accordance with the desire of the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, which shall be signed by the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, and shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized to take acknowledgement of deeds. 
(6)  When the subdivision consists of land acquired from more than one source of title the outlines of the various tracts shall be indicated by dashed lines and identification of the respective tracts shall be placed on the plat. 
(7)  The accurate location and dimensions by bearings and distances with all curve data of all lot and street lines and centerlines of streets, boundaries of all easements, parks, school sites or other public areas; location of all building setback lines and the number and area of all building sites; all existing and platted streets, their names, numbers and width; watercourses and their names; names of owners and their property lines, both within the boundaries of the subdivision adjoining such boundaries. 
(8)  All dimensions shown in feet and decimals of a foot to the closest 1/100 of a foot; all bearings in degrees, minutes and seconds to the nearest ten seconds. 
(9)  The data for all curves along street frontages shall be shown in detail at the curve or in a curve data table containing the following: central angle, radius, arc, tangent, chord and chord bearing. 
(10)  Other information which may be required by the planning commission which relates to common ownership of land or to matters related to zoning. 
(Code 1982, § 31-14; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Secs. 38-60-38-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 38-77. - Conformance with article provisions. 
    The improvements required in subdivisions lying in whole or in part within the corporate limits of the city which include or involve any public street, any extension of the city sewer or water systems or any right-of-way connecting two public streets or any easements shall be made by the subdivider in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1982, § 31-15; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-78. - Standards and specifications for grading and surfacing. 
    All grading and surfacing shall be done and all curbs and gutters, sidewalks, storm and sanitary sewers, water and gas mains, underground electric power and communication lines, and all other items pertaining to the development of any street or alley shall be installed in strict accordance with the standards and specifications as specified by the director of public works. All underground utilities such as water, sewer, gas and electric power and communication lines shall be in place prior to final surfacing and acceptance of the street by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 31-16; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-79. - Drainage systems. 
    A drainage system shall be provided for as required by the director of public works, including culverts, lead and outlet drains, headwalls and any other structures that are necessary to provide adequate drainage of both natural water and stormwater for all streets and surrounding properties. 
(Code 1982, § 31-17; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-80. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Commercial areas. All streets which abut property which has business, industrial or transitional zoning designations shall have sidewalks. 
(b)  Residential areas. 
(1)  All streets abutting property which has multifamily, cluster of townhouse zoning designations shall have sidewalks. 
(2)  On all other streets abutting residentially zoned property, sidewalks shall be provided as follows: 
a.  Where sidewalks presently exist on the same side of the block; 
b.  Where safety considerations such as significant vehicular traffic or the need for safe pedestrian pathways to nearby public uses require them, such as schools, churches, parks, public transportation stops, and shopping. 
The procedures and policy as set out in the sidewalk policy shall be used here. 
(c)  City manager to provide traffic counts in vicinity of proposed construction. The city manager shall provide hourly and daily traffic counts current within six months, in the vicinity of the proposed construction. Additionally, a current map showing existing sidewalks and relationships to nearby public facilities and activities shall be provided. Nonbinding guidelines with respect to traffic density are as follows: 
(1)  Average weekday traffic (AWT) under 500 and AWT under 60 during peak hour, no sidewalk needed absent special circumstances. 
(2)  AWT between 500 and 5,000 and AWT between one and ten vehicles per minute during peak hour, sidewalk needed on one side. 
(3)  AWT above 5,000 and AWT above ten vehicles per minute during peak hour, sidewalks needed on both sides of the street. 
(Code 1982, § 31-18; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982; Ord. No. 1175, 3-9-1987) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; assessment for construction of sidewalks, § 36-7. 
Sec. 38-81. - Sanitary sewer and water systems. 
    Sanitary sewer and water systems shall be designed as required by the director of public utilities to service all lots in the proposed subdivision and shall be installed and connected to the municipal sewer and water systems with a connection for each lot and building site. 
(Code 1982, § 31-19; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-82. - Street signs. 
    Street signs of a design approved by the director of public works shall be installed at all street intersections. Street addresses shall be assigned by the director of public works. Street address numbers and/or letters shall be at least three inches high and shall be placed on each improved lot by the owner in a location visible from the appropriate street or drive. 
(Code 1982, § 31-20; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-83. - Monuments. 
    Monuments shall be placed in the ground at all corner and angle points in the outer lines of the subdivision, at all corner and angle points of property lines and at all tangent points of street intersections and at all points of angles and curvature in the right-of-way lines of all streets within the subdivision. At designated points in the outer lines of the subdivision and at least two points in each block such monuments shall be of stone or concrete not less than four inches square or four inches in diameter and at least 30 inches long. In all other locations the monuments shall be iron pipe not less than one-fourth inch or more than one inch in diameter. The top of all stone and concrete monuments shall be set not less than one inch or more than four inches above the finished grade of the ground surface at their respective locations. 
(Code 1982, § 31-21; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-84. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  All improvement plans and specifications shall conform to city requirements. 
(b)  Before the development of any required improvement in any subdivision is begun, the owner or proprietor shall file with the director of public works a complete plan and profile prepared by a surveyor or engineer duly certified to perform such services. The plan shall be drawn to a scale of 25 feet to the inch and the profile shall be drawn to a horizontal scale of 25 feet to the inch and a vertical scale of five feet to the inch, or as designated by the director of public works. On the plan shall be shown the location of the following: sidewalks, curb and gutter, storm and sanitary sewers, water and gas main, underground electric power and communication lines, parking spaces and all other contemplated improvements. On the profile shall be shown the proposed centerline grade of the street and alley, the size, depth and rate of grade of storm and sanitary sewers, the size and approximate depth of water and gas mains, and the approximate depth of electric power and communication lines. The director of public works may further require cross sections of the street or alley, same to be taken at each 50-foot station or other interval at all street intersections and any other points which may be required to establish properly the grade of the street. 
(Code 1982, § 31-22; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-85. - As-built plans to be filed. 
    Upon completion of the work on any required improvements and before acceptance or approval of same by the city, the owner shall file with the director of public works the required number of copies of the plan and profile of the improvements upon which shall be shown the actual location, as constructed, of all manholes, house connections, controls or cut-off valves, catchbasins, electric distribution transformers, switch gear, meter and telephone pedestals, air-conditioning apparatus, and any and all changes in the approved plans which may have been permitted by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 31-23; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-86. - Inspection during installation. 
    Periodic inspection during the installation of the physical improvements shall be made by a duly authorized city official to ensure conformity with the approved plans and specifications. The subdivider shall notify the proper administrative officers when each phase of the installation is completed and ready for inspection. 
(Code 1982, § 31-24; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-87. - Approval. 
    Upon completion of installation of the required improvements and approval of the as-built plan, the subdivider will be issued a certificate of approval by the director of public works. Such certificates shall operate as evidence for the release of any agreement or bond which may have been furnished for the guarantee of satisfactory installation of such improvements or parts thereof. 
(Code 1982, § 31-25; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-88. - Acceptance. 
    The installation of improvements in subdivisions, as required by this article, shall in no case serve to bind the city to accept such improvements for the maintenance, repair or operation, but such acceptance shall be subject to the existing regulations concerning the acceptance of each type of improvement. 
(Code 1982, § 31-26; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 38-89. - Vacation of plats. 
    Vacation of plats shall take place in accordance with section 17.33 of the city Charter, except the planning commission shall approve any consolidation of lots or parcels or the adjustment of property lines in accordance with this chapter, provided such consolidation or adjustment does not involve the loss of any public rights in any recorded streets, alleys, easements or other land devoted to or designated for public use. 
(Code 1982, § 31-27; Ord. No. 961, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 999, 2-22-1982) 
Chapter 40 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference- Authority of city to tax, § 2.02.
