    Professional and specialized occupation includes every person engaged in an occupation enumerated in section 40-495 or section 40-499. 
    Professional services means services performed by architects, attorneys-at-law, certified public accountants, dentists, engineers, land surveyors, surgeons, veterinarians, and practitioners of the hearing arts (the arts and sciences dealing with the prevention, diagnosis, treatment and cure or alleviation of human physical or mental ailments, conditions, diseases, pain or infirmities) and such occupations, and no others, as the state department of taxation may list in the BPOL guidelines promulgated pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3701. The state department of taxation shall identify and list each occupation or vocation in which a professed knowledge of some department of science or learning, gained by a prolonged course of specialized instruction and study, is used in its practical application to the affairs of others, either advising, guiding, or teaching them, and in serving their interests or welfare in the practice of an art or science founded on it. The term "profession" implies attainments in professional knowledge as distinguished from mere skill, and the application of knowledge to uses for others rather than for personal profit. 
    Purchases means all goods, wares and merchandise received for sale at each definite place of business of a wholesale merchant. The term "purchases" also include the cost of manufacture of all goods, wares and merchandise manufactured by any wholesale merchant and sold or offered for sale. A wholesale merchant may elect to report the gross receipts from the sale of manufactured goods, wares and merchandise, if it cannot determine the cost of manufacture or chooses not to disclose the cost of manufacture. 
    Real estate services means providing a service with respect to the purchase, sale, lease, rental, or appraisal of real property. 
    Repair service includes every person engaged in the business of repairing, renovation or servicing one or more of those items or articles enumerated in section 40-497. 
    Retail merchant includes every person engaged in the conduct of a business enumerated in section 40-498. The term "retail merchant" is further defined to mean any merchant who sells to others for their use only and not for resale. 
    Wholesale merchant includes every person engaged in the conduct of a business enumerated in section 40-500. The term "wholesale merchant" is further defined to mean every merchant who sells to others for resale only, or who sells to institutional, commercial or industrial users. 
(Code 1982, § 18-1; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3700.1. 
Sec. 40-457. - Authority to impose license tax. 
(a)  Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703 authorizes localities to enact an ordinance levying a local license (BPOL) tax and/or a fee for issuing a license. Every ordinance adopted or maintained by a locality which levies a license tax is required to be substantially similar to the provisions in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703.1. Further, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3703 and 58.1-3706 set statutory maximums for license rates and fees. 
(b)  The license tax imposed in this section is not an ad valorem tax. Gross receipts are used as the standard for fixing the amount of tax because gross receipts have been found to be the best indicator of the volume of the activity within the city. It is the intent of this definition of gross receipts to require to the fullest extent permitted by law the equitable taxation of every business, profession, trade or occupation, vocation, calling or activity (referred to collectively as "business"). No business or phase of a business conducted in the city shall escape taxation because the gross receipts attributable to that business are paid to a person located outside the city. Thus, in those instances where gross receipts otherwise attributable to a business or a phase of a business conducted within the city are actually paid to a person located outside of the city, the business shall be taxed based upon the gross receipts paid outside of the city which are attributable to the amount of activity conducted by the phase located in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18-1; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
State Law reference- Business, professional, occupational license, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3700 et seq. 
Sec. 40-458. - Tax levied. 
    Each and every year beginning with January 1 of each year and ending December 31 following, until otherwise changed, there are hereby levied and there shall be collected the annual license taxes hereinafter set forth in this section, except as otherwise specifically provided in this article, on persons conducting or engaged in any business, trade or occupation in the city hereinafter set forth in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 18-2(a); Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-459. - Situs of gross receipts. 
(a)  Gross receipts based on definite place of business within state. Except as otherwise provided by law, situs refers to the locality in which a person subject to a local license taxation for any business, profession, trade, occupation or calling has a definite place of business. If the person has a definite place of business in any other locality, then the other locality may impose a license tax on him, provided such other locality is otherwise authorized to impose a local license tax upon his business. When a BPOL tax is measured by gross receipts, the gross receipts included in the taxable measure are only those gross receipts attributed to the exercise of a privilege subject to licensure at a definite place of business within the state. Where activities are conducted outside of a definite place of business, such as during a visit to a customer location, gross receipts are attributed to the definite place of business from which such activities are initiated, directed, or controlled. The situs of gross receipts for different classifications of business are attributed to one or more definite places of business or offices. 
(b)  General rule. Whenever the tax or fee imposed by this section is measured by gross receipts, the gross receipts included in the taxable measure are only those gross receipts attributed to the exercise of a privilege subject to licensure at a definite place of business in the city. In case of business activities conducted outside of a definite place of business in the city, such as during a visit to a customer's location, gross receipts from such activities shall be attributed to the definite place of business from which such activities are initiated, directed or controlled. The situs of gross receipts for different license tax classifications of business shall be attributed to one or more definite places of business or offices as follows: 
(1)  The gross receipts of a contractor shall be attributed to the definite place of business at which the contractor services are performed, or if his services are not performed at any definite place of business, then the definite place of business from which his services are directed or controlled, unless the contractor is subject to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3715. 
(2)  The gross receipts of a retailer or wholesaler shall be attributed to the definite place of business at which sales solicitation activities occur, or if sales solicitation activities do not occur at any definite place of business, then the definite place of business from which sales solicitation activities are directed or controlled; however, a wholesaler or distribution house subject to a license tax measured by purchases shall determine the situs of its purchases by the definite place of business at which or from which deliveries of the purchased goods, wares and merchandise are made to customers. Any wholesaler who is subject to license tax in two or more localities and who is subject to multiple taxation because the localities use different measures, may apply to the department of taxation for a determination as to the proper measure of purchases and gross receipts subject to license tax in each locality. 
(3)  The gross receipts of a business renting tangible personal property are attributed to the definite place of business from which the tangible personal property is rented or, if the property is not rented from any definite place of business, then the definite place of business from which the rental of such property is managed. 
(4)  The gross receipts from the performance of services shall be attributed to the definite place of business at which the services are performed or, if not performed at any definite place of business, then to the definite place of business from which the services are directed or controlled. 
(c)  Apportionment. If the licensee has more than one definite place of business, and it is impractical or impossible to determine the definite place of business to which gross receipts should be attributed under the general rule of this section, the gross receipts of the business shall be apportioned between the definite place of business on the basis of payroll. Gross receipts shall not be apportioned to a definite place of business under the applicable general rule unless some activities occurred at, or were controlled from, such definite place of business. Gross receipts attributable to a definite place of business in another jurisdiction shall not be attributed to the city solely because the other jurisdiction does not impose a tax on the gross receipts attributable to the definite place of business in such other jurisdiction. A taxpayer may propose an alternative method of allocation and apportionment. The commissioner of the revenue may consider such alternative in apportioning gross receipts if the commissioner of the revenue finds such method reasonable. 
(d)  Interjurisdictional agreements. The commissioner of the revenue may enter into agreements with other political subdivisions of the state concerning the manner in which gross receipts shall be apportioned among definite places of business. However, the sum of the gross receipts apportioned by any such agreement shall not exceed the total gross receipts attributable to all of the definite places of business affected by the agreement. Upon notification by a taxpayer that the commissioner's method of attributing gross receipts is fundamentally inconsistent with the method of one or more political subdivisions in which the taxpayer is licensed to engage in business and that the difference has resulted, or is likely to result, in taxes on more than 100 percent of its gross receipts from all locations in the affected jurisdictions, the commissioner of the revenue shall make a good faith effort to reach an apportionment agreement with the other political subdivisions involved. 
(e)  Procedure when no agreement. If an agreement as provided in subsection (d) of this section cannot be reached, either the commissioner of the revenue or the taxpayer may seek an advisory opinion from the department of taxation pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3701; notice of the request shall be given to the other party. 
(f)  Procedure to prevent double assessment. Notwithstanding the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3993, when a taxpayer has demonstrated to a court that two or more political subdivisions of the state have assessed taxes on gross receipts that may create a double assessment within the meaning of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3986, the court shall enter such orders pending resolution of the litigation as may be necessary to ensure that the taxpayer is not required to pay multiple assessments, even though it is not then known which assessment is correct and which is erroneous. 
(Code 1982, § 18-2(b)-(f); Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
State Law reference- Situs of gross receipts, apportionment, agreements, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703.1 A.3. 
Sec. 40-460. - Persons subject to tax. 
(a)  Each and all of the taxes hereinafter imposed are in all cases imposed upon the privilege of doing business or exercising a profession, trade or occupation in the city, including all phases of the business, profession, trade or occupation conducted in the city. 
(b)  Every person shall apply for a license tax for each business or profession when engaging in a business in the city if: 
(1)  The person has a definite place of business in the city; 
(2)  The person maintains no definite place of business anywhere, but resides in the city; or 
(3)  The person maintains no definite place of business in the city but operates amusement machines, is an itinerant merchant, peddler, carnival or circus, pursuant to the Code of Virginia and this section, is a contractor pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3715, or is a public service corporation under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3731 and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-2690. 
(c)  A separate license is required for each definite place of business and for each business in the city; except a person engaged in two or more businesses or professions carried on at the same place of business may elect to obtain one license for all such businesses and professions if all of the following criteria are satisfied: 
(1)  Each business or profession is subject to licensure at the location and has satisfied any requirements imposed by state law or other provisions of this Code; 
(2)  All of the businesses or professions are subject to the same tax rate, or, if subject to different tax rates, the licensee agrees to be taxed on all businesses and professions at the highest rate; and 
(3)  The taxpayer agrees to supply such information as the commissioner of the revenue may require concerning the nature of the several businesses and their gross receipts. 
(Code 1982, § 18-3; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1525, 9-26-1995; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-461. - Exemptions from business license tax. 
    The following shall be exempt, in whole or in part, from the business license tax: 
(1)  Any public service corporation except as provided in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3731 or as permitted by other provisions of law; 
(2)  For selling farm or domestic products or nursery products, ornamental or otherwise, or for the planting of nursery products, as an incident to the sale thereof, outside of the regular market houses and sheds in the city, provided, such products are grown or produced by the person offering such products for sale; 
(3)  Upon the privilege or right of printing or publishing of any newspaper, magazine, newsletter or other publication issued daily or regularly at average intervals not exceeding three months, provided the publication's subscription sales are exempt from state sales tax; or operating or conducting any radio or television broadcasting station or service; 
(4)  On a manufacturer for the privilege of manufacturing and selling goods, wares and merchandise at wholesale at the place of manufacture; 
(5)  Upon a wholesaler for the privilege of selling goods, wares and merchandise to other persons for resale unless such wholesaler has a definite place of business or store in the city. This section shall not be construed as prohibiting imposition of a license tax on a peddler at wholesale; 
(6)  On or measured by receipts for management, accounting, or administrative service provided on a group basis under a nonprofit cost-sharing agreement by a corporation which is an agricultural cooperative association under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 13.1-312 et seq., or a member or subsidiary or affiliated association thereof, to other members of the same group. This exemption shall not exempt any such corporation from such license or other tax measured by receipts from outside the group; 
(7)  On or measured by receipts or purchases by a corporation which is a member of an affiliated group of corporations from other members of the same affiliated group. This exclusion shall not exempt affiliated corporations from such license or other tax measured by receipts or purchases from outside the affiliated group. This exclusion also shall not preclude a wholesale merchant's license tax on an affiliated corporation on those sales by the affiliated corporation to a nonaffiliated person, company, or corporation, notwithstanding the fact that the wholesale merchant's license tax would be based upon purchases from an affiliated corporation. Such tax shall be based on the purchase price of the goods sold to the nonaffiliated person, company, or corporation. As used in this article, the term "sales by the affiliated corporation to a nonaffiliated person, company or corporation" shall mean sales by the affiliated corporation to a nonaffiliated person, company or corporation where goods sold by the affiliated corporation or its agent are manufactured or stored in the state prior to their delivery to the nonaffiliated person, company or corporation; 
(8)  On any insurance company subject to taxation under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-2500 et seq., or any agent of such company; 
(9)  On any bank or trust company subject to taxation under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1200 et seq.; 
(10)  Upon a taxicab driver working for a taxicab company in the city, provided that such company has a business license under this article; 
(11)  On any blind person operating a vending stand or other business enterprise under the jurisdiction of the department for the visually handicapped, or a nominee of the state department for the blind and vision impaired, as set forth in Code of Virginia, § 51.5-98; 
(12)  On an accredited religious practitioner in the practice of the religious tenets of any church or religious denomination. The term "accredited religious practitioner" shall be defined as one who is engaged solely in praying for others upon accreditation by such church or religious denomination; 
(13)  a.  On or measured by receipts of a charitable nonprofit organization, except to the extent the organization has receipts from an unrelated trade or business the income of which is taxable under Internal Revenue Code, § 511 et seq. For the purpose of this subdivision, the term "charitable nonprofit organization" means an organization which is described in Internal Revenue Code, § 501(c)(3) and to which contributions are deductible by the contributor under Internal Revenue Code, § 170, except that educational institutions shall be limited to schools, colleges and other similar institutions of learning; 
b.  On or measured by gifts, contributions, and membership dues of a nonprofit organization. Activities conducted for consideration which are similar to activities conducted for consideration by for-profit businesses shall be presumed to be activities that are part of a business subject to licensure. For the purpose of this subdivision, the term "nonprofit organization" means an organization exempt from federal income tax under Internal Revenue Code, § 501 other than charitable nonprofit organizations; 
(14)  On any venture capital fund or other investment fund, except commissions and fees of such funds. Gross receipts from the sale and rental of real estate and buildings within the city remain taxable by the city, provided the city is otherwise authorized to tax such businesses and rental of real estate; 
(15)  Itinerant merchants who participate in a special event sponsored or run by a not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization, provided the event lasts no longer than four days, shall not be required to obtain a business license nor pay a gross receipts tax; 
(16)  Persons in the business of printing, other than persons engaged in the business of instant printing, photocopying, or similar businesses, shall be considered manufacturers and shall be entitled to the exemption from local business license taxation provided to manufacturers under state law. 
(Code 1982, § 18-3.5; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 40-462. - Procedures for obtaining license. 
    Every person liable for the payment of a license tax under the provisions of this article shall make application therefore in writing to the commissioner of the revenue at his office in the Harry E. Wells Building. The commissioner of the revenue shall furnish a license application form, which form shall be properly and fully executed by the applicant, and shall contain such information as may be required by the commissioner of the revenue. No license shall be issued to cover more than one place of business. All applicants shall be required to obtain a separate license for each place of business in which the business, profession, trade or occupation to be licensed is pursued. The commissioner of the revenue shall assess such applicant or other person of whom a license is required with the license tax required by this article and shall retain a copy of the license application. The commissioner of the revenue shall issue a license to the licensee, which shall be displayed at the place of business. 
(Code 1982, § 18-4; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 40-463. - Beginner's license. 
(a)  Every person beginning a business, profession, trade or occupation which is subject to a license tax under the provisions of this article, which is based in whole or in part on gross receipts or gross expenditures, shall estimate the amount of the gross receipts he will receive or the gross expenditures he will incur between the date of beginning business and the end of the then current license year and his license tax for the then current year shall be computed on such estimate. 
(b)  The commissioner of the revenue shall make a determination as to whether a reasonable estimate of gross receipts has been made, prior to the issuance of a beginner's license. In making a determination, the commissioner of the revenue shall take into account the size and location of the business, as well as the actual experience of reasonably similar businesses and other relevant factors. If the commissioner of the revenue determines that the applicant's estimate is unreasonable, the estimate of the commissioner of the revenue shall be the basis for computing the estimate. 
(c)  Whenever a license tax is computed upon the estimated gross receipts or gross expenditures, any incorrect estimate shall be subject to correction, and the commissioner of the revenue shall assess such person with an additional license tax found to be due after the end of that license year and shall, at the same time, correct the estimate for the then current year until a full year of operation shall have been completed. In case of an overestimate, the taxpayer shall be entitled to a credit upon has license tax payable in the following year. 
(d)  A grace period of 30 days shall be allowed from the date of beginning a business, before a penalty of ten percent shall be added to all license taxes imposed under the terms of this section. 
(e)  No interest shall accrue on an adjustment of estimated tax liability to actual liability at the conclusion of a base year. 
(Code 1982, § 18-5; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-464. - Applicants for license to give certain information. 
    Every applicant for a license to conduct any business, profession, trade or occupation under the provisions of this article shall furnish the commissioner of the revenue, in writing, with the correct name and trade name, if any, of the applicant, the correct residence of the applicant, the nature of the business, profession, trade or occupation to be pursued, the place where it is to be pursued, and any and all other pertinent information as may be required by the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1982, § 18-6; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-465. - Transferring licenses. 
(a)  Licenses issued under the provision of this article, except as otherwise provided, may be transferred from one person to another or from one location to another; provided no such transfer shall be valid unless and until notice in writing is given to the commissioner of the revenue of the proposed transfer, which notice shall contain the name, trade name, if any, and the address of the proposed transferee, the proposed new location, if any, as well as the time of the proposed transfer; and the commissioner of the revenue may approve such transfer upon being satisfied of the good faith thereof. Failure to notify the commissioner of the revenue of the transfer of a license within 30 days of such transfer shall invalidate such license and such invalidated license shall not be subject to refund as provided by section 40-471. 
(b)  It is specifically provided, however, that if the transferor's license for the current license year has been based on an estimate of gross receipts, or gross expenditures, as provided in section 40-463, that the transferor shall reveal his gross receipts or gross expenditures from the period he was in business during the current license year and if the accumulation of gross receipts by the transferor shall exceed the original estimate, the transferee shall be required to amend the license by an estimate of the gross receipts or gross expenditures he will incur between the day of beginning business and the end of the current license year. 
(Code 1982, § 18-7; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-466. - Compliance with zoning provisions. 
(a)  The commissioner of the revenue shall issue a license for conducting any business, profession, trade or occupation at a location where the conduct of such business, profession, trade or occupation is not prohibited by chapter 48, pertaining to zoning. 
(b)  All licenses issued shall be subject to verification to ascertain compliance with chapter 48, pertaining to zoning. Failure to comply shall be just cause for immediate revocation of the license by the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1982, § 18-8; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-467. - Minimum tax on gross receipts. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, businesses, professions, trades and occupations required to be licensed under this article with total annual gross receipts of less than $10,000.00 shall pay no tax, including the minimum tax. However, such businesses, trades and occupations shall file an annual business license application as required elsewhere in this article and shall be subject to all other provisions of this article. The commissioner of the revenue shall review the application and issue a business license if the application is in order. A business, trade or occupation required to be licensed under this article with total annual gross receipts of between $10,000.00 and $50,000.00 shall pay the minimum tax of $30.00 per each business. If a business files for a license based on an estimate of gross receipts, then the commissioner of the revenue shall correct the assessment pursuant to section 40-463, if necessary. This section shall not be applicable to any business, profession, trade or occupation which has a license based on other than gross receipts. 
(Code 1982, § 18-9; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1525, 9-26-1995; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-468. - Payment of taxes. 
    All license taxes may be paid on a quarterly basis where the amount of such tax is in excess of $1,000.00. The due date for payment of quarterly payments shall be on or before the first day of each calendar quarter. 
(Code 1982, § 18-10; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-469. - License requirements. 
    Whenever a license is required by law or whenever the general assembly shall levy a license tax on any business, employment or profession, it shall be unlawful to engage in such business employment or profession without first obtaining the required license. No business license under this article shall be issued until the applicant has produced satisfactory evidence that all delinquent business license, personal property, meals, short-term rental, transient occupancy, and admission taxes which have been assessed against the applicant by the city and owed by the business to the city have been paid. 
(Code 1982, § 18-11; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 40-470. - Business license tax records required; report of gross receipts; audit. 
(a)  Every person liable for a license tax under this article which is based on gross receipts or gross expenditures shall keep all records and accounts necessary to compute and to verify such gross receipts or gross expenditures and the report of such gross receipts or gross expenditures shall be taken from such records. All such records and general books of account shall be maintained and be open to inspection and examinations for the current year and for a period of three additional years. The accessing official shall assess the local license tax omitted because of fraud or failure to apply for a license for the current license year and the six preceding license years. 
(b)  Each licensee whose license is measured by gross receipts or gross expenditures shall submit to the commissioner of the revenue, not later than the March 1 of each year, a report of the business gross receipts or gross expenditures for the preceding year. In those cases in which the conduct of the business, trade or occupation involves operations subject to more than one rate or is computed on more than one base, as hereinafter set forth, the licensee is hereby required to maintain separate accounts for each such operation; provided, however, that the licensee may elect to maintain one account for all operations taxed on gross receipts, in which case the entire business taxed on gross receipts shall be computed at the highest rate applicable to any part of the business taxed on gross receipts. 
(c)  If any taxpayer fails to maintain the records required in this section, regularly supported by customary vouchers, the commissioner of the revenue shall estimate the taxpayer's gross receipts on the basis of the best evidence obtainable, and the commissioner of the revenue shall make an assessment on the basis of such evidence. 
(d)  The commissioner of the revenue may provide the taxpayer with the option to conduct a business tax audit in the taxpayer's office, if the records are maintained in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area. If the records are maintained outside the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area, copies of the appropriate books and records shall be sent to the commissioner of the revenue's office upon demand. 
(Code 1982, § 18-12; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-471. - Erroneous assessments; proration of license taxes; refund. 
(a)  The commissioner of the revenue is empowered to certify to the city treasurer any instance of erroneous assessments. Upon receipt of such certificate, the treasurer is directed to make a refund based upon the certification of the commissioner of the revenue. 
(b)  Licenses issued under the provisions of this article, except those measured by other than gross receipts, shall be subject to a refund where the licensee goes out of business before the end of the current license year. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, general or special, and regardless of the basis or method of measurement or computation, the city shall impose a license tax based on gross receipts on a business, trade, profession, occupation or calling, or upon a person, firm or corporation for any fraction of a year during which such person has permanently ceased to engage in such business, trade, profession, occupation or calling within the city. In the event a person ceases to engage in a business, trade, profession or calling within the city during a year for which a license tax based on gross receipts has already been paid, the taxpayer shall be entitled, upon application, to a refund for that portion of the license tax already paid, prorated on a monthly basis so as to ensure that the licensed privilege is taxed only for that fraction of the year during which it is exercised within the city. In no event shall the city be required to refund any part of a flat fee or minimum flat tax, or any of the minimum tax referred to in section 40-467. 
(c)  Interest on refunds of additional or omitted tax assessments is as follows, except as provided in section 40-463(e): Whenever an assessment of additional or omitted tax by the commissioner of the revenue is found to be erroneous, all interest and penalty charged and collected on the assessment found to be erroneous shall be refunded, together with interest on the refund from the date of payment or the due date, whichever is later, whether attributable to an amended return or other reason. Interest on any refund shall be paid at the same rate charged by the treasurer for late payment of taxes. No interest shall be paid on a refund or charged on a late payment, provided the refund or the late payment is made not more than 30 days from the date of the payment that created the refund or the due date of the tax, whichever is later. The refund, if in excess of $1,000.00, shall be made in the ensuing fiscal year. Refunds of $1,000.00 or less shall be made within 60 days of the application. Refunds shall only be made upon application. 
(Code 1982, § 18-13; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-472. - Appeals. 
(a)  If the commissioner of the revenue ascertains that any person who has been assessed with a license tax levied under the provisions of this article for any license tax year of the three license tax years last past or for the then current license tax year, but that, upon a correct audit and computation of the license tax, the assessment should be an increased amount and the assessment of the license tax at the lesser amount was not due to fraudulent intent or to evade taxes, then the commissioner of the revenue shall assess the taxpayer with the additional license tax found to be due, without penalty, and shall furnish written notice to the taxpayer and at the same time shall transmit a copy of the assessment notice to the city treasurer for collection. If the assessment of the additional license tax is not paid to the city treasurer within 30 days after written notice to the taxpayer of such additional assessment, a penalty of ten percent of such tax due, plus interest at the rate of ten percent per annum shall begin to accrue from the first day of the month following the month in which payment is due until payment is made. The city treasurer shall collect such interest in the same manner as the tax may be collected. 
(b)  Any person assessed with a license tax as a result of an audit may apply within 90 days from the date of such assessment to the commissioner of the revenue for a correction of the assessment. The application must be filed in good faith and sufficiently identify the taxpayer, audit period, remedy sought, each alleged error in the assessment, the grounds upon which the taxpayer relies, and any other facts relevant to the taxpayer's contention. The commissioner of the revenue may hold a conference with the taxpayer if requested by the taxpayer, or require submission of additional information and documents, further audit, or other evidence deemed necessary for a proper and equitable determination of the application. The commissioner of the revenue shall undertake a full review of the taxpayer's claims and issue a determination to the taxpayer setting forth its position. Every assessment pursuant to an audit shall be accompanied by a written statement of the taxpayer's right to seek correction. 
(c)  Provided an application is made within 90 days of an assessment, collection activity shall be suspended until 30 days after the final determination is issued by the commissioner of the revenue, unless the treasurer determines that collection would be jeopardized in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3719. Interest shall accrue in accordance with the provisions of section 40-476. If application for correction is made to the commissioner of the revenue within 30 days of the assessment, before the tax is delinquent, no penalty as provided in section 40-476 shall be imposed on the tax due unless it remains unpaid 30 days after the final determination from the commissioner of the revenue. 
(d)  Any taxpayer whose appeal on an audit of the business license has been denied by the commissioner of the revenue may appeal to the state tax commissioner pursuant to state law. See Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703.1(5). 
(e)  Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3703.1 is hereby adopted, mutatis mutandis, and made a part of this article as fully as though set forth at length herein. 
(Code 1982, § 18-14; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-473. - Assessment in case of fraudulent intent to evade license tax. 
    If the commissioner of the revenue ascertains that any person has fraudulently, or with intent to evade the payment of proper license taxes, failed or refused to obtain a proper license or pay the proper license tax as required by the provisions of this Code for any one or more of the three license tax years last past, or for the then current license tax year, and the liability is ascertained, such omitted or additional license tax and a penalty of ten percent of such tax due, plus interest at the annual rate of ten percent from the first day of the month following the month in which the taxes should have been paid shall be assessed. 
(Code 1982, § 18-15; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-474. - Display of license receipts. 
    The license receipts or other certificates showing the payment of license taxes whenever imposed by the provisions of any section of this article are to be displayed in a conspicuous place at the regular place of business or profession of the licensee, in order that the commissioner of the revenue or authorized agent, or any police officer of the city may inspect the same at any and all reasonable times. All licensees who have or maintain no regular place of business shall either carry with them on their person or have affixed or attached to their truck, car or other vehicle the license receipt or certificate and promptly display the same when called upon by any enforcement officer of the city to do so. 
(Code 1982, § 18-16; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-475. - Jurisdiction over violations. 
    The general district court of the city shall have jurisdiction of violations under this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18-17; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-476. - Penalties; interest on delinquent taxes. 
(a)  All license taxes shall be due and payable at the office of the city treasurer on the last day of March of each year except as herein otherwise provided for, and a penalty in the amount of ten percent of the license tax assessed or a penalty of $10.00, whichever is the larger amount, shall be imposed for failure to pay license taxes on or before the last day of March of each year. The penalty imposed hereby shall be due and payable when imposed and, when imposed, shall become a part of the tax. Interest at the rate of ten percent per annum shall be added to the delinquent license taxes, in addition to any other penalties imposed by law, beginning the first day following the day such tax is due. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to file a return or to pay a tax shall not be imposed if such failure was not the fault of the taxpayer, or was the fault of the commissioner of the revenue or the treasurer. No penalty for failure to pay any tax shall be imposed for any assessment made later than two weeks before the day on which the taxes are due, if such assessment is made thereafter through the fault of a local official and if such assessment is paid within 15 days after the notice is mailed. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and constitute a misdemeanor for any person to conduct a business or to engage in a profession, trade or occupation before procuring a license as required under the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful to willfully fail or refuse to file a license tax return at the times required by this article. The penalty shall not exceed those prescribed by general law for: 
(1)  A class 3 misdemeanor, if the amount of the tax lawfully assessed in connection with the return is $1,000.00 or less; or 
(2)  A class 1 misdemeanor, if the amount of the tax lawfully assessed in connection with the return is more than $1,000.00. 
Each day any person shall continue to violate the provisions of this article after the due date of any license tax prescribed in this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  In the enforcement of the provisions of this article the commissioner of the revenue of the city, in addition to the powers herein specifically granted, shall have all and the same enforcement authority with respect to the city licenses that state law confers upon the commissioners of the revenue generally with respect to licenses. As one of the means of ascertaining the amount of any license tax due under the provisions of this article, or of ascertaining any other pertinent information, the commissioner of the revenue may propound interrogatories to each applicant and may use such other evidence as he may procure. Such interrogatories shall be answered under oath, and it shall be unlawful for any applicant for a city license to refuse to answer any such interrogatories. 
(e)  The commissioner of the revenue of the city shall have such duties, authority and power with respect to the enforcement of the provisions of this article as may be conferred by the city council. The commissioner of the revenue shall have the power to summon any person by registered letter or otherwise to appear before him at his office at a time to be specified in such summons and to answer, under oath, questions touching such taxpayer's license tax liability. Failure to answer such summons without good cause or failing or refusing to answer, under oath, questions touching their tax liability shall be a misdemeanor and punishable as provided by Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3111. 
(f)  The commissioner of the revenue, after the hereinabove set out powers of enforcement have been exhausted, shall have the added power to proceed by warrant to enforce compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 18-18; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Secs. 40-477-40-490. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SCHEDULE OF TAXES 

Sec. 40-491. - Sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the manufacture, bottling or selling of alcoholic beverages within the city shall pay for the privilege, an annual license tax, as follows: 
(1)  For each distiller's license: $1,000.00 per annum; no such city license shall be required for any person who shall manufacture not more than 5,000 gallons of alcohol or spirits or both during such license year; 
(2)  For each winery license: $1,000.00 per annum; 
(3)  For each brewery license: $1,000.00 per annum; 
(4)  For each bottler's license, $500.00 per annum; 
(5)  For each wholesale beer license: $125.00 per annum; 
(6)  For each wholesale wine distributor's license: $50.00 per annum, and for each wholesale druggist license, $10.00 per annum; 
(7)  For each retail on-premises wine and beer license for a hotel, restaurant or club and for each retail off-premises wine and beer license: $75.00 per annum; 
(8)  For each retail on-premises beer license for a hotel, restaurant or club, for each retail off-premises beer license and for each druggist license: $50.00 per annum; 
(9)  For each banquet license: $5.00; 
(10)  For each fruit distiller's licenses: $1,500.00; 
(11)  For each hospital license: $10.00; 
(12)  For each mixed beverage license for restaurants, including restaurants located on premises of and operated by hotels and motels: $200.00 per annum for each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for up to 100 persons; $350.00 per annum for each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for more than 100 but not more than 150 persons; and $500.00 per annum for each restaurant with a seating capacity at tables for more than 150 persons; and for each private, nonprofit club operating a restaurant on the premises of such club, $350.00 per annum; and for each caterer, $200.00. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued to any person, unless such person shall hold or shall secure simultaneously therewith the proper state license provided for in Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed so as to require any person to obtain a city license where such person is a wholesaler or distributor who maintains no place of business within the city, but merely delivers alcoholic beverages in the city. 
(d)  No alcoholic beverage license authorized by this section shall be construed as exempting any licensee from any merchants' or restaurants' licenses. The alcoholic beverage tax is an annual tax, not subject to proration (Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3710) and cannot be transferred. 
(Code 1982, § 18-19; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-492. - Contractors; worker's compensation requirements. 
(a)  Whenever a license tax is levied on contractors by the city, the governing body of the city may, in its discretion, require a bond from the person licensed, with such surety, penalty and conditions as it may deem proper. 
(b)  The commissioner of the revenue shall require each contractor to provide a contractor's certification of insuring liability for worker's compensation at the time of application for a business license, which certifies such contractor is in compliance with Code of Virginia, § 62.5-800 et seq. 
(c)  Every person engaged in business in the city as a contractor shall pay for the privilege a license tax of $30.00 or $0.16 per $100.00 of gross receipts, whichever is greater. The restrictions on imposing license taxes contained in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3715 are applicable. 
(d)  All contractors are required to submit to the commissioner of the revenue a roster of all subcontractors doing work within the city for the contractor within 30 days from the date of issuance of building permit, listing name, address, phone number, amount of contract, and type of work to be performed. 
(e)  Definition. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor. 
(1)  The term "contractor" means any person who accepts, or offers to accept: 
a.  Contracts to perform, or regularly performs, or engages others to perform any of the work described in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3714 B on buildings, structures or real estate owned by him when the buildings, structures or real estate are sold upon completion of such work; or, if he regularly performs, or engages others to perform any of the work described in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3714 B, on buildings, structures, or real estate owned by others; 
b.  Contracts for the subdivision and improvement of real estate, and for the speculative building of houses or other buildings with the intention of offering the subdivided lots or completed buildings for sale. The mere subdivision of land into lots, without more, is not contracting within the meaning of this section. A person who would otherwise be classified as a contractor shall not lose such classification because real estate is temporarily leased, less than 12 months, until it can be sold, or leased with an option to purchase instead of sold, unless the leasing activity constitutes a separate licensable business. Any gross receipts from such leases shall be considered ancillary to the business of contracting; 
c.  Contracts to install water or sewer systems, roads, or engages in any other activity described in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3714 B on his own land with the intent to offer the land for sale; 
d.  Orders or contracts for doing any work on or in any building or structure requiring the use of paint, stone, brick, mortar, wood, cement, structural iron or steel, sheet iron, galvanized iron, metallic piping, tin, lead or other metal or any other building material; 
e.  Contracts to do any paving, curbing or other work on sidewalks, streets, alleys or highways, on public or private property, using asphalt, brick, stone, cement, concrete, wood or any composition; 
f.  An order for or contract to excavate earth, rock or other material for foundation or any other purpose or for cutting, trimming or maintaining rights-of-way; 
g.  An order or contract to construct any sewer of stone, brick, terra-cotta or other material; 
h.  Orders or contracts for doing any work on or in any building or premises involving the erecting, installing, altering, repairing, servicing or maintaining of electric wiring, devices or appliances permanently connected to such wiring or the erecting, repairing, or maintaining of the lines for the transmission or distribution of electric light and power; 
i.  An order or contract to remodel, repair, wreck or demolish a building; 
j.  An order or contract to bore or dig a well; 
k.  An order or contract to install, maintain or repair air conditioning apparatus or equipment. 
(2)  The term "contractor" does not include the business of contracting by the property owner to build or improve a building which the property owner intends to occupy as the property owner's residence, office or other place of business for not less than six months prior to sale of property. 
(f)  Contracting generally includes, but is not limited to, persons engaged in the following occupations, businesses or trades: 
Air conditioning. 
Brick contracting and other masonry. 
Builder. 
Building. 
Buyer. 
Cementing. 
Developer. 
Dredging. 
Electrical contracting. 
Elevator installation. 
Erecting signs which are assessed as realty.

(Code 1982, § 18-20; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001)

Sec. 40-493. - Limits on principal contractors receiving federal appropriations for research and development. 
    Any person designated as the principal or prime contractor receiving identifiable federal appropriations for research and development services as defined in section 31.205-18(a) of the Federal Acquisition Regulation in the areas of: 
Computer and electronic systems; 
Computer software; 
Applied sciences; 
Economic and social sciences; and 
Electronic and physical sciences; 
shall be subject to a license tax rate not to exceed $0.03 per $100.00 of such federal funds received in payment of such contracts upon documentation provided by such person to the commissioner of the revenue confirming the applicability of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 18-21; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-494. - Financial or real estate services. 
(a)  Every person engaged in financial or real estate services within the city, except those excluded by the terms of subsection (f) of this section, shall pay for the privilege a license tax of $30.00 or $0.52 per $100.00 of gross receipts, whichever is greater. 
(b)  Any person rendering a service for compensation in the form of a credit agency, an investment company, a broker or dealer in securities and commodities or a security or commodity exchange is providing a financial service, unless such service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(c)  Those engaged in rendering financial services include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Buying installment receivables. 
Chattel mortgage financing. 
Check cashing. 
Consumer financing. 
Credit card services. 
Credit unions. 
Factors. 
Financial consultants, portfolio managers. 
Financing accounts receivable. 
Industrial loan companies. 
Installment financing. 
Inventory financing. 
Loan or mortgage brokers. 
Loan or mortgage companies. 
Safety deposit box companies. 
Security and commodity brokers and services. 
Stockbroker. 
Working capital financing. 
(d)  Any person other than a national bank or bank or trust company organized under the laws of this state or duly licensed and practicing attorney-at-law that engages in the business of buying and selling for others on commission or for other compensation, shares in any corporation, bonds, notes or other evidence of debt is a stockbroker. The fact that orders are taken subject to approval by a main office does not relieve the broker from license taxation. Also, an insurance company engaged in selling mutual funds is a broker as to that portion of its business. 
(e)  Any person rendering a service for compensation as lessor, agent or broker is providing a real estate service, unless the service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(f)  All real estate agencies are required to submit to the commissioner of the revenue a roster of all their active agents working from a city office, listing name and address, every January 1 and July 1 of each year. 
(g)  All developers are required to submit to the commissioner of the revenue a roster of all subcontractors performing work in the city within 30 days from date of issuance of building permit, listing name, address and type of work to be performed. 
(h)  Those rendering real estate services include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Appraisers of real estate. 
Escrow agents, real estate. 
Fiduciaries, real estate. 
Lessors of real property. 
Operators of residential mobile home sites. 
Owner-operators and lessors of buildings. 
Real estate agents, brokers and managers. 
Real estate selling agents. 
Rental agents for real estate. 
(i)  Any person engaged in financial or real estate services who is engaged as an employee of an employer, who has paid the proper license tax under the provisions of this section, shall be excluded from the terms of this section. It is the intent of this section that the employer, but not the employee, be taxed on gross receipts including those attributed to or produced by the employee. 
(Code 1982, § 18-22; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001; Ord. No. 1754, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 40-495. - Professional occupations. 
(a)  Every person conducting or engaging in one or more of the following professions, occupations or businesses shall pay for the privilege an annual license tax of $0.52 for each $100.00 of gross receipts or gross expenditures. The minimum annual licenses tax shall be $30.00. 
(b)  Those engaged in rendering a professional occupation include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Architects. 
Attorneys-at-law. 
Certified public accountants.

Neurologist. 
Oculist. 
Optometrist.

Physician.

Practitioner of the healing arts, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 54.1-2900, as amended. 
Psychiatrist. 
Surgeons. 
Surveyors. 
Teachers, certified. 
Veterinarians. 
Other similar professional occupations. 
(Code 1982, § 18-23; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 40-496. - Renting of houses, apartments or commercial establishments by owner. 
(a)  Every person who, as principal or through an agent, shall engage in the business of renting houses, or apartments in the city shall pay for the privilege of doing business an annual license tax of $0.38 on each $100.00 of gross receipts from the rental of all houses, apartment units or dwelling units during the preceding fiscal or calendar year. Persons engaged in the business of renting houses or apartments, or both, shall not be affected by or come within the provisions of this section, unless such person is engaged in the business of renting in excess of two separate dwelling units. The minimum annual licenses tax shall be $30.00. 
(1)  The business of renting houses and apartments as used in this section shall be construed to mean the rental of a building or portion thereof designed exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family and multiple family dwellings, but not including hotels, boardinghouses and roominghouses. 
(2)  The term "dwelling unit" is defined to mean one or more rooms in a dwelling house or apartment designed for occupancy by one family for living purposes and having cooking, toilet and bathing facilities. The term "single piece of commercial property" is defined to mean either land improved or unimproved. 
(b)  Every person who, as principal or through an agent, shall engage in the business of renting commercial property in the city shall pay for the privilege of doing business an annual license tax of $0.53 on each $100.00 of gross receipts from the rental of all commercial establishments during the preceding fiscal or calendar year. Persons engaged in renting a single piece of commercial property shall be considered to be doing business and shall come within the provisions of this section. The minimum annual licenses tax shall be $30.00. 
(c)  Every person operating any commercial establishment in the city having four or more tenants in any building shall on or before February 1 of each year, upon request of the commissioner of the revenue of the city, furnish a list of such tenants giving the name, address and the type or nature of business of each such tenant, as of January 1 preceding. 
(d)  This section applies to the renting or leasing of all or a portion of buildings or other improvements. It does not apply to the rental or leasing of rooms in hotels, motels, motor lodges, auto courts, tourist courts, lodginghouses, roominghouses and boardinghouses, but it does apply to land on which such buildings or other improvements are located. 
(Code 1982, § 18-24; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1703, 5-14-2001) 
Sec. 40-497. - Repair, personal, business and other services. 
    Every person engaged in a repair, personal or business service within the city shall pay for the privilege a license tax of $30.00 or $0.36 per $100.00 of gross receipts, whichever is greater. 
(1)  Repair service. The repairing, renovating, cleaning or servicing or some article of item of personal property for compensation is a repair service, unless the service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(2)  Personal service. Any service rendered for compensation either upon or for persons, animals or personal effects is a personal service, unless the service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(3)  Business service. Any service rendered for compensation to any business, trade, occupation or governmental agency is a business service, unless the service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(4)  Service enumerated. Those rendering a repair, personal or business service or other service including, but are not limited to, the following:

(Code 1982, § 18-25; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1991, 12-18-2018) 
Sec. 40-498. - Retail sales. 
(a)  Every person engaged in business in the city in retail sales shall pay for the privilege a license tax of $30.00 or $0.19 per $100.00 of gross receipts, whichever is greater. For itinerant merchants and peddlers, the maximum tax shall be $500.00 per year. The license tax imposed herein shall be further limited as required by Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3717 and 58.1-3719. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant merchant means any person who engages in, does or transacts any temporary or transient business in the city either in one locality or in traveling from place to place in the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and who, for the purpose of scarring on such business hires, leases, uses or occupies any building or structure, motor vehicle, tent, car, boat or public room or any part thereof, including rooms in hotels, lodginghouses or houses of private entertainment, or in any street, alley or public place for a period of less than one year for the exhibition of or sale of such goods, wares or merchandise. 
    Peddler means any person who carries from place to place any goods, wares, or merchandise and offers to sell or actually sells and delivers at the same time is a peddler. Any person who does not keep a regular place of business, whether it is a house or a vacant lot or elsewhere, with regular business hours, but at that place offers to sell goods, wares and merchandise is a peddler. Any person who keeps a regular place of business or regular business hours at the same place, who other than at that regular place of business, personally or through agents offers for sale or sells and at the time of such offering for sale, delivers goods, wares and merchandise is a peddler. 
    Retail merchant means any person who makes retail sales. 
    Retail sale means the sale of goods, wares and merchandise for any purpose other than resale, but not including sales at wholesale to institutional, commercial and industrial users. 
(c)  Any peddler or itinerant merchant who sells goods, wares or merchandise at retail is engaged in retail sales and is subject to this license tax as such. 
(d)  When a merchant conducts both a wholesale and a retail business, the merchant is subject to the retail license tax on the retail portion of the business and subject to the wholesale license tax on the wholesale portion of the business. However, he may, but is not required to, pay the license tax as a retailer on both the retail and wholesale portions of the business. 
(e)  Banks and savings and loan associations that sell promotional items are engaged in retail sales as to the sales of the promotional items and are not exempt from license taxation as to those sales. 
(f)  A charitable institution or other not-for-profit organization that engages in the business of buying and selling merchandise is subject to the license tax as a retail or wholesale merchant, even though the proceeds are subsequently used for charitable purposes. 
(g)  A lunch counter operated by an organization open to members only, the proceeds from which are used to maintain the organization, is subject to a local license tax. 
(g)  Any hotel, motel, boardinghouse or lodginghouse which also furnishes or sells food or merchandise for compensation is engaged in retail sales as to the sales of the food or merchandise. 
(i)  Any person who sells goods at retail through a commission merchant, upon consignment or otherwise, is liable for the license tax as to such sales. 
(j)  A person is not subject to a license tax if his business in this city is limited solely to the solicitation of orders by catalogs mailed from outside this city to mail-order buyers in this city and who fills orders from outside this city. However, if the catalogs are distributed by a city resident by mail or in person or if the person engaged in the mail-order business has a definite place of business in this city at which mail orders are received or filled, the mail-order business shall be treated the same as any other retail or wholesale business for the purpose of city license taxes. 
(k)  Any person who merely fills prescriptions for or fits corrective lenses and eyeglasses frames is a retail merchant. However, any practitioner who examines eyes is engaged in rendering a professional service. 
(l)  Any practitioner of a profession who sells goods, wares or merchandise in connection with the practice of the profession is engaged in making retail sales as to those goods, wares or merchandise he sells, but does not himself administer. 
(Code 1982, § 18-26; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2.
