Sec. 40-501. - Coin-operated amusement machines, operators, and services. 
(a)  Every person conducting or engaging in the business of amusement arcade operator shall pay for the privilege an annual license tax. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement arcade operator means any person selling, leasing, renting or otherwise furnishing or providing a coin-operated amusement machine or device; however, a person owning less than three machines and operating such machines on property owned or leased by such person is not an amusement machine operator. 
(c)  Every amusement machine operator as herein defined shall pay for the privilege an annual license tax according to the following: 
2 machines or less $50.00 3 to 9 machines $100.00 10 or more machines $200.00  
This tax shall not be prorated. This tax shall be due 30 days after the adoption of the ordinance enacting this section and no later than the first day of March each year hereafter. Each amusement machine operator shall furnish the commissioner of the revenue a complete list of all machines on location in the city and the address of each location, by January 31 of each year. Each machine shall post a label or sticker as required by Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3722. Any person failing to procure any license as established in this section shall be subject to the maximum fine permissible for a class 1 misdemeanor under state law and the machine or other device shall be forfeited to the city. 
(d)  In addition to the above, each amusement operator shall pay a gross receipts tax in the amount of $0.36 per $100.00 of gross receipts. This tax shall be due only on that portion of the receipts actually received by the amusement operator. 
(e)  There is hereby imposed a gross receipts tax of $0.36 per $100.00 on those providing amusement services. Those engaged in rendering an amusement service include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Amusement park. 
Arcade or building devoted to general amusement or entertaining. 
Auditorium. 
Billiards. 
Bowling alley. 
Furnishing closed-circuit television. 
Furnishing closed-circuit musical. 
Entertainment. 
Hobby-horse machines, etc. 
Shooting galleries. 
Skating rink. 
Theaters. 
Theatrical performers, bands and orchestras. 
(Code 1982, § 18-30; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 40-502. - Advertising with loudspeakers on vehicles. 
    For each vehicle used on the streets of the city for advertising by means of a loudspeaker, radio or other mechanical equipment, there shall be a license tax of $12.50 per diem, which license fee shall not be prorated. 
(Code 1982, § 18-31; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-503. - Canvassers and soliciting agents. 
    Canvassers or soliciting agents not otherwise provided for shall pay a license tax of $25.00 per annum or $5.00 per diem; except, that activities by or in behalf of charitable agencies are exempt herein. Any canvasser or soliciting agent exempt from local licenses under the federal law shall register with the chief of police and any canvasser or soliciting agent failing to register will be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 18-32; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-504. - Circuses, etc. 
(a)  No show, circus, carnival or other like performances shall be exhibited within the city until a license has been obtained, for which privilege a license tax of $150.00 per day shall be charged, and no rebate shall be allowed for rainy days. 
(b)  For the privilege of using the streets and highways of the city for a circus street parade, a license tax of $100.00 shall be charged, and no such license shall be issued except after a permit for the parade has been obtained from the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 18-33; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-505. - Fortunetellers, clairvoyants, phrenologists, etc. 
    Every fortuneteller, clairvoyant, phrenologist, spirit medium, chiromancer, astrologist or palmist operating in the city shall pay for the privilege an annual license tax of $1,000.00. This license tax shall not be prorated and the license shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1982, § 18-34; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-506. - Savings and loan associations. 
    Stock savings and loans associations, state chartered credit unions, and building and loan associations whose main office is in the city shall pay an annual license tax for the privilege in the sum of $50.00. 
(Code 1982, § 18-35; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-507. - Short-term rental business. 
    Every person conducting or engaging in the short-term rental business as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510 shall pay an annual business license tax of $0.19 for each $100.00 of gross receipts. The tax shall be collected in the manner described by state law. If a person's certification as a short-term rental business is revoked or not renewed, the tax rate mandated by this section shall not apply for the year in which the certificate is revoked nor for any years in which the certificate is not renewed. 
(Code 1982, § 18-36; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-508. - Telephone companies and motor vehicle carriers. 
(a)  To the extent permitted by state law, telephone companies, without regard to place of office or place of business, shall pay a license tax of one-half of one percent of gross receipts from sales of goods and services to ultimate consumers within the city during the calendar year. 
(b)  Motor vehicle carriers operating on or through the streets of the city shall pay for the privilege or using the streets, roads and routes, including bridges, an annual license tax of one-fifth cent per mile for each vehicle operated within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18-37; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996; Ord. No. 1689, 10-30-2000) 
Sec. 40-509. - Wall signs and billboards. 
    All persons engaged in the business of wall sign or billboard painting or posting or the rental of space or facilities for such signs or billboards shall pay for the privilege an annual tax of $50.00 for each such wall sign or billboard. The commissioner of the revenue shall issue no license under the provision of this article, unless the applicant shall present a certificate in writing from the city planning commission that the location of such wall signs or billboards is in conformity with chapter 48, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1982, § 18-38; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Sec. 40-510. - Severability; purpose. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, clauses, sentences, and parts of this article are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this article is declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this article or the application of such provisions to other provisions or circumstances but shall be confined in its application to the section, clause, sentence, paragraph, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which said judgment shall have been rendered and the person or circumstances involved. 
(b)  Should any exemption from, lower rate of, or limitation on this tax be declared invalid, illegal, unconstitutional, or void for any reason, such declaration is not intended to affect the taxes imposed by this article, but the transactions found to be wrongfully exempted, limited, or subject to a lower tax rate shall become fully subject to this tax to the same extent as if such exemption, attempted exemption or limitation, or lower rate had never been included in this article. If any conflict arises between this article and applicable state law, then it is intended that the provision of state law shall be applicable. 
(c)  The purpose of this section is to comply with the minimum requirements of Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3700 through 58.1-3732.2 regulating local business, professional, and occupational license taxation; and in any event where the provisions of this Code conflict with the state law, the provisions of state law shall control as if set out in this Code in full. 
(Code 1982, § 18-39; Ord. No. 1457, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 1562, 12-9-1996) 
Secs. 40-511-40-525. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - SHORT-TERM RENTAL TAX[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference- Daily rental property tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.1 et seq. 

Sec. 40-526. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Affiliated means any common ownership interest in excess of five percent of any officers or partners in common with the lessor and lessee. For purposes of this test: 
(1)  Any rental to a person affiliated with the lessor shall be treated as rental receipts but shall not qualify for purposes of the 80 percent requirement; and 
(2)  Any rental of personal property which also involves the provision of personal services for the operation of the personal property rented shall not be treated as gross receipts from rental. For purposes of this article, the delivery and installation of tangible personal property shall not mean operation. 
    Certificate of registration refers to the annual certificate issued by the Falls Church Commissioner of the Revenue to persons engaged in the short-term rental business in the city who make application for such certificate, pursuant to section 40-534. 
    City means the City of Falls Church, Virginia. 
    Commissioner of the revenue means the commissioner of the revenue of the City of Falls Church, Virginia, and any of the commissioner's duly authorized deputies or agents. 
    Daily rental property means all tangible personal property held for rental and owned by a person engaged in the short-term rental business as defined in this section, except trailers, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100 and other tangible personal property required to be licensed or registered from the state department of motor vehicles, the state department of game and inland fisheries or the state department of aviation. 
    Gross proceeds shall mean the total amount charged including penalties, late charges of interest, to each person for the rental of daily rental property from a short-term rental business with a valid certificate of registration, excluding any state and local sales tax paid pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 48.1-600 et seq. Gross proceeds is the taxable basis for the daily rental tax. 
    Gross rental receipts shall mean all proceeds from rentals during a calendar year, including rentals to persons affiliated with the lessor, except that proceeds from rental of personal property which also involves the provision of personal services for the operation of the personal property rented shall not be treated as gross receipts from rental. For purposes of this article, the delivery and installation of tangible personal property shall not mean operation. 
    Person shall mean and include individuals, firms, partnerships, associations, corporations, and combinations of individuals of whatever form and character. 
    Short-term rental business shall include any person engaged in the short-term rental of daily rental property as defined in this section, if: 
(1)  Not less than 80 percent of the gross rental receipts of such business in any year are from transactions involving rental periods of 92 consecutive days or less, including all extensions and renewals to the same person or a person affiliated with the lessor; and provided that 
(2)  Any rental to a person affiliated with the lessor shall be treated as rental receipts for the purpose of collecting the daily rental tax but shall not qualify for purposes of the 80 percent requirement to qualify as a short-term rental business; and 
(3)  Any rental of personal property which also involves the provision of personal services for the operation of the personal property rented shall not be treated as gross receipts from rental. For purposes of this article, the term "delivery and installation of tangible personal property" shall not mean operation. 
(Code 1982, § 40-1; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510. 
Sec. 40-527. - Levy and rate of daily rental tax. 
    Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.1, and in addition to all other taxes of every kind now or hereinafter imposed by law, the city hereby levies and imposes on every person engaged in the short-term rental business a tax of one percent on the gross proceeds of such business, as defined in section 40-526. Such tax shall be in addition to the tax levied pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-605. 
(Code 1982, § 40-2; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Sales tax authority, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-605; authority to levy daily rental tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.1. 
Sec. 40-528. - Exemptions from daily rental tax. 
(a)  No tax hereunder shall be collected or payable on rentals by the commonwealth, by any political subdivision of the commonwealth or by the United States. 
(b)  No tax hereunder shall be collected or payable on any rental of durable medical equipment as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-609.10(10). 
(c)  All rentals exempt from the state sales and use tax, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-600 et seq., shall be exempt from this daily rental tax. 
(d)  All exemptions from this tax claimed by short-term rental businesses at the time of payment of collected taxes shall be proved by filing of appropriate documentation as directed by the commissioner and are subject to verification by the commissioner at any time. 
(Code 1982, § 40-3; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Exemptions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.1 C. 
Sec. 40-529. - Short-term rental business application for certificate of registration. 
    Every person engaging in the business of short-term rental, as defined in section 40-526, shall annually file an application for a certificate of registration with the city commissioner of the revenue for each place of business in the city from which short-term rental business will be conducted by the applicant. Such application shall be filed by January 31 of each year or within 30 days of the beginning of a short-term rental business. The application shall be on a form prescribed by the city commissioner of the revenue and shall contain: 
(1)  The name under which the applicant intends to operate the rental business; 
(2)  The location in the city from which the rental business will be conducted, as well as the location of the rental business headquarters; 
(3)  The figures for the previous year's business including the total gross receipts from all business, the total gross rental proceeds and the total receipts from short-term rental of daily rental property; 
(4)  A list of all tangible personal property owned by the applicant as of January 1 of the current year and used as short-term rental property; 
(5)  A list of all property leased or licensed to the short-term rental business as of January 1 of the current year, used for short-term rental, with the name and address of the owner of such property; 
(6)  Such other information as the commissioner may require; and 
(7)  An oath by the person making application or an officer, partner or duly authorized agent for such applicant that they are in fact qualified for tax treatment as a short-term rental business, they shall collect only those daily rental taxes due under the law in the time and manner prescribed by law, and they shall remit all daily rental taxes collected or due and owing to the city. 
(Code 1982, § 40-4; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Certificate of registration, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.2. 
Sec. 40-530. - Issuance and effect of certificate of registration for short-term daily rental business. 
    Upon approval of the application required by section 40-534 by the commissioner of the revenue, a certificate of registration shall be issued for each location from which a daily rental business is to be conducted or operated in the city by the applicant. The certificate shall be conspicuously displayed at all times at the place of business for which it is issued. Each annual certificate shall be valid and authorize the collection of the short-term rental tax until renewal or revocation of the certificate. The certificate is not assignable and shall be valid only for the person in whose name it is issued and the place of business designated. 
(Code 1982, § 40-5; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Certificate of registration, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.2. 
Sec. 40-531. - Collection and recordkeeping. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the short-term rental business with a valid certificate of registration from the commissioner of the revenue shall collect this daily rental tax from the lessee of the daily rental property at the time of the rental. 
(b)  The person collecting this tax shall maintain a record of all rental transactions for which this tax is collected, which record shall contain: 
(1)  A description of the property rented; 
(2)  The period of time for which the property was rented; 
(3)  The name and address of the person to whom the property was rented; and 
(4)  The amount charged for each rental, including all late charges, penalties and interest. 
(c)  Every person engaged in the short-term rental business shall maintain a complete record of all exemptions from payment of this tax granted to renters of short-term rental property including, in addition to the information specified in subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  A copy of the state department of taxation tax-exemption certificate; 
(2)  A copy of the U.S. State Department tax exemption certificate, which U.S. State Department card must specify the renter by name who is exempt from sales tax; or 
(3)  Other explanation and proof of claimed exemption. 
(Code 1982, § 40-6; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-532. - Filing of quarterly tax returns and remittance of tax. 
    Each certified short-term rental business under the provisions of this article shall file a quarterly tax return with the commissioner of the revenue, indicating for the quarter just past: 
(1)  The total business gross receipts of the return filer; 
(2)  The gross proceeds derived from the short-term rental business; 
(3)  All rental gross proceeds claimed to be exempt from the daily rental tax and documentation of each such claim; 
(4)  The total daily rental tax due the city for the previous quarter's short-term rental business. 
Each return shall indicate the gross proceeds derived from the short-term rental business. The city commissioner of the revenue shall assess the tax due, and the treasurer or director of finance shall collect the daily rental property tax. The quarterly return shall be filed with the commissioner of the revenue on or before the 20th day of each of the months of April, July, October and January, representing, respectively, the gross proceeds and taxes collected during the preceding quarters ending March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31. 
(Code 1982, § 40-7; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
State Law reference- Assessment by the commissioner of the revenue, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.1 B. 
Sec. 40-533. - Taxes held in trust for city. 
    The taxes required to be collected under this article shall be deemed to be held in trust for the city by the person required to collect such taxes until remitted as required in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 40-8; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-534. - Penalty for failure or refusal to collect tax. 
    If any certified, short-term rental business in the city fails or refuses to collect the tax imposed under this article, their current certificate of registration shall be revoked and the business shall not be subject to the provision of Code of Virginia, §§ 58.2-3510, 58.1-3510.1 and 58.1-3706 nor to the provisions of section 40-507 and this article for the calendar year in which the certificate was revoked. Any payments of daily rental tax made previous to the revocation of the certificate shall be refunded to such lessees as can be identified by the lessor. 
(Code 1982, § 40-9; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-535. - Penalties and interest; failure to file return or pay over taxes collected. 
(a)  If any certified, short-term rental business fails to file the returns required by this article or fails or refuses to remit to the commissioner of the revenue the tax collected and paid under this article at the time specified in this article, its certification as a short-term rental business shall be revoked and there shall be added to such tax collected prior to revocation of the certificate and due the city but not paid a penalty in the amount of ten percent of the tax past due or the sum of $10.00, whichever is greater. The assessment of such penalty shall not be deemed a defense to any criminal prosecution for failure to comply with any of the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Interest on late payment of any taxes and penalties due shall be at the rate of ten percent for the first year. For the second and subsequent years, interest shall be paid on the delinquent tax and penalty at a rate established by the treasurer, at his or her discretion, but not to exceed ten percent per annum or the rate of interest, established pursuant to section 6621 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1984, as amended, whichever is greater. Penalty and interest for failure to file the return or to pay the tax due pursuant to this article shall be assessed on the first day following the day such quarterly return and tax payment is due. The certification shall be revoked if the failure to pay the tax due or to file the returns required by this article continues for 60 days beyond the due date. 
(Code 1982, § 40-10; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-536. - Uncertified renters prohibited from collecting tax. 
    No person renting any property or services to any other person shall collect from the lessee the daily rental tax authorized by this article, unless they have a valid certificate of registration issued for the current year by the commissioner of the revenue. Any taxes collected in a manner not authorized by law shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Code 1982, § 40-11; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-537. - Criminal penalties. 
    Persons violating or failing to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, except as provided below: 
(1)  If the amount of tax due and unpaid for any quarter exceeds $1,000.00, any person failing to file a return or remit payment when due and convicted of such failure on a criminal warrant shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(2)  Any person violating section 40-536 shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 40-12; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-538. - Taxation of rental property that is not daily rental property. 
    Except for daily rental passenger cars, rental property that is not daily rental property shall be classified for taxation, pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3503. 
(Code 1982, § 40-13; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-539. - Effect of revocation of certification as short-term rental business. 
    If upon audit by the commissioner of the revenue of the preceding full year's gross proceeds and gross rental receipts, it is ascertained that a certified short-term rental business did not meet the criteria for certification set out in section 40-526, any current certification shall be revoked or renewal of certification shall be denied. In addition the business shall not be treated for business license tax and business tangible property tax assessment as a certified, short-term rental business for the preceding year and for the current year. The business shall be assessed any additional business license and business tangible property taxes found to be due. 
(Code 1982, § 40-14; Ord. No. 1289, 12-11-1989) 
Sec. 40-540. - Exemptions, penalties. 
    Provisions in Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-609.1 through 58.1-609.11 relating to exemptions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-635 and 58.1-636 relating to penalties, and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-615 relating to the manner of collecting the local retail sales and use tax applicable in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-600 et seq., shall apply mutatis mutandis to the daily rental property tax, except that the city commissioner of the revenue shall assess the tax due, and the treasurer or director of finance shall collect the daily rental property tax, instead of the state department of taxation. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3510.3. 
Chapter 42 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to construct, regulate, etc., sewers and water system, §§ 2.03, 2.04; establishment of use rates, § 2.05; public utilities, §§ 13.01-13.05. 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; cable television, ch. 10; consumer utility tax, § 40-294; outdoor lighting, § 14-127 et seq.; housing, ch. 22; water recreation facilities, § 8-425 et seq.; safety standards for underground installations, § 36-127 et seq.; activities of public utilities relative to trees, shrubs and weeds, § 44-23; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; subdivisions, ch. 42; zoning, ch. 48. 
State Law reference- Municipal public utilities generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2109 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Director of public utilities. 
(a)  Creation of office; duties. The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to employ a director of public utilities of the city at a salary to be fixed and apportioned to the various city accounts by the council. 
(b)  Supervision; duties. The director of public utilities shall be under the supervision of the general manager of the department of environmental services and orders of the council and it shall be the duty of the director of public utilities to faithfully operate the water and sanitary sewer utilities of the city. The director shall perform such other duties as may be assigned by the general manager of the department of environmental services. 
(Code 1973, §§ 31-1, 31-2; Code 1982, § 29-1) 
Charter reference- Charter provision as to director of public utilities, §§ 13.03, 13.04. 
Sec. 42-2. - Privies. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain a privy or dry closet within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 31-4; Code 1982, § 29-2) 
Sec. 42-3. - Septic tanks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install a septic tank in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 31-5; Code 1982, § 29-3) 
Secs. 42-4-42-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal water supplies and facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2109 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-25. - Wells and cisterns. 
    No wells or cisterns will be allowed to be connected to the potable water supply of any building in the city. Existing wells shall be disconnected when a health hazard would result from their continued use, and the building's potable water system shall be connected to the city water supply. Wells may be drilled for use as nonpotable water supply for use in cooling towers, lawn sprinklers and the like, when approved by the building official, and a permit with approval shall be obtained from the health department. 
(Code 1973, § 31-6; Code 1982, § 29-4) 
Sec. 42-26. - Connection with city water supply. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any house or type of construction used as a human habitation, or the owner of any land used for the parking or standing of any trailer or automobile trailer or vehicle of any kind used as a human habitation, or the owner of any public building or other place where persons congregate or are employed, within the corporate limits of the city, to occupy, rent or lease the same for occupancy, unless the habitation has been connected to the city water system. 
(b)  Fee. A charge as set by the city council by ordinance will be made for connecting any building to the city water system. 
(Code 1973, §§ 31-7, 31-8; Code 1982, § 29-5) 
Sec. 42-27. - Account charge. 
    An account charge shall be paid by each applicant for service whether for a new account or for a transfer of account. This charge is included in the first bill rendered to the customer. The amount of the account charge shall be $12.50. 
(Code 1973, § 31-9; Code 1982, § 29-6; Ord. No. 735; Ord. No. 920) 
Sec. 42-28. - Service rates. 
    The rates for water service to all consumers shall be as set by the city council by ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 31-10; Code 1982, § 29-7) 
Sec. 42-29. - Bills. 
(a)  Due date. All water bills shall be paid within 30 days after date of rendition. 
(b)  Division of system into sections. The water system shall be divided into sections; one section to be billed to water consumers each month for the current quarterly period beginning with that month. Large consumers, as determined by the director of utilities customer service, shall be billed monthly. 
(Code 1973, §§ 31-12, 31-13; Code 1982, § 29-8) 
Cross reference- Billing and collection of charges for use of water and sewer, § 29-28. 
Sec. 42-30. - Disconnection on default or violation. 
    In case of any default of payment of a bill or violation of any other requirement or regulation of the department of public utilities, water service shall be cut off from the premises affected without further notice. 
(Code 1973, § 31-14; Code 1982, § 29-9) 
Sec. 42-31. - Charge for reconnection. 
    When water service has been shut off from any consumer on account of default in payment of water bill or for other violations, a charge for reconnection will be set by the city council by ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 31-15; Code 1982, § 29-10) 
Sec. 42-32. - New installations or extensions-Permits and inspections. 
(a)  No water installations or extensions in new or old buildings, either or both, either inside or outside the boundaries of the city shall be made without a permit by the appropriate jurisdiction for same. An inspection shall be made of the completed work before the water meter is installed in new buildings or water is turned on in extensions in old buildings. 
(b)  The cost of such permit and inspection shall be as required by the appropriate jurisdiction. 
(c)  Failure to comply with regulations of this section shall be deemed cause for the refusal of the use of water by the city in new installations and immediate disconnection of meter in old installations. 
(Code 1973, §§ 31-16-31-18; Code 1982, § 29-11) 
Sec. 42-33. - Same-Costs; title; agreements for reimbursement. 
(a)  Responsibility for costs. The entire cost of water line extension shall be paid for by the person requesting such extensions. When such extensions are made by the department of public utilities, the estimated whole cost of such extensions must be deposited with the treasurer of the city before any work is started. All extensions shall become the property of the department of public utilities. Agreements may be made to reimburse those making extensions by requiring any person connecting to the extensions to pay a pro rata share. However, all such agreements shall become null and void after a period of ten years from the date of execution. The council may, by ordinance, establish a local facilities charge or an availability charge, to be paid by anyone requesting a water tap on lines installed by the city at its own expense or on lines which have been otherwise acquired by the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Availability charge means the applicant's share of the cost of that portion of the pumping stations, transmission mains, storage tanks and treatment facilities and associated appurtenances needed to convey water to a location convenient to the applicant's local distribution system and which have been or will be provided at the expense of the city. 
    Local facilities means water mains, valves, fittings, fire hydrants and associated appurtenances needed to provide water service at a location that obviates the need for any further extension, by the applicant, and which have been provided at the expense of the city, individuals, corporations, or firms other than the applicant and subsequently conveyed to the city. 
(c)  Agreement for reimbursement. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the council, upon the recommendation of the city manager, from authorizing the expenditure of funds from the waterworks renewal fund or from other sources for the extension of trunk mains; provided, further, that the city manager may, upon the recommendation of the general manager of the department of environmental services, enter into an agreement to reimburse persons required by the city to install oversize mains in order to provide for the future expansion of the water system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-19; Code 1982, § 29-12; Ord. No. 832) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-34. - Dimensions of water taps. 
    Dimensions of water taps shall be established by the director of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, § 31-20; Code 1982, § 29-13) 
Sec. 42-35. - Size of permanent water main. 
    No permanent water main smaller than four inches shall be installed under any consideration. 
(Code 1973, § 31-21; Code 1982, § 29-14) 
Sec. 42-36. - Single connection to one meter. 
    It shall be unlawful to connect or serve more than one residence or other establishment from one meter. This is not to be construed as prohibiting the extension of a water line of a residence or other establishment to the out-buildings properly appertaining thereto. The city manager is authorized to permit the serving of a church and its parsonage from one meter. 
(Code 1973, § 31-22; Code 1982, § 29-15) 
Sec. 42-37. - Connections outside city. 
    No water connections shall be made to facilities of the city until permits for the same shall have been issued and fees collected as set by ordinance by the city council. All such connections shall be inspected in the usual manner by the department of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, § 31-23; Code 1982, § 29-16) 
Sec. 42-38. - Unauthorized interference with system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection or turn any valve, or in any way to tamper with the water line, connections, hydrants or valves belonging to the water supply or distribution system of the city, except by permit issued by the city authorities. 
(Code 1973, § 31-24; Code 1982, § 29-17) 
State Law reference- Destruction or damage to water facilities, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-162. 
Secs. 42-39-42-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to require installation of water conservation devices, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-923. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 42-65-42-87. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Water Shortage Control Plan 

Sec. 42-88. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coordinator means the coordinator of the Metropolitan Washington Water Supply Emergency Agreement. 
    Emergency plan means the Metropolitan Washington Water Supply Emergency Plan contained within the Metropolitan Washington Water Supply Emergency Agreement entered into by the jurisdiction on December 5, 1979, and any amendments subsequently approved by the jurisdiction. 
    Emergency stage means the stage in the emergency plan at which ordinances which require mandatory curtailment of nonessential water use by the general public will be activated in affected areas. Upon notification from the coordinator that the emergency stage has been declared and that the jurisdiction is affected, the water use administrator shall activate and implement the provisions of this subdivision. 
    Jurisdiction means the City of Falls Church, Virginia. 
    Water means water taken from any public water supply or distribution system within the boundaries of the jurisdiction. 
    Water use administrator means the city manager or the designee of the city manager authorized to implement this subdivision. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(a); Ord. No. 752) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-89. - Restriction of water use. 
    At such time as the water use administrator is notified by the coordinator that the emergency stage of the emergency agreement has been declared, and after appropriate legal notice has been given to the general public, the water use administrator is authorized to implement this section by ordering the restricted use or absolute curtailment of use of water for certain nonessential purposes including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The use of hoses, sprinklers or other means for sprinkling or watering of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, flowers or any other vegetation. 
(2)  The use of water for washing automobiles, trucks, trailers, trailer-houses or any other type of mobile equipment. 
(3)  The washing of streets, driveways, parking lots, service station aprons, office buildings, exterior of homes, sidewalks, apartments or other outdoor surfaces. 
(4)  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structures making a similar use of water. 
(5)  The use of water for filling swimming and wading pools. 
(6)  The operation of any water-cooled comfort air conditioning which does not have water conserving equipment. 
The water use administrator shall notify the coordinator of any and all such actions. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(b); Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 42-90. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this subdivision or order of the water use administrator implementing this subdivision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by section 1-12. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(c); Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 42-91. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the water use administrator shall issue an order directing restriction or curtailment of the use of water as provided herein, or shall seek suspension of water service as a result of a violation of provisions of this subdivision, the person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the decision of the water use administrator to the city council. The city council may appoint a temporary board of appeal consisting of members of the council and other appropriate parties to act in its place on this matter. The council or board of appeal shall grant such person a reasonable opportunity to present in writing or, at the option of the council or board of appeal, in open hearing, such person's arguments against such decision of the water use administrator. The council or board of appeals shall consider such arguments and pertinent facts and its decision with respect to such appeal shall be final. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(d); Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 42-92. - Exception to maintain sanitation. 
    The water use administrator, upon the recommendation of the city health officer or upon its own recognizance, shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case necessary to maintain adequate health and sanitation standards. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(e); Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 42-93. - Exceptions for business necessary to public welfare. 
(a)  The provisions of this subdivision shall not apply to any business or industry which shall be declared by resolution of the city council to be specifically excepted as necessary for the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Businesses and industries processing animal, vegetable and mineral matter for food for human consumption purposes shall be regulated in the following manner: The water use administrator, when so ordered by ordinance of the city council, shall hold a public hearing to determine the amount of water to be used based upon the amount needed during normal years in the particular business and the severity and period of the existing drought conditions. 
(c)  The utilities customer service division shall have available and furnish all records necessary to determine the usages of water restricted by this subdivision. 
(Code 1973, § 31-25; Code 1982, § 29-18(f); Ord. No. 752) 
Secs. 42-94-42-115. - Reserved.

Sec. 42-116. - New and existing installations. 
    Carwash installations shall be equipped with an approved water recycling system. This clause shall be retroactive and all existing carwash installations shall be equipped with such recycling devices by not later than one year after the effective date of the ordinance from which this subdivision is derived.

    No coin-operated carwash may be permitted to be installed and used until plans have been submitted to and approved by the administrative authority. The plans must show the method of connection to an approved sanitary sewer system, disposal of rain subsurface water and the protection of the potable water system.

DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW PREVENTION CONTROL IN WATERWORKS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, ch. 6; underground utilities, § 42-231 et seq. 

Sec. 42-150. - Adoption of state regulations. 
    Section 6.00, pertaining to cross connection and backflow prevention control in waterworks, Commonwealth of Virginia Waterworks Regulations is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this Code, as fully as if set out at length herein, save and except such portions as are modified, amended or deleted hereby. Three copies of such regulations together with a copy of this division attached to each shall be filed and maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1982, § 6-106; Ord. No. 776) 
Sec. 42-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air gap separation means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying pure water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the rim of the receptacle. 
    Auxiliary water system means any water system on or available to the premises other than the waterworks. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's waterworks; or water from a source such as wells, lakes or streams; or process fluids; or used water. They may be polluted or contaminated or objectionable, or constitute a water source or system over which the water purveyor does not have control. 
    Backflow means the flow of contaminants, pollutants, process fluids, used water, untreated waters, chemicals, gases, or nonpotable waters into any part of a waterworks. 
    Backflow prevention device means any approved device, method, or type of construction intended to prevent backflow into a waterworks. 
    Consumer means the owner or person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a waterworks. 
    Consumer's water system means any water system located on the consumer's premises, supplied by or in any manner connected to a waterworks. 
    Contamination means any introduction into pure water of microorganisms, wastes, wastewater, undesirable chemicals or gases. 
    Cross connection means any connection or structural arrangement, direct or indirect, to the waterworks whereby backflow can occur. 
    Degree of hazard means the term that is derived from an evaluation of the potential risk to health and the adverse effect upon the waterworks. 
    Double gate-double checkvalve assembly means an approved assembly composed of two single, independently acting checkvalves including tightly closing shut-off valves located at each end of the assembly and petcocks and test gauges for testing the watertightness of each checkvalve. 
    Health hazard means any condition, device or practice in a waterworks or its operation that creates, or may create, a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. 
    Interchangeable connection means an arrangement or device that will allow alternate but not simultaneous use of two sources of water. 
    Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (chemical, physical, radiological or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute an unnecessary risk or impair the usefulness of the water. 
    Pollution hazard means a condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or degrading material may enter the waterworks or a consumer's water system. 
    Process fluids means any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted which would constitute a health, pollution or system hazard, if introduced into the waterworks. This includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Polluted or contaminated waters; 
(2)  Process waters; 
(3)  Used waters originating from the waterworks which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; 
(4)  Cooling waters; 
(5)  Contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams or irrigation systems; 
(6)  Chemicals in solution or suspension; and 
(7)  Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquor and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes. 
    Pure water or potable water means water fit for human consumption and use which is sanitary and normally free of minerals, organic substances and toxic agents in excess of reasonable amounts for domestic usage in the area served, and normally adequate in supply for the minimum health requirement of the persons served. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device means a device containing a minimum of two independently acting checkvalves together with an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the two checkvalves. During normal flow and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two checkvalves shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either checkvalve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the checkvalves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shut-off valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. These devices must be of approved type. 
    Service connection means the terminal end of a service line from the waterworks. If a meter is installed at the end of the service, then the service connection means the downstream end of the meter. 
    System hazard means a condition posing an actual, or threat of, damage to the physical properties of the waterworks or a consumer's water system. 
    Used water means any water supplied by a water purveyor from waterworks to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the service connection. 
    Water purveyor means an individual, group of individuals, partnership, firm, association, institution, corporation, municipal corporation, county or authority which supplies water to any person within this state from or by means of any waterworks. 
    Waterworks means all structures and appliances used in connection with the collection, storage, purification and treatment of water for drinking or domestic use and the distribution to the public or residential consumers as set forth in Code of Virginia, § 32.1-167 et seq., as amended. 
(Code 1982, § 6-107; Ord. No. 776) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-152. - Inspections. 
    The city shall cause inspections to be made of properties served by the waterworks where cross connection with the waterworks is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections, based on potential health hazards involved, shall be established by the city manager in the cross connection control and backflow prevention program and as approved by the state department of health. 
(Code 1982, § 6-108; Ord. No. 776) 
Sec. 42-153. - Administrative authority. 
    The representative of the city, as designated by the city manager, shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time properties served by a connection to the waterworks of the city piping system for cross connections. Upon request, the owners or occupants of property served shall furnish to the inspection agency pertinent information regarding the piping system on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(Code 1982, § 6-109; Ord. No. 776) 
Sec. 42-154. - Discontinuation of service. 
    The water purveyor may deny or discontinue the water service to a consumer if the required backflow prevention device is not installed. If it is found that the device has been removed or bypassed or if a cross connection exists on the premises, or if the pressure in the waterworks is lowered below ten pounds per square inch gauge, the purveyor shall take positive action to ensure that the waterworks is adequately protected at all times. Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the deficiencies have been corrected or eliminated in accordance with state waterworks regulations and to the satisfaction of the purveyor. 
(Code 1982, § 6-110; Ord. No. 776) 
Sec. 42-155. - Protection of water system. 
    The water purveyor or its agent shall require that the potable water made available to the properties served by the waterworks shall be protected by the consumer from possible contamination or pollution, by enforcement of this division and the city plumbing code. Any water outlet which would be used for potable or domestic purposes and is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled as "Water Unsafe for Drinking" in a conspicuous manner. 
(Code 1982, § 6-111; Ord. No. 776) 
Sec. 42-156. - Penalty; violations. 
(a)  Any person or customer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this division, or any written order of the duly designated representative of the city, in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as per section 1-12. 
(b)  Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this division shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purposes of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 6-112; Ord. No. 776) 
Secs. 42-157-42-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Sewage disposal generally, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-163 et seq. 

Sec. 42-171. - Regulation and protection of public sewers. 
(a)  Deposits, obstructing flow. No person shall throw or deposit in or upon any public drainage ditch, streambed, storm or sanitary sewer, or any trap, basin or other appurtenance of any public storm or sanitary sewer in the city, any matter, organic or inorganic, except groundwater or roof water discharged into a public storm sewer when approved by the administrative authority, or matter normally discharged into a sanitary sewer from industrial, commercial or residential structures. Nor shall any person obstruct, impede, or cause to be impeded or obstructed, the flow of any public drainage ditch, streambed, storm or sanitary sewer, nor interfere with the free discharge or ventilation, nor clog up any appurtenance. 
(b)  Entry. No person other than on-duty employees of the city shall enter any public storm or sanitary sewer or appurtenance without a written permit from the city manager or the designee of the city manager; provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to a master plumber acting under circumstances of emergency. 
(c)  Cutting, tapping. No person shall cut, break, damage, pierce or tap any public storm or sanitary sewer or appurtenance, or introduce any tube, pipe, trough or conduit into any public storm or sanitary sewer or appurtenance without a written permit from the city manager, or the designee of the city manager; provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to a master plumber acting under circumstances of emergency. 
(d)  Lifting manhole covers, etc. No person other than on-duty employees of the city shall turn, lift, remove, raise or tamper with any cover of any manhole, basin, inlet or other appurtenance of any public storm or any sanitary sewer without a written permit from the city manager or the designee of the city manager; provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to master plumber acting under circumstances of emergency. 
(e)  Prohibited discharges. No person shall make or maintain any connection with any public storm or sanitary sewer or appurtenance whereby there may be conveyed into same any hot, suffocating, corrosive, inflammable or explosive liquid, gas, vapor, substance or material of any kind; provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to hot water heaters when properly connected as required by the plumbing code or to boilers installed and operating in accordance with the provisions of the building code. 
(Code 1973, § 31-26; Code 1982, § 29-19) 
Sec. 42-172. - Availability charge. 
(a)  Classification of customers. All customers will be classified into one of the following categories: single-family; townhouse; apartment; commercial; municipal. 
(1)  Single-family and townhouse customers with established winter quarter consumption. Sewer service charges for single-family and townhouse class customers will be based on either the previous smooth winter quarter water usage or the actual water usage during the quarter, whichever is less. 
(2)  Single-family and townhouse customers without established winter quarter consumption. Sewer services charges for single-family and townhouse class customers who have not established a winter quarter consumption will be based on either an average consumption of similar units or the current quarter's water consumption, whichever is less. 
(3)  Commercial, apartment and municipal class customers. Sewer service charges for commercial, apartments and municipal class customers will be billed on the basis of all water consumed during a given month or quarter. 
(4)  Single-family and townhouse customers not connected to public water supply. Sewer service charges for single-family and townhouse class customers who have only a sanitary sewer connection will be based on the number of people at the residence up to a maximum of four. It will be assumed that: 
a.  One person uses 5,000 gallons a quarter. 
b.  Two people use 10,000 gallons a quarter. 
c.  Three people use 15,000 gallons a quarter. 
d.  Four or more people use 19,000 gallons a quarter. 
(5)  Pro-ration of initial and final bills. 
a.  For single-family and townhouse class customers connected to public water supply: new accounts that do not include an entire quarter will be billed based on the lesser of the actual water consumption or the pro-rated (based on the number of days) portion of the household average for the prior winter quarter. 
Final bills will be based on the lesser of the actual water consumption or the pro-rated winter quarter figure for the respective account. 
b.  For single-family and townhouse class customers not connected to public water supply: initial and final bills that do not include an entire winter quarter will be pro-rated based on the number of days actually on service. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  The winter quarter billing period is defined as any quarterly billing period based on meter readings obtained in the months of February through April. 
(2)  Smooth winter quarter is defined as a customer's winter quarter consumption averaged on a daily basis for their meter-reading period and extrapolated to a standard length quarter of 91.25 days (365 divided by 4) or 91.5 (366 divided by 4) during a leap year. 
(3)  For computational purposes, the billing year utilizing the preceding smooth winter quarter begins on July 1 and end the following June 30. 
(c)  Advance quarterly use charge and commodity charges. 
(1)  The first bill a customer receives shall include an advance quarterly use charge of $18.50. 
(2)  The sewer charge as determined by the appropriate method noted above shall be $9.87 per 1,000 gallons of water billed. 
(3)  A fixed charge of $6.00 for quarterly customers and $2.00 for monthly customers shall be included in each bill. 
(d)  Sewer revenue fund. All charges for sewer service collected by the city shall be credited to the sewer revenue fund.
